**Prohibition of Sales to EEA Retail Investors**

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or
otherwise made available to any retail investor in a member state of the EEA. For the purposes of this paragraph,
a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (a) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1)
of Directive 2014/65 (as amended, “MiFID II”); (b) a customer within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97
(the “Insurance Distribution Directive”), where that customer would not qualify as a “professional client” as
defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II; or (c) not a “qualified investor” as defined in Regulation (EU)
2017/1129 (as amended, the “Prospectus Regulation”).

Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (as amended, the
“PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in
the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any
retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation.

This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in any member state of the
EEA will be made pursuant to an exemption under the Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a
prospectus for offers of Notes. This Offering Memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the Prospectus
Regulation.

**Monitchem Holdco 3 S.A.**

**€250,000,000** **Floating Rate Notes due 2028**
**€420,000,000** **8.75% Fixed Rate Notes due 2028**

Monitchem Holdco 3 S.A., a public limited liability company (société anonyme) incorporated and existing under the laws of Luxembourg (the “Issuer”),
is offering €250,000,000 aggregate principal amount of its Floating Rate Notes due 2028 (the “Floating Rate Notes”) and €420,000,000 aggregate principal
amount of its 8.75% Fixed Rate Notes due 2028 (the “Fixed Rate Notes” and, together with the Floating Rate Notes, the “Notes”). The Issuer is an entity
beneficially owned principally by Permira Funds (as defined herein).
The Floating Rate Notes will mature on May 1, 2028. The Issuer will pay interest on the Floating Rate Notes at a per annum rate equal to three-month
EURIBOR (subject to a zero floor) plus 5.25% per year, reset quarterly. Interest will be paid on the Floating Rate Notes quarterly in arrears on March 15,
June 15, September 15 and December 15 of each year, beginning on September 15, 2023. The Fixed Rate Notes will mature on May 1, 2028. The Issuer
will pay interest on the Fixed Rate Notes semi-annually on each June 15 and December 15, commencing December 15, 2023.
The Issuer may redeem the Notes at the times and at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum.

Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all of the relevant series
of Notes at a redemption price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any. However, a
change of control will not be deemed to have occurred on one occation if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded as a result of such
event. In addition, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the relevant series of Notes upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax
law.
The Notes will be the Issuer’s general, senior obligations and will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of the Issuer
that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including obligations under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement (as defined
herein), certain cash management obligations, if any, and certain hedging obligations, if any, and rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future
obligations of the Issuer that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, if any. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis (the “Notes
**Guarantees” and each, a “Notes Guarantee”) (i) on or about the Issue Date, by CABB Group GmbH and (ii) within 120 days of the Issue Date, by the**
Subsidiary Guarantors (as defined herein) (each a “Guarantor” and together, the “Guarantors”). The Notes Guarantee issued by each Guarantor will rank
_pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of that Guarantor that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such_
Notes Guarantee (including indebtedness incurred under the New Revolving Credit Facilities, certain cash management obligations, if any, and certain
hedging obligations, if any) and rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are expressly subordinated in
right of payment to such Notes Guarantee, if any.
On or about the Issue Date, each series of the Notes will be secured by the Issue Date Collateral (as defined herein). Within 120 days of the Issue Date,
subject to agreed security principles, the Notes will also be secured by the Post-Issue Date Collateral (as defined herein). Under the terms of the Intercreditor
Agreement (as defined herein), in the event of enforcement of the security interests, holders of Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after
amounts owing under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement have been repaid in full. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes—The
_Collateral may not be sufficient to secure the obligations under the Notes.” The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the security interests_
and the liability of the Guarantors will be subject to the limitations described in “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees
_and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_

There is currently no public market for the Notes. We will apply to have the Notes listed on the Securities Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange
(the “LuxSE”), without admission to trading on one of the securities markets operated by LuxSE. There is no assurance that the Notes will be, or will
remain, listed on the Securities Official List of the LuxSE.

**Investing in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. See “Risk Factors” beginning on page 25.**

**Price for the Floating Rate Notes: 97.5% plus accrued interest, if any, from the Issue Date.**

**Price for the Fixed Rate Notes: 100.0% plus accrued interest, if any, from the Issue Date.**

We expect that the Notes will be delivered in book-entry form through Euroclear Bank SA/NV (“Euroclear”) and Clearstream Banking S.A.
(“Clearstream”) on or about April 28, 2023 (the “Issue Date”).

**Adoption of new accounting standards**

With effect from January 1, 2022, we applied certain new and amended standards and interpretations published
by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and endorsed by the European Union. The amendments
had no material impact on the Group’s financial position or results of operations:

- Amendments to IFRS 3 Business Combinations, IAS 16 Property, Plant and Equipment, IAS 37 Provisions,
Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets as well as Annual Improvements to IFRS 2018 – 2020. The
amendments to IFRS include an update of the reference of the Conceptual Framework in IFRS standards.
Furthermore, an additional provision was added to IFRS 3 stating that an acquirer must apply the provisions
from IAS 37 and IFRIC 21 rather than the Conceptual Framework when identifying assumed liabilities within
the scope of these standards.

- The amendments to IAS 16 specify that income received by a company through the sale of items produced
while the asset is being brought to its location and into working order must be recognized with the associated
costs in profit or loss. Including these items in the cost of the asset is not permissible.

- The amendments to IAS 37 specify which costs an entity includes in determining the cost of fulfilling a
contract for the purpose of assessing whether the contract is onerous. The amendments apply for annual
reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2022 to contracts existing at the date when the amendments
are first applied. At the date of initial application, the cumulative effect of applying the amendments is

i


-----

recognized as an opening balance adjustment to retained earnings or other components of equity, as
appropriate. The comparatives are not restated.

- The annual improvements to IFRS 2018 – 2020 pertain to amendments to IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments,
whereby only such costs and fees which are paid to the lender by the company and vice versa are to be
included in the “10% test” for the purpose of derecognition of financial liabilities. Costs or fees paid to other
third parties may not to be included. Moreover, they pertain to minor amendments to IFRS 1 First-Time
Adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards, IAS 41 Agriculture, and to the explanatory
examples of IFRS 16 Leases.

**Segmental Reporting Change**

In 2021, the Group’s business was reorganized into a new corporate structure, which transferred the two former
business units “Custom Manufacturing” and “Acetyls” into a fully integrated organization, “One CABB.” As a
result, the Group no longer reports segment information relating to the two former business units “Custom
Manufacturing” and “Acetyls” and therefore, the financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2021 and
2022 are not directly comparable against the financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020.

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

This Offering Memorandum contains non-IFRS measures and ratios, including Reported EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Group Net Working Capital, Operating Net Working Capital, Capital
Expenditure, Total Net Financial Debt, Cash Generation and Cash Conversion that are not required by, or
presented in accordance with, IFRS. Our non-IFRS measures are defined by us as follows:

We define “Reported EBITDA” as net result for the period adding back taxes on income, financial results,
amortization and depreciation.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA” as net result for the period adding back taxes on income, financial result,
amortization and depreciation and adjustments for expenses and income not related to the operational performance
of the business activities, such as strategic projects, restructuring and reorganization measures, financial impacts
of natural disasters, property damage insurance compensations, as well as valuation impacts resulting from
curtailments or modifications to pension or post-retirement benefits schemes and purchase price allocations.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA Margin” as Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue.

We define “Group Net Working Capital” as inventories plus accounts receivable, trade plus contract assets plus
other non-financial receivables plus income tax receivables minus accounts payable, trade minus contract
liabilities minus income tax liabilities minus other non-financial liabilities.

We define “Operating Net Working Capital” as Group Net Working Capital minus purchase price allocation
(“PPA”) valuation on inventory plus net working capital of holding entities plus net income tax receivables.

We define “Capital Expenditure” acquisition of intangible assets plus acquisition of property, plant and
equipment as stated in the cash flow statement. Total Capital Expenditure includes paid capital expenditures only.

We define “Total Net Financial Debt” as the aggregate principal amount of notes, loans from non-controlling
interests, accrued interests, lease liabilities, the negative fair value of interest rate swap agreements and utilized
revolving credit facilities, less short-term cash deposits as well as cash and cash equivalents.

We define “Cash Generation” as Adjusted EBITDA minus net cash flow from investing activities.

We define “Cash Conversion” as Cash Generation divided by Adjusted EBITDA.

We present non-IFRS measures because we believe that they and similar measures are widely used by certain
investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity.
The non-IFRS measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and have
limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our
operating result as reported under IFRS. Non-IFRS measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance
or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to profit for the year or any other performance
measures derived in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles or as alternatives
to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities.

**Business Overview**

We are a leading CDMO (contract development and manufacturing organization) and fine chemistry manufacturer
with global operations, supplying customized ingredients to major players in the Western Crop Science market,
as well as high purity and high-complexity chemical ingredients to customers in the Life Science and Performance
Material markets. Our strong technology portfolio, technical know-how and execution capabilities allow us to
cover a wide spectrum of highly specialized customer needs, specifications and complexity profiles.

Headquartered in Germany, we operate a global network with six production facilities located in Pratteln
(Switzerland), Kokkola (Finland), Galena (Kansas, United States), Gersthofen (Germany), Knapsack (Germany)
and Jining, Shandong Province (China).

Our varied product portfolio is organized across two product groups: (i) Exclusives (tailor-made active ingredients
and precursors developed for individual customers on an exclusive basis (our CDMO offering)) and Specialties
(highly specialized ingredients with applications in high-margin end-markets) products and (ii) Advanced
Intermediates and Base Chemicals products (intermediate and base chemical products such as high purity
monochloroacetic acid (“MCA”), chloroacetyl chloride (“CAC1”) and caustic soda across a large purity spectrum
with multiple end-use applications).

Our products are deeply embedded into our customers’ value chains, often on a near-exclusive basis, allowing us
to be aligned in demand planning and supply chain coordination and to set up scalable manufacturing facilities
and efficient commercial production processes. The combination of our production know-how, lengthy product
development processes and contractually agreed capital expenditure contributions for some of our products
typically result in high contract renewal rates and low customer churn.

For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenue of €755.5 million and an Adjusted
EBITDA of €162.6 million (21.5% Adjusted EBITDA margin). Between 2020 and 2022, our revenue grew at
23.9% CAGR, whereas our Adjusted EBITDA grew at 20.0% CAGR. Exclusives and Specialties contributed to
56.8% of our revenue for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 whereas Advanced Intermediates and Base
Chemicals accounted for 43.2% of our revenue for the same period.

Our products are used for end-market applications mainly in: (i) Crop Science (e.g., herbicides, fungicides,
insecticides and other livestock and crop protection products), (ii) Life Science (e.g., pharma, personal care,
nutrition, fragrances and flavor applications) and (iii) Performance Materials (e.g., curatives in epoxies,
polyimides, polyesters and other resin systems used for electronic components, semiconductors and for
composites, fibers, films, and foams that provide heat and electrical resistance). These end-markets, in particular
Crop Science, have shown resilient historical growth rates and benefit from structural mega-trends that are
expected to drive further resilient growth in the near- to mid-term, such as increasing demand for food and need
for increased farming yields on the one hand, and an aging population and improving living standards on the other.
In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of our products were used in the
Crop Science market, approximately 20% in the Life Science market, approximately 15% in the Performance
Materials market and approximately 15% relate to others (e.g., base chemicals and industrial MCA) (measured as
a percentage of revenues).

Exclusives, our CDMO offering, provides tailor-made active ingredients and precursors tailored to individual
customer specifications in Crop Science and are a primary contributor to our overall profitability. Based on
customer-developed IP, these products require customized production lines, expansive know-how and close
cooperation with our customers. We offer development and manufacturing services for proprietary products on
an exclusive and confidential basis to leading players in the Crop Science market such as: BASF, Bayer, Corteva
and Syngenta, and we have relationships with nearly all major players in the Western Crop Science market.

1


-----

Our Specialties offering consists of specialty ingredients that leverage our considerable manufacturing expertise
to create complex chemical products that serve specific customer needs across a variety of applications in the
Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials industries. Unlike Exclusives, these products can be
offered to multiple customers at a time. Our offering highlights our excellent production capabilities and knowhow along with our ability to offer specialized technology process and development services which allows us to
continuously provide high-quality and purity products to our customers and which we believe is a key
differentiator in this field. Our Specialties products are also a strong contributor to profitability, leveraging our
close client relationship and high customer “stickiness”. In particular, we offer high value-add products for fastgrowing applications in Life Science (pharma and personal care as well as nutrition) and Performance Materials
markets (coatings, e.g., in electronics or other industrial applications), backed by several attractive long-term
customer contracts, which offer high visibility on the lifecycle and returns on our products. Customers for our
Specialties products include players such as Agilent Technologies, Bayer, Corteva, Deciem/Estee Lauder, DSM,
Evonik, Merck, Novartis and Syngenta.

In our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group, we offer intermediate and base chemical
products, such as MCA, CAC1 and caustic soda, that serve as chemical building blocks for other secondary
chemical processes with a variety of applications across a large number of industries and markets. We believe we
are one of the leading suppliers of MCA to Western Europe and the Americas and we operate state-of-the-art sites,
allowing us to provide a full range of purity and quality for our customers. Large parts of our Advanced
Intermediates supply agreements feature price formulas that allow us to partially pass on price increases in costs
of certain raw materials. Furthermore, we also generate a portion of our revenue from Base Chemicals and other
products such as caustic soda, that are generated as by-products from our Exclusives and Advanced Intermediates
production lines.

**Our Strengths**

**_Structurally growing end-markets and increasing outsourcing trends_**

Our underlying key end-markets (Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials) are enjoying strong and
resilient underlying growth, further supported by increasing outsourcing trends that are reinforcing demand for
our Crop Science CDMO offering.

In the financial year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 70% of our revenue was generated in the Crop
Science and Life Science markets (estimate based on internal company assessments), the majority of which
consists of our CDMO offering through our Exclusives products and to a smaller degree of contributions from
our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals products. As a result, growth in the underlying Crop Science
and Life Science markets, specifically within CDMO products and novel advanced intermediates, represent key
growth levers for our business.

_Crop Science_

Our addressable CDMO Crop Science market grew by 9% to 10% CAGR between 2019 and 2022, outperforming
the underlying global market for Crop Science products which grew by approximately 8% CAGR during the same
period (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor). Market research indicates continued growth until 2027 with
respect to both our addressable CDMO Crop Science market (4% to 5% CAGR from 2022 to 2027) and the
underlying global market for Crop Science products (2% CAGR) (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor). For
more information on the specific historical and projected growth of the addressable CDMO Crop Science and
underlying global Crop Science markets, see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺General.”

The growth in the underlying global Crop Science market in particular is underpinned by the following megatrends (see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺Key Drivers” for a more detailed overview) (Roland
Berger Report, AgbioInvestor):

    - Growing population: global population growth drives demand for food and crops; and

    - Decreasing arable land: arable land per capita is decreasing, requiring efficient crop protection
products to increase farming yields.

These market dynamics are further supported by several specific trends in the addressable CDMO Crop Science
market, including (see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺Key Drivers” for a more detailed overview)
(Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor, Company Information):

2


-----

    - Growth in CDMO outsourcing: customers prioritizing research and development, sales and
marketing and digitalization activities and striving to reduce their capital intensity and costs (in 2022,
approximately 40% to 50% of active ingredient production by Crop Science Players was outsourced
to CDMOs);

    - Increasing complexity of active ingredient molecules: requires specialist CDMO partners with strong
technical expertise and assets fitting into global supply chains of Crop Science players; and

    - Increasingly stringent regulatory requirements: lead to higher demand for novel active ingredients,
often outsourced to CDMOs with highly efficient multi-purpose facilities.

Furthermore, historical demand for crop protection products has proven to be resilient to adverse events
maintaining a growth trend in spite of temporary downturns. For example, declines in average crop commodity
prices (e.g., corn, wheat, soybean) caused by events such as lower pest pressure and economic recessions in
production markets such as in Brazil, and North American weather conditions in 2019 led to a temporary downturn
in the crop protection market but were followed by year-on-year increases. Furthermore, while agrochemical
production was impacted by coronavirus-related restrictions in the first quarter of 2020, it swiftly normalized
following an easing of lockdown restrictions. While the coronavirus restrictions did impact labor availability both
in terms of production and field work, many countries deemed the agricultural sector to be of considerable
importance in maintaining food security, so restrictions on movement were less severe than in most industries
(Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

The addressable market for novel active ingredients (active ingredients introduced after 2010), a subset of the
CDMO Crop Science market, is anticipating significantly higher growth rates at a CAGR of approximately 13.7%
from 2021 to 2027, owing to, among other factors, a higher outsourcing rate due to production complexity (Roland
Berger Report). Against this background, we act as a key partner for our clients in this area, supporting innovators
with our technical expertise and state-of-the-art production facilities. Our Crop Science product portfolio benefits
from a modern set of active ingredients. We are not materially involved in the production of raw materials or
finished product for glyphosate or neonicotinoids.

_Life Science_

Our Specialty products benefit from the strong underlying growth rates in a number of attractive niche markets
for specialized Life Science applications. In 2022, the addressable Life Science market accounted for the second
largest portion of our revenue after the Crop Science market. Our products in this area consist primarily of
Advanced Intermediates products as well as Specialties products.

Our addressable Life Science markets grew between 2019 and 2022 and are expected to grow further, driven by
structural mega-trends including a global aging population and an increasing disposable income spent on personal
care, showing the strength of this segment for our future growth potential (Roland Berger Report, Company
Information). For more information on trends driving Life Sciences growth (including niche markets), see
“Industry and Market Data⸺Life Science⸺Key Drivers.”

Individual addressable high growth sub-markets such as the oligonucleotide synthesis market (used for the
production of synthetic RNA and DNA templates) increased significantly in 2021 and 2022, and forecasts are
estimating future significant growth. See also “Industry and Market Data⸺Life Science⸺General⸺DCA.”
While this is in part due to the market’s limited current size, it also highlights how we may be able to leverage
our technical excellence to capitalize on developing demand for high-purity ingredients. For example, we are the
global market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high purity grade DCA (a key ingredient for RNAbased medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications (by high purity DCA revenue as of 2022).
Furthermore, DCA applications in the production of synthetic RNA and DNA templates have wider uses in the
Life Sciences industry than COVID-19 applications (where mostly enzymatic synthesis is employed), so our
product has only some commercial exposure to the trends driving COVID-19 vaccines and will benefit from
growing end markets due to both increased investments into research and development (e.g. improvement of
genomic technologies) as well as broader commercial use (e.g. “oligonucleotide therapeutics”), see “Industry and
_Market Data⸺Life Science⸺DCA⸺Key Drivers” (Roland Berger Report, Company Information)._

_Performance Materials_

Our Specialties products with niche applications benefit from attractive market dynamics in addressable endmarkets in the Performance Materials segment, BTDA, 6FDA and other markets, which are expected to grow

Our BTDA and 6FDA products are used for numerous applications in electronics, infrastructure and transportation

**_Leading Crop Science CDMO and Differentiated Life Science Ingredients Player with Global Presence_**

We are a leading player in the Western Crop Science CDMO market, serving major global agrochemicals
companies and holding strategic supplier status with some of the largest European-based Crop Science companies
for their agrochemicals business. We are among the top two Western CDMO players in the Crop Science market
(by Crop Science CDMO revenue as of 2021). We have a strong focus on novel active ingredients, directly
competing with only a select number of other Tier 1 players that are able to serve this segment. We are wellpositioned within the top five players globally in the Crop Science market (measured by Crop Science CDMO
revenue as of 2021) due to strong customer relationships, diverse and unique asset footprint and technical knowhow (Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

We also have a significant presence in the Life Science market, providing customized products in segments such
as novel RNA therapeutics, vitamins and supplements, and anti-aging and personal care and hold leading positions
in the markets for European MCA supply, high purity DCA, as well as CAE manufacturing and cosmetic grade
GA in Life Science: We are one of the largest European Life Science MCA suppliers (by production volume in
Europe as of 2022). We are the global market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high purity grade
DCA (a key ingredient for RNA-based medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications (by high purity
DCA revenue as of 2022) (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). In cosmetic grade GA, we are globally
the second largest supplier (measured by revenue as of 2022) and the only European producer with global coverage
(Company assessment based on Roland Berger Report).

Our customized products are highly integrated in our key customers’ value chains (sometimes protected by “key
supplier” relationships for major products), and we are closely aligned in demand planning and coordination. We
have flexible multi-purpose contract manufacturing plants that allow for optimized downtimes between different
product campaigns and change-overs. Furthermore, we benefit from six well-invested sites across the globe
offering reliability, safety and high product quality. As a result, we have developed a strong reputation of reliable
performance in delivering innovative products in large quantities to our clients. We also operate a global site
network with assets spanning the U.S., Europe and China, which we believe is unique among Tier 1 Crop Science
CDMOs.

**_Longstanding, Trusted Relationships with Diversified, Blue-Chip Customer Base_**

We have long-standing relationships with most of our blue-chip customers. We are a trusted partner to major
players in the Crop Science market and numerous leading specialties companies in the Life Science and
Performance Materials markets rely on our solutions and significant expertise for their products and applications.
High customer retention rates serve as a competitive moat against new entrants: For example, in 2021 and 2022,
we had an overall average customer retention rate of approximately 98% (based on existing customer revenue
over total revenue for the respective year), which illustrates, together with the high rate of contract renewal and
lock-in effects, the “stickiness” of our topline in Exclusives.

Our average duration of business relationships with our top four customers in Crop Science exceeds 15 years in
tenure (based on management estimates between 2020 and 2022) and a number of our Crop Science blue-chip
relationships span more than 30 years (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). Together with the high
revenue visibility that most of our longer-term contracts in Exclusives provide, our customers’ long-term
commitments are supported by a track record of co-investments in production facilities through upfront capital
expenditure or top-up pricing over the term of the contract. We supply a multitude of individual products to our
top customers, which we believe indicates our customers’ trust in our capabilities and the quality of our varied
products. In 2021 and 2022, we supplied more than 10 products for each of our top three customers.

4


-----

Our customer base in particular reflects our established position and depth of integration into their respective
value chains, with the top ten customers by revenue across all markets accounting for approximately 60%, based
on internal assessments, of our group-wide revenue in the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Our
established customer base in our CDMO Crop Science business includes the top five Crop Science majors across
all major crop systems in our key end-markets, with whom we work in close cooperation in terms of process
development and planning as well as the lifecycle of the project (Roland Berger Report, Company Information).
In addition, while agrochemicals are a key end-market for our products, we are diversifying into other applications
such as further high-value intermediates within Advanced Intermediates, pharmaceuticals and Specialties. For our
Exclusives products in particular, the close customer cooperation enables de-risked investments in growth capex
for further capacity and technology expansion through customer contributions (e.g., capex co-investment or ‘takeor-pay’ commitments by customers).

Over the last three years, we have established a track record of consistent project wins (at least one major 1 [st]
campaign project per year), building upon our deep integration into our customers’ value chains and our reputation
of reliability and ability to manage complex processes. As of March 31, 2023, we also had multiple projects in
varying ramp-up phases, supporting growth of the business. The growth capex associated with these ramp-up
projects mainly targets or has targeted capacity expansion for Exclusives and Specialties across our plants, and
production under these projects is expected to ramp-up over the short-term.

**_Attractive CDMO business model: high visibility, de-risked growth and recurring earnings_**

For our Exclusives products, we have developed strategic partnerships with well-known companies, including
some of the largest global agrochemicals producers, including blue chip customers in our key end-markets. Due
to our high level of integration into our customers’ product development and long contract terms for most of our
contracts, we have high visibility on the lifecycle and returns on our products. Our long-term contracts often
provide for guaranteed volumes in the initial period, contributing to a high contract renewal rate and low customer
churn for a large part of our portfolio. Because of our strong market position and customer integration, we also
have high visibility into our customers’ future demand and their upcoming product launches. For example, we
received customer inquiries from five top Crop Science players for 70% of all active ingredients launched or
planned to be launched in the market between 2020 and 2023E (calculated as share of novel active ingredients
and advanced/key intermediate launches where we were inquired) and have won projects in novel active
ingredients with these players at a success rate of approximately 40% (calculated as the share of projects won if
we were inquired).

Moreover, our customers in the CDMO business typically contractually agree for new products to either (i)
contribute a portion of the capital expenditures related to new product developments and the production line setup,
with minimum contract terms providing payback of the capital expenditures incurred directly by us, or (ii) firm
take-or-pay agreements with limited capital expenditures contributions upfront. We continue to invest
significantly in growth projects to deliver contracted new product wins and in maintenance to safeguard asset
reliability. Our disciplined selection criteria in our CDMO business are focused on superior contracts with limited
investment periods for growth capex projects where we typically target EBITDA pay-back periods of
approximately three years and return rates of approximately 25% IRR secured by binding customer capex or
offtake commitments. While this is not achieved in all our projects, we aim to strengthen our product portfolio
over time with projects that either match our key criteria or otherwise offer strategic opportunities.

We are well positioned to benefit from the ramp-up of contracted growth projects in Kokkola and Pratteln with
an existing agreement portfolio featuring ‘take-or-pay’ commitments. For more information, see also “⸺Our
_Product Portfolio.”_

**_Resilient Top-line Growth and Strong Margins with Significant Future Upside_**

We have shown our ability to maintain high revenue growth and margin stability, especially within Exclusives
and Specialties, driven by new product wins and strong demand in the existing portfolio, while maintaining
flexibility to changing market conditions through our ability to partially pass on increasing raw material and
energy costs. Most recently, we commissioned a new line of product under a ‘take-or-pay’ contract and secured a
new contract in our Exclusives business. Our major project wins over the last four years reflect our consistent
track-record of winning and delivering large-scale projects:

In addition, our rationalization of our portfolio to focus on high margin and growth products (e.g., DCA, GA for
skin care applications) as well as price increases in Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals have further
contributed to our successful performance. We have also been able to adjust our business to the effects of the
COVID-19 pandemic without major impacts on our operations or financial results due to resilient demand from
Crop Science and Life Science customers. Driven by our management’s commitment to support high-value
products and projects, we have been able to consistently generate stable margins.

As a result, our revenue increased at a CAGR of 23.9% from €492.3 million for the financial year ended December
31, 2020 to €755.5 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Revenue growth in 2022 was primarily
driven by strong demand in both our product groups across the portfolio supported by higher pricing effects, in
particular partial pass-through of increased raw material prices and supply chain costs in our Advanced
Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group.

Our Adjusted EBITDA has grown at a CAGR of 20.0% from €112.9 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2020 to €162.6 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The significant growth in
Adjusted EBITDA in 2022 in particular was due to an increase in pricing resulting in a higher margin for our
products from customers in our Exclusives and Specialties business as well as positive pricing effects in our
Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals business.

**_Backward-integrated model that enables re-use of by-products and reduction of waste_**

Increasing operational efficiency is a top priority for us as it provides clear benefits. When these benefits are
combined, they create a virtuous cycle by minimizing negative environmental impacts, creating cost advantages
in production, driving innovation and enabling our long-term competitiveness.

Production processes always result in byproducts. We aim to reuse or commercialize such byproducts wherever
feasible and avoid waste wherever possible. To this end, we believe we operate a highly efficient circular economy
processes and we eliminate waste by developing highly efficient processes with optimized product yields and
reusing materials within production cycles. Besides the environmental and sustainability advantages, this type of
closed-loop system also has tangible financial benefits, as it can reduce costs for raw materials and waste
treatments. In Pratteln, we are contributing to the creation of a circular economy using a “Verbund System”. This
enables highly efficient and sustainable chlorination and sulfonation reactions. Chlorine and sulfur trioxide are
produced as primary raw materials and used to manufacture a variety of chlorination and sulfonation reagents. In
turn, these are used to produce further downstream intermediates and active ingredients. The HCl and SO2
generated as off-gases are separated, purified and recycled, reused or resold.

Finally, our production sites benefit from high supply chain resilience through backward integration of key raw
materials and production processes for our Exclusives and Specialties Products (by using our Advanced
Intermediates production). In particular, our main multi-purpose plant in Pratteln uses an innovative set-up that
offers high efficiency production of Exclusives and Specialties products, based on backwards integration of the
key raw materials of chlorine. Together with the supply of large volumes of necessary MCA from our sites in
Germany, we can therefore contribute to supply resilience, as we are in control of the relevant production steps
and at the same time can manage the direct commercialization of side streams generated in the production
processes, which are then sold as Base Chemicals. See “⸺Production Facilities.” We benefit from close
proximity to our customers’ main production sites in the Western markets and we focus on developing and

**_Focus on ESG and sustainability principles_**

We have made ESG one of our corporate priorities and consider it a key element of our success. Due to the nature
of our business and our position as a business partner deeply integrated into our customers’ supply chains, we are
aware of the importance of ESG in daily operations as our performance directly translates into the value chain and
ESG commitments of our partners.

We have underlined our sustainability commitment by committing to seven UN sustainable development goals,
signing the ‘UN Global Compact’, ‘Charta der Vielfalt’ and the ‘Responsible Care’ initiative. Our corporate
programs are based on external standards and assessments, and we have set up a special team as well as an ESG
management tool for implementing and monitoring our ESG measures. In 2022, we became a member of the
“Together for Sustainability” initiative, a collaboration of operating chemical companies that are committed to
sustainability throughout their value chains. From 2022 on, all our sites will undergo annual audits by Eco-Vadis
with the latest ratings conducted in 2022. Furthermore, our holistic approach to ESG is reflected by, among other
indicators, our twelve sustainability targets, which comprise seven targets by 2025 and five by 2030, respectively,
and by the role of ESG performance in management bonus schemes.

In addition, we are focused on our social responsibility and, as a result, strive to offer employees an attractive and
inspiring work environment that provides opportunities for individual development and growth. We focus on
promoting diversity as well as occupational health and safety as essential components for operational excellence.
See “Our Business⸺ESG and Sustainability.”

**_Focused, Credible Management Team with Proven Track Record_**

We have a highly qualified workforce alongside an experienced management team with deep industry experience.
Our management team has successfully repositioned CABB as an integrated CDMO platform and led a significant
step-up in growth and margin since 2018, effectively managing our continued success during the COVID-19
pandemic.

Our demonstrated track record has been achieved by strict contract discipline and a streamlined organizational
setup, while simultaneously leveraging efficiencies from OneCABB (which combined our legacy business units
into one integrated company to flatten the organizational structure and drive efficiencies across functions) and
making further improvements to operational excellence. This has been the basis of the successful transformation
of our business, developing a differentiated CDMO position with highly successful year-over-year improvements
over the past five years, including developing on our environmental, social and governance practices.

We believe our management’s industry knowledge and leadership, combined with their long-term experience,
provide us with the skills necessary to continue improving performance and efficiency through a common
corporate infrastructure and the implementation of best practices across our network, which constitutes a

On March 24, 2023, we announced that Thomas H. Ahrens will become the new chief executive officer of CABB

**Our Strategy**

The following is a summary of the activities we are currently undertaking in pursuit of these opportunities:

**_Deliver excellence in production to optimize profitability_**

We are focused on further developing our project portfolio and aim to add more high-value projects to our
portfolio each year, keeping in line with our historical project win rates. Our established market position in
Exclusives serves as the backbone of our strategy by continuously driving resilient growth and margin stability,
complemented by high growth in existing niche markets in Specialties and further supported by fundamental
market trends. We are dedicated to continue focusing on novel active ingredients and high-value products,
expanding our distribution and geographical reach in our Life Science applications and focusing on high-purity
and higher margin segments in Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals for attractive contracts with
increasing capacity. We aim to further increase our operational excellence by focusing on efficiency,
strengthening key account and sales functions, ramp-ups of additional capacities and continuous de-bottlenecking,
as well as fostering our commercial excellence by winning new customers from large, less reliable competitors in
the MCA business.

**_Deliver de-risked capacity and technology expansion_**

We will continue to strengthen our strategic positioning in Exclusives and Specialties by focusing on novel active
ingredients and investments in state-of-the-art technologies. We believe that we can benefit from a ramp-up in a
number of contracted and already invested projects across Exclusives and Specialties products with contractual
‘take-or-pay’ or exclusivity clauses which are underpinned by a well invested asset base that, as a result,
significantly reduces the risks associated with their execution. We expect to additionally benefit from leveraging
partial cost pass-through mechanisms in future contracts. Consequently, we believe our business is highly resilient
and that the predictable customer demand for our CDMO and other highly specialized products offers high
visibility on the underlying product lifecycle and returns for a certain part of the portfolio.

**_Strong focus on client relationships and varied commercial capabilities_**

We are dedicated to winning new projects by leveraging our long-standing relationships with our blue chip
customer base as well as our know-how and reputation as a trusted Western CDMO Crop Science business partner
to accelerate and win new contracts as proven in the past. In addition, we plan to further increase our Specialties
revenue through a push of our attractive portfolio to additional geographies and customers expanding the volume
of our high margin products.

Furthermore, as some of our main customer relationships exceed 15 years, we have established ourselves as a key
outsourcing partner with trusted supplier status for our clients worldwide who often return to extend existing
projects or to collaborate with us on potential new products. As a result, we have very low customer churn,
particularly for our Exclusives and Specialties offering, and our top customers work with us for a multitude of
individual products. We will continue to strengthen those long-standing customer relationships by working closely
with our customers to meet their volume and specification needs for their existing and new products. We intend
to expand our production capacity to meet the growing demand of our key customers, continue to optimize our
production processes to share efficiency gains and work closely with them to tailor our production processes to
new products.

We intend to continue to focus on multinational customers and industry leaders, in an effort to benefit from strong
innovation and global market penetration opportunities. By further strengthening our relationships with

8


-----

multinational customers who have leading market positions in their industries, we seek to grow with them as they
expand their businesses. The introduction of OneCABB has allowed us to further streamline our customers
primary points of contact with us and will, we believe, contribute to even stronger customer relationships.

**_Develop and further expand into additional markets_**

We remain focused on targeted capacity expansion to capture growing demand and additional production volumes
that our customers seek to outsource to us, in line with new growth projects of our customers. Jayhawk, located
in the United States, produces customized agricultural, pharmaceutical and specialty chemicals and continues to
offer the potential for standalone growth from its existing pipeline portfolio and production of new products, as
well as proximity to customers in the Americas. In addition, we believe our Pratteln and Kokkola sites have
benefited from cooperation with Jayhawk due to the fact that we can offer various technologies and additional
geographies and act in an agile manner according to their needs.

By focusing on high quality services, we plan to further capture rising needs in markets which deliver higher
margin profiles, for example, pharma, personal care, nutrition and performance materials. This will allow us to
capitalize our operating leverage and efficiency gains by, for example, planning to hold plant costs relatively
stable despite topline growth. We continue to focus on high capacity utilization as the key success factor for
sustainable development, as well as optimized logistics solutions such as the addition of our leased titanium fleet
of railcars which will allow for the delivery of more product with fewer railcars due to its lower weight and better
loading factor.

**_Maintain focus on profitability and cash flow_**

We will continue to focus on improving our profitability through cost savings and efficiency enhancements where
possible, such as investments in energy saving measures, footprint optimization and automatization. We believe
that there is an ongoing potential for efficiency measures through continuous optimization of our manufacturing
processes and recycling streams. We intend to seek to further improve cash flow generation by maximizing the
utilization of our production facilities and expanding our production capacity (e.g., in Kokkola and Jayhawk), as
well as continuing investments for maintenance to preserve our well-maintained asset base. At the same time, we
plan to remain disciplined in our growth capital expenditure projects by securing customers’ longer-term volume
commitments in advance and co-investments in the form of upfront capital expenditure or top-up pricing over the
terms of customers’ contracts.

**_Maintain health, safety and environmental excellence_**

We are committed to a strategy of ESG and sustainability based on environmentally responsible manufacturing
processes and ensuring the health and safety of our employees. We aim to benefit from the strong collaboration
on ESG and sustainability with customers and industry platforms to improve our sustainability footprint while
capitalizing on operating efficiencies. The strong collaboration on ESG in negotiations is based on joint
improvement programs further developing our green footprint in our customers’ value chain which, in turn, also
contributes to operational efficiencies. Our production facilities in Pratteln and Gersthofen play a significant role
in our effort to conserve energy and resources and to reduce emissions and waste. We believe measuring ourselves
at a high standard with respect to ESG and sustainability contributes not only to environmental and societal goals
but also makes us an even more attractive partner to our business partners in their selection of partners within their
value chain. See “Our Business⸺ESG and Sustainability.”

**Our History**

Our business has its origins in the chemical production activities of Hoechst AG, which originally commissioned
our production facility in Gersthofen, Germany, in 1905 as well as our production facility in Knapsack, Germany,
in 1949. In 1997, the Hoechst Specialty Chemicals business was acquired by Clariant. Several years later, in 2003,
the CABB Group GmbH was founded as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Clariant before being acquired by an
Investment Management in 2005 and then by AXA Private Equity in the following year.

In 2007, we acquired SF Chem, including our production facility in Pratteln, Switzerland, which allowed us to
expand into contract manufacturing. In 2011, we were acquired by Bridgepoint; that same year we acquired
KemFine from 3i and commenced production at our facility in Kokkola, Finland, to further expand our contract
manufacturing capabilities.

In 2013, we expanded our footprint to Asia through the establishment of a joint venture with Jining Jinwei Gold
Power to acquire Jinwei Huasheng Chemicals. We hold a 67% stake in the joint venture entity CABB-Jinwei
Specialty Chemicals (Jining) Co., Ltd.

In 2014, we were acquired by the Permira Funds and have since invested in an electrolysis plant in Pratteln,
capacity expansions and de-bottlenecking in most facilities as well as in a new wastewater facility in China.

In 2019, we acquired Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals Corporation, one of the leading fine chemicals companies
in the U.S., from Evonik Industries AG.

In 2021, we introduced OneCABB, which combined our legacy business units into one integrated company to
flatten the organizational structure and drive efficiencies across functions.

**Principal Shareholders**

Permira is a global investment firm that backs successful businesses with growth ambitions. Founded in 1985, the
firm advises funds with total assets under management of €77 billion and makes long-term majority and minority
investments. The Permira Funds have made approximately 300 private equity investments in four key sectors:
technology, consumer, healthcare and services. Permira employs over 450 people in 15 offices across Europe,
North America, and Asia.

_risks and uncertainties we describe below are not the only ones we face. Additional risks and uncertainties of_
_which we are not aware or that we currently believe are immaterial may also adversely affect our business,_

_trading prices of the Notes could decline, we may not be able to pay interest or principal on the Notes when due_
_and you could lose all or part of your investment. The order in which these risks are presented is not intended to_

_This Offering Memorandum also contains “forward-looking” statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our_

**Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate**

**_Economic downturns or worsening global economic conditions may adversely impact our business, financial_**
**_condition, results of operation and cash flows._**

Our business is affected by changes in the general economic conditions of the industries and market segments in
which we sell our products, including, in particular, the Crop Science (e.g., herbicides, fungicides, insecticides
and other livestock and crop protection products) and Life Science (e.g., pharma, personal care, nutrition,
fragrances and flavor applications) markets, as well as the market for Performance Materials (e.g., curatives in
epoxies, polyimides, polyesters and other resin systems used for electronic components, semiconductors and for
composites, fibers, films, and foams that provide heat and electrical resistance). Any change in demand or in the
application of our products within these end-markets or the failure to accurately predict or adapt to future market
trends may negatively impact our sales and margins and could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Based on our internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of all our products were used in the Crop
Science market in 2022 (measured as a percentage of revenues). Historically, the Crop Science market has
experienced seasonal declines due to, among other things, decreasing crop commodity prices and subsequently
lower net cash income for farmers, lower pest threats which negatively affects demand for pesticides, trade
restrictions, inclement long-term weather conditions and economic recession in production markets such as in
Brazil. While the market for Crop Science has grown each year for the past three years, any future market trends
are inherently uncertain and any declines in demand for Crop Science (as well as in any other end-market) could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. This
industry is driven by structural long-term trends, such as population growth combined with an increasing calorie
intake per capita, in particular in emerging markets, and decreasing arable land per capita. Furthermore, over the
past decades, Crop Science products have become increasingly complex and newer products are required to
replace old ones, driven by either regulatory requirements or the search for more effective formulations (Roland
Berger Report, Company Information) and we may not be successful in offering the products required by our
customers. See also “⸺Risks Related to Our Business⸺We are dependent on a small number of Customers and
_Key Products for a significant portion of our revenue.”_

consumer confidence and spending as well as the general business climate and levels of business investment. This
may directly affect our customers in the food, personal care and cosmetics industries and ultimately our business,

financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. See also “⸺Risks Related to Our Business⸺We are

**_We are subject to stringent environmental, health and safety laws and regulations across multiple jurisdictions._**
**_We are highly regulated and may incur significant costs to maintain compliance with, or address liabilities_**
**_under, environmental, health and safety laws and regulations applicable to our business._**

The chemical industry is subject to increasingly stringent environmental laws and regulations in all of the
jurisdictions in which we operate or do business, including requirements under governing licenses and permits
with regard to air emissions (e.g. CO2 and NOx emissions reduction requirements), energy efficiency (e.g. energy
usage reduction), water discharge, the use, management, storage, treatment, transportation and disposal of waste
and other materials, the protection and restoration of plants, wildlife, natural resources and public health and
safety, product safety and content, the investigation and remediation of contaminated land, and worker- and
product-related health and safety, as well as numerous related reporting and record keeping requirements.

We are required to comply with environmental, health and safety laws and regulations in relation to our production
and distribution processes, and the relevant regulatory authorities carry out regular inspections to ascertain our
compliance with applicable laws, regulations and permits. The demands of compliance may require us to incur
substantial costs, including capital requirements, clean-up costs, fines or penalties, and/or may restrict our ability
to conduct our operations or to do so profitably, and, therefore, could have a material adverse effect on our business
and results of operations. Failure to comply with applicable laws and regulations may also lead to public
reprimand, fines or other sanctions, loss of ability to operate and/or sell within certain jurisdictions and damage
to our goodwill and reputation and could materially affect our business, financial condition, results of operations
and cash flows.

We cannot ensure that we will in the future be able to obtain and finance all permits which we require for our
business operations. Such failure or any violation of the terms and conditions of such permits, permitting delays
or revocation of existing permits could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results
of operations and cash flows.

We also cannot ensure whether or not future administrative action, laws, regulations, international treaties or
policies will ban or restrict the usage of some of our products or their respective ingredients or substances in the

**_Competition in our markets may adversely affect our market share, margins and overall profitability._**

Our industry is competitive and we face competition from several CDMO producers for our Exclusives products,
as well as competition from other large international chemical manufacturers and smaller regional competitors for
other parts of our business. We may face increased competition in the future from other potential new entrants in
our markets. Competition is based on several key criteria, including technology and technological capabilities,
product quality, proprietary technologies and know-how, innovation and performance, production capacity,
attractive pricing, geography, security, speed of supply and responsiveness to product development in cooperation
with customers.

Some of our existing competitors are, and potential future competitors may be, larger than we are (e.g., by revenue
or geographical coverage), may have greater financial resources and may also be able to maintain significantly
greater operating and financial flexibility than we do. As a result, these competitors may be able to better withstand
changes in conditions within our industry, fluctuations in the prices of raw materials and energy and changes in
general economic conditions. Additionally, competitors’ pricing decisions could compel us to lower our prices or
lead to loss of customers or products and, as a consequence, additional costs for investments into replacement
products and/or internal restructurings, which could adversely affect our sales, margins and profitability. See
“Risks Related to Our Business⸺We are dependent on a small number of customers and Key Products for a
_significant portion of our revenue.”_

Further, our competitors may undertake to expand their production capacity, which could lead to a shift in supply
and negative pricing impacts on our products. Our ability to maintain or increase our profitability is, and will
continue to be, dependent upon our ability to offset decreases in the prices and margins of our products by
improving production efficiency and volume, focusing on higher margin products and improving efficiency of
operations through innovation. If we are unable to do so or to otherwise maintain our competitive position, we
could lose a portion of our market share to our competitors.

**_Changes in the agricultural and certain other policies of governments and international organizations may_**
**_adversely impact the Crop Science industry and prove unfavorable to us._**

The policies of governments and international organizations may affect the income available to growers to
purchase Crop Science products used in agricultural production. In subsidized markets such as the United States,
Europe and certain markets in Asia, including Japan, reduction of subsidies to growers may inhibit the growth of
markets for products used in agriculture. In addition, changes in governmental policies that impact agriculture
may similarly inhibit the growth of markets for products used in agriculture. Specifically, government programs
that create incentives for farmers (for example, the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard) may be modified or
discontinued. However, it is difficult to predict accurately whether, and if so when, such changes will occur.
Should such changes occur, we may experience decreased demand for our products, which would adversely affect
our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We expect that the policies of governments
and international organizations will continue to affect the planting choices made by growers as well as the
subsidies available to growers to purchase products used in agriculture and, accordingly, the results of our
operations in the agriculture industry.

As a result of the outbreak of COVID-19 in late 2019 and early 2020 and its spread into numerous countries across

lockdowns nationally or on certain cities and regions, all of which have significantly impacted and could continue

measures such as staggered schedules, cleaning costs and costs for protective equipment. Uncertainty regarding

shipping products internationally, that could result in higher costs of our products. Furthermore, demand for
certain products may fluctuate in the future, negatively affecting our business, financial condition, results of

The Company has not experienced any material negative impact from COVID-19 with respect to customer

temporary full or partial shutdowns due to a rise in number of infections and our plants may experience such
shutdowns in the future. The extent of the adverse impact of an infectious disease or other serious public health
concern, including the COVID-19 pandemic, on the global economy and markets as well as on our business,
