**Risks Related to Our Business**

**_We are dependent on a small number of Customers and Key Products for a significant portion of our revenue._**

We derive a substantial portion of our revenue from several large customers and key products and the loss of any
such customer or key product would negatively impact our operations. For the financial year ended December 31,
2022, based on internal assessments, our top ten customers across all markets accounted for approximately 60%
of our total revenue. Our top 5 Exclusives products accounted for approximately 40% of our Exclusives and
Specialties revenue in the financial year ended December 31, 2022 and our top 5 Specialties products generated
approximately 15% of our Exclusives and Specialties revenue in the same period. Similarly, our top 5 Advanced
Intermediates products generated approximately 60% of our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals revenue
in the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Our inability to maintain our customer relationships with key
customers or otherwise retain their business at current levels could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. This applies across almost all our product groups.

We may lose customers or key products because of, among other things, industry consolidation, customer
dissatisfaction, competition, our customers’ products becoming obsolete, product quality and impurity concerns
or customers finding cheaper alternative products. Our sales would be adversely affected if customers who
currently outsource manufacturing of certain products to us decide to source such products internally or with one
of our competitors. For example, one of our customers has decided not to renew a supply contract for a key product
that is due to expire in 2024, which generated a mid single digit percentage of revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2022.

In addition, since certain of our products are difficult and expensive to transport over long distances, if local or
regional customers were no longer to buy such products, we may encounter difficulties in finding other customers
in the same area, which could lead to a decrease in our sales. Furthermore, we supply some of our customers,
particularly for our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals, without formal agreements in the open market,
which results in lower switching costs for our customers and reduces our ability to predict our sales to such
customers in the long-term.

29


-----

Several of our key customers require us to undergo a manufacturer certification process for new products in
connection with the registration they undergo when registering a new product or formulation. This may involve
an inspection by the customer’s own testing team of the product itself, focusing on quality testing, and of our
manufacturing process by conducting plant audits. These manufacturer certifications are essential, because no
sales to these customers can occur without such certifications. The testing is rigorous and can be time-consuming.
We currently hold many certifications from key customers, but we cannot guarantee that we will not experience
difficulties in retaining existing and obtaining new certifications as and when necessary. Failure to retain existing
certifications or obtain new certifications may result in the loss of such customers.

Any loss of, or significant reduction in demand from, one or more of our significant customers or termination of
contracts with regards to any key product could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
results of operations and cash flows.

**_Changes in our customers’ products or processes can reduce the demand for our products._**

Our customers use our products for a broad range of applications. Changes in our customers’ products or processes
may result in our customers reducing the volume of products they outsource to us or otherwise purchase from us,
or even make our products unnecessary. Customers may also find alternative chemicals or processes that no longer
require our products. For example, should a customer in Crop Science, Life Science or Performance Materials
decide to use a different active ingredient or intermediate due to price, performance or other considerations, we
may not be able to supply a product that meets the customer’s new requirements. In some instances, we are the
key supplier to our customers with respect to selected key products. Consequently, the success of our products
depends, to a significant extent, on the success of our customers’ own products in the relevant end-market.
Conversely, new digitalization and technological advances could also lead to more efficient farming (through
genetically modified seeds and more precise weather predictions) and our chemical products could ultimately be
used more efficiently by our customers such that there is a decrease in demand. For example, genetically modified
organisms could reduce or replace the need for insecticides or other Crop Science products. In addition, the
improved availability and accuracy of field data could lead to more precision and efficiency in the use of
herbicides, fungicides and insecticides for crop protection purposes and likewise lower the demand for our Crop
Science products. Similarly, newly launched products might not reach the expected performance due to lack of
sufficient demand in certain end-markets or customers decide to purchase lower volumes of our products.

Any reduction in demand for herbicides, fungicides and insecticides products for which we supply advanced
chemicals and active ingredients to our customers could negatively impact demand for our products. Additionally,
our results of operations are influenced by the evolving nature of regulations impacting the industries in which
our customers operate. We are also dependent on our customers’ continuous development of new products and
their need for our production and technical expertise. If our customers were to fail to develop new products for
which they outsource manufacturing to us, or if they otherwise do not require our production facilities or
production facility capacity, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results
of operations and cash flows.

**_We rely on long-term contracts for a certain part of our revenue and growth prospects._**

For our CDMO business in Exclusives products, we produce specialized chemical products (mainly in Crop
Science) in partnership with our clients to ensure we match their specific requirements and quality expectations.
This requires significant ramp-up times and costs to set-up appropriate production lines and processes. We commit
to such long-term projects (under contractual frameworks) with the expectation that we will recover our initial
investments in the short-term and achieve desired returns and profitability growth in the mid- to long-term. The
expected returns under these long-term contracts for Exclusives products account for a certain portion of our
Group’s future growth and profitability prospects and if the actual returns do not match our expectations or if the
contracts are breached, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows.

Additionally, our CDMO contracts in Exclusives typically feature a minimum contractual length, as well as other
mechanisms (e.g., co-investments by customers), targeting the recovery of our capital expenditure (“Capex”) for
the project. We cover part of our initial Capex either through an initial investment from our clients or through
contractual ‘take-or-pay’ clauses committing the clients to minimum purchase volumes and prices for an initial
period. While this contribution from our clients to our costs helps integrate our services into their value chains
and adds to their potential cost to switch suppliers, the custom production lines and processes developed this way
are usually product specific and cannot be easily re-purposed in case a contract is terminated or otherwise

30


-----

modified. Should our customers refuse to renew existing contracts with such clauses, our profitability might be
impacted.

Furthermore, should a customer choose to exercise a force majeure clause, or otherwise refuse to tender payment
for our services or terminate our contract, this would lead to losses or write-offs or additional costs on our part
(such as increased storage and other costs). Conversely, we may be unsuccessful in exercising a force majeure
clause ourselves, and as a result incur additional expenses under a contract that is no longer generating the
expected returns. Furthermore, if such contracts are terminated for cause, or modified or breached by ourselves or
our customers, we may not receive payment for our capital expenditures or generate the expected returns, which
could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Our results of operations may be affected by our inability to meet our customers’ requirements in terms of_**
**_product quality, specifications or other terms._**

Our products may fail to meet our customers’ expectations in terms of quality, performance or otherwise, which
may result in reputational harm, customers reducing the volume of orders they place with us or having to replace
products at our expense. As many of our products are critical to, or enhance the performance of, our customers’
applications and products, our customers rely on us to provide them with products that meet their specifications
and quality requirements. Our quality control systems and in-process production controls provide for regular
inspection of our products. However, there can be no assurance that our products will meet agreed specifications
or quality requirements, will not contain impurities or be mistakenly co-mingled with other products (for example,
due to mislabeling) when initially produced. In the past, prior to distribution to the customer, our controls have
identified completed products which have failed to meet customer specifications. In such instances, we have been
required to re-run the manufacturing process to achieve the proper specifications, which has resulted in loss of
revenue due to the need to deliver replacements at our own expense, reduction in sales volume due to the loss of
diverted production capacity and delayed delivery of product to customers. Our contracts with our customers
require our products to meet agreed specifications or quality requirements and therefore we may face similar
consequences if we fail to detect such quality deficiencies in the first instance or otherwise deliver products which
do not meet these requirements. In the event our quality systems identify issues only after shipping, we could
further face the possibility of a recall, which could result in damage to our reputation, substantial additional work
or destruction of material. Furthermore, some of our customers may ask us to manage the whole supply chain
process (raw material sourcing, production and delivery) which would require increased resources and working
capital, and therefore funding. If we are unable to obtain additional funding in order to finance increased working
capital, we could fail to meet our customers’ demands. Any of these failures could also result in reputational harm
and customers’ placing orders for lower volumes with us, which could also have an adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_We are exposed to risks related to conducting operations in several different countries._**

We currently have manufacturing facilities located in Germany, Switzerland, Finland, the United States and
China. Our operations in these countries may be subject to the following risks: changes in the rate of economic
growth; political or (macro-)economic conditions; availability and prices of raw materials and energy; supply
chain disruptions; expropriation or other governmental actions; regulatory actions (including bans or restrictions
on the usage of some of our products or their respective ingredients or substances); social unrest, war, terrorist
activities or other armed conflict; bribery and corruption; national and regional labor strikes; confiscatory taxation
or other adverse tax policies; deprivation of contract rights; trade restrictions and regulations affecting production,
pricing and marketing of products; reduced protection of intellectual property rights; restrictions on the
repatriation of income or capital; exchange controls and export restrictions; inflation; currency fluctuations and
devaluation; the effect of global environmental, health and safety issues on economic conditions (including severe
weather conditions), market opportunities and operating restrictions; and changes in financial policy and
availability of credit. These factors could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations
and cash flows.

**_We may be unable to successfully implement our business strategies and capital expenditure plans._**

Our future financial performance and success depend on our ability to implement our business strategy
successfully. We continue to focus on efficiency improvement initiatives to optimize our asset base, increase
operating efficiencies and generate cost savings. We also continue to select suitable materials to build various
process equipment, estimate raw material usage ratios, production capacity and waste generation as part of our
business strategy. However, we cannot guarantee that we will be able to successfully implement our business
strategies or that implementing these strategies will sustain or improve, rather than harm, our results of operations.

31


-----

In particular, we may not be able to maintain or increase our manufacturing efficiency or asset utilization or
achieve other cost savings, such as the operational efficiency measures we are currently implementing in all of
our international production facilities. In addition, the costs involved in implementing our strategies may be
greater than we currently anticipate. For example, we have invested more than €25 million into a new production
train in our Kokkola facility in Finland and we expanded into the United States in 2019 when the Permira Funds
acquired Monitchem Kansas S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries, including Jayhawk Fine Chemicals Corporation and its
production facility in Galena, Kansas, United States. However, our ability to continue similar capacity expansions
in our production facilities may be delayed or interrupted by the need to obtain environmental and other regulatory
approvals, the availability of labor and materials, unforeseen hazards, such as weather conditions and natural
disasters, internal restructurings due to loss of customers or key products and other risks customarily associated
with construction projects, including access to credit. See “We are dependent on a small number of Customers
_and Key Products for a significant portion of our revenue.”_

Moreover, the capital expenditure that we estimate for use in such capacity expansion projects may be insufficient
to cover the actual cost. We may experience cost overruns, and the cost of capacity expansion projects could have
a negative impact on our financial results until capacity utilization is sufficiently high to absorb the incremental
costs associated with the expansion.

Our business strategy, in particular our production capacity expansion plans, is based on assumptions about future
demand for our products and on our ability to optimize utilization of our existing and future production facilities.
We cannot guarantee that we will be able to implement our strategy of optimizing utilization of assets in
accordance with our plans or at all. For example, the frequency and length of facility maintenance and turnarounds
(scheduled outages of a production facility in order to perform necessary inspections, tests to comply with industry
regulations and any maintenance activities that may be necessary), planned restructurings and unplanned outages
have had, and may in the future have, an impact on our operating results. Furthermore, major capacity expansions
require long lead times in which operational business may be temporarily halted. Any failure to develop, revise
or implement our strategy in a timely and effective manner may adversely affect our business, financial condition,
results of operations and cash flows.

**_Seasonal fluctuations may impact our sales and cash flows._**

Our results of operations for the first and fourth quarters of the year are generally stronger than our results of
operation for the second and third quarters of the year, primarily due to seasonal factors in demand from our Crop
Science customers. We typically experience the strongest demand in the fourth quarter of the year and the first
quarter of the following year in line with increased demand for Crop Science products in the Northern Hemisphere
each spring prior to the growing season. Further, seasonal fluctuations including adverse weather conditions (heat,
cold, heavy rain, dryness, storm and exacerbated weather conditions due to climate change) may adversely affect
certain of our markets and customers. Elevated temperatures may lead to prolonged vegetation periods and
multiple harvests. Mild winters and strong humidity may lead to the increased spread of fungi, viruses and harmful
insects and thus crop yields may decrease and/or the use of pesticides may increase. For example, in early 2019
severe North American weather conditions led to a temporary downturn due to limited crop planting in that region
and in the summer of 2020, dry weather in Europe affected some of our customers, impacting demand.
Furthermore, droughts and dry weather conditions in Europe, North, Central and South America in 2022 impacted
the production of, amongst others, fruits, vegetables, soybeans and maize. In addition, most chemical production
companies, including certain of our suppliers and customers, generally schedule repairs of machinery and
production facility turnarounds (scheduled shutdowns of production units or facilities for maintenance) in the
summer months, which may result in lower sales in the second and third quarters compared to the first and fourth
quarters of a given year.

**_Our competitive position and future prospects depend on our senior management’s experience and expertise_**
**_and our ability to recruit and retain qualified personnel._**

The unanticipated departure of any key member of our senior management team could have an adverse effect on
our business. In addition, because of the specialized and technical nature of our business, our future performance
is dependent on the continued service of, and on our ability to attract and retain, qualified management, scientific,
engineering, technical, marketing and support personnel. Competition for such personnel is intense, and we may
be unable to continue to attract or retain such personnel. If we are unable to retain key personnel or attract new
skilled personnel, it could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and
cash flows.

32


-----

**_We depend on good relations with our workforce, and any significant disruption could adversely affect us._**

For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, we employed an average of approximately 1,200 employees in
our operations around the world. The countries in which we operate provide for various protections and rights for
employees, as well as collective bargaining agreements. These protections and rights may require us to invest
greater time and costs in amending employees’ terms of employment or make it more difficult to terminate
employment contracts. For example, certain employees in Germany and Finland are represented by trade unions
and works councils which generally must approve changes in conditions of employment, including salaries and
benefits. The employees of Jayhawk are also members of a union. Litigation by labor representatives, a labor
disturbance or work stoppage at any of our facilities as a result of any changes to our employment terms and
conditions or for any other reason could have a material adverse effect on that facility’s operations and, potentially,
on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Our insurance coverage may not be adequate to protect us against all potential losses to which we may be_**
**_subject, and it may be difficult to obtain replacement insurance on acceptable terms or at all._**

Due to the nature of the chemicals industry, our operations are generally difficult and expensive to insure. Our
production facilities, equipment and other assets are insured for property damage and business interruption risks.
However, our insurance does not cover mechanical equipment failure, and we may choose not to seek such
coverage in the future due to our assessment of the cost effectiveness of entering into such policies and the
possibility of mitigating such risks with spare parts or alternative sourcing options instead. We maintain liability,
property, directors’ and officers’ and other insurance coverage with coverage limits we consider adequate for the
size of our company and consistent with our business needs. However, we cannot be fully insured against all
potential hazards incident to our business, including losses resulting from global conflicts or terrorist acts, certain
natural catastrophes, environmental risks or other potential losses. Furthermore, there can be no assurance that
any claim under our insurance policies will be honored fully or timely, our insurance coverage will be sufficient
in any respect or our insurance premiums will not increase substantially. For example, after a fire incident at our
Pratteln site in 2020, affected our production output, our insurance policy premium for property damage and
business interruption more than doubled. We have experienced increases driven by inflation and other
macroeconomic developments and insurance premiums may significantly increase in the future as a result of
accidents of ours, other companies in Industrial Parks, or our competitors (which could be considered as industry
risk) or due to changing market conditions. If we were to incur a significant liability for which we were not fully
insured, or if premiums for certain insurance policies might increase substantially in the future as a result of any
further incidents for which we are insured or as a result of general market forces, our business, financial condition,
results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

**_Future acquisitions may prove difficult for us to complete and we may fail to realize the anticipated benefits_**
**_from such acquisitions._**

We have a history of making and integrating acquisitions, such as our operations in Switzerland in 2007 (Pratteln),
Finland in 2011 (Kokkola) and in the USA in 2019 (Jayhawk). In the future we may acquire companies or assets
engaged businesses similar or complementary to ours. Restrictions in our existing financing agreements may
preclude us from or limit our ability to make certain acquisitions. See “⸺Risks Related to Our Financial
_Profile⸺We may not be able to generate sufficient cash to service our indebtedness and may be forced to take_
_other actions to meet our obligations under our indebtedness, which may not be successful.”_

Further, we may use debt financing for any permitted acquisitions, which would increase our debt service
requirements. If making acquisitions or integrating any acquired business diverts too much management attention
from the existing operations, this could adversely affect our business, financial condition, operating results and
cash flows.

Any acquisition that we make could be subject to a number of risks, including proposed acquisitions being
prohibited or subject to onerous conditions by certain antitrust or other regulatory laws; problems with effective
integration of operations; the inability to maintain key pre-acquisition business relationships; increased operating
costs; costs related to achieving or maintaining compliance with laws, rules or regulations; costs related to postclosing asset impairment charges and expenses associated with eliminating duplicate facilities; the loss of key
employees of the acquired company; exposure to unanticipated liabilities and unidentified loss contingencies; and
difficulties in realizing projected efficiencies, synergies and cost savings. Integrating any future acquired business
may result in additional unforeseen difficulties or liabilities and could impact the effectiveness of our internal
controls over financial reporting.

33


-----

We cannot guarantee that any of our future acquisitions will ultimately provide the benefits we originally
anticipate, including the expected business growth opportunities, revenue benefits, cost synergies and other
operational efficiencies. Furthermore, we may not succeed in identifying attractive acquisition candidates or
financing and completing potential acquisitions on favorable terms. Any of the foregoing or other factors could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.

**_We may fail to realize anticipated benefits from joint ventures._**

We have made, and may continue to make, investments and enter into joint ventures. For example, in 2014 we
established a joint venture with Shandong Lutai Chemical Co., Ltd. (formerly Jining Jinwei Gold Power Co.,
Ltd.), a state-owned enterprise, to serve the market in Northern China and serve as a platform for further growth
in China. We have a 68 % interest in the joint venture with Shandong Lutai Chemical which contributes to less
than 1% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The success of joint ventures
or arrangements with third parties is not always predictable, and we may not realize our anticipated objectives or
benefits. Such arrangements may require significant initial expenditures as well as ongoing expenditures for
modernization and expansion. Furthermore, the ability to receive dividends, royalties and other payments from
joint ventures depends not only on the joint venture’s cash flows and profits, but also upon the terms of the joint
venture agreement with our partner. Conflicts with joint venture partners may lead to deadlock and may result in
our inability to pursue our desired strategy or exit from the joint venture on favorable terms. From time to time,
we may require the approval of a joint venture partner and any delay or difficulties in obtaining such approval
could have a negative impact on our business. In addition, sales or transfers of our interests in joint ventures may
be subject to the written approval of the joint venture partner, rights of first offer and, in the case of our joint
venture with Shandong Lutai Chemical, to the approval of certain Chinese regulatory authorities. Furthermore,
the bankruptcy, insolvency or severe financial distress of a joint venture partner or the joint venture itself or any
new regulations, international trade restrictions or enforcements to which they become subject could adversely
affect the joint venture and lead to its liquidation or a sale of our joint venture interest at a loss and, as a result,
could affect our reputation as well as our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.

**_We may be subject to information technology systems failures, cyberattacks, network disruptions and breaches_**
**_of data security._**

Our information technology systems are an important element of effectively operating our business. Information
technology systems failures, including risks associated with upgrading our systems, network disruptions and
breaches of data security could disrupt our operations by impeding our processing of transactions, our ability to
protect customer or company information and our financial reporting, leading to increased costs. It is possible that
future technological developments could adversely affect the functionality of our computer systems and require
further action, which could require us to spend substantial funds to prevent or repair computer malfunctions.

Our computer systems, including our back-up systems, could be damaged or interrupted by power outages,
computer and telecommunications failures, computer viruses, internal or external security breaches, including
cyberattacks, events such as fires, earthquakes, or floods and/or errors by our employees. Security vulnerabilities
in information technology solutions and insufficient contingency planning measures may lead to incidents that
affect the entire Group. As such threats, particularly around cybersecurity, continue to evolve we may be required
to expend significant resources to enhance our control environment, processes, practices and other protective
measures. Although we have taken steps to address these concerns by implementing network security, back-up
systems, cybersecurity insurance and internal control measures, there can be no assurance that a system failure or
data security breach and/or the resulting loss of trade secrets or other intellectual property will not have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Furthermore, based on the EU Data and Digital Strategies, there are several initiatives pending and new laws
passed aimed at establishing a single, uniform digital European market with robust cybersecurity requirements,
including the Digital Services Act, the Data Act, the Directive EU 2022/2557 on the resilience of critical entities
(so-called NIS2 Directive), the Cyber Resilience Act and the Artificial Intelligence Act. Overall, implementing
and complying with these laws may lead to us incurring higher costs or having to change our business practices
in this respect. In addition, confidential information that we maintain may be subject to misappropriation, theft
and deliberate or unintentional misuse by current or former employees, third-party contractors or other parties.
Any such misappropriation and/or misuse of our information could result in us, among other things, being in
breach of certain global data privacy, data protection, localization, security and consumer-protection laws and
regulations. In general, data privacy laws regulate when and how personal data of employees, customers or any
other third-party may be collected, for which purposes they may be processed and/or used, for how long they may
be stored and to whom and how they may be transferred. These laws and regulations are emerging and evolving

34


-----

in countries worldwide and the interpretation and application of these laws and regulations in the European Union,
the United States and elsewhere are often uncertain, contradictory and changing. For example, we are subject to
the European General Data Protection Regulation (EU 2016/679) (“GDPR”), under which we have compliance
obligations regarding the treatment (so-called processing) of personal data, including notification obligations of
personal data breaches and additional requirements for sharing personal data with any recipient outside the
European Economic Area. Furthermore, the GDPR inter alia requires the implementation of appropriate technical
and organizational measures to ensure the data security in general. Under the GDPR, breaches of data protection
rules may result in maximum fines equal to the greater of €20 million and 4% of the annual global turnover of the
group of the sanctioned company. It is possible that the GDPR and other laws may be interpreted or applied in a
manner that is adverse to us, unforeseen, or otherwise inconsistent with our practices or that we may not
adequately adapt our internal policies and/or procedures to evolving regulations, any of which could result in
litigation, regulatory investigations and potential legal liability, require us to change our practices in a manner
adverse to our business or limit access to our products and services in certain countries. As a result, our reputation
and brand may be harmed, we could incur substantial costs, and we could lose both customers and revenue.

Our failure to comply with applicable data protection laws and regulations could result in enforcement actions
against us, including fines, imprisonment of company officials and public censure, claims for damages by affected
individuals, the imposition of integrity obligations and agency oversight and damage to our reputation, any of
which could harm our business. Evolving and changing definitions of personal data and personal information,
within the European Union, the United States and elsewhere, may limit or inhibit our ability to operate or expand
our business, including limiting strategic partnerships that may involve sharing of personal data. Moreover, if the
relevant laws and regulations change, or are interpreted and applied in a manner that is inconsistent with our data
practices or if we expand into new markets and are required to comply with new requirements, we may need to
expend resources in order to change our business operations or data practices. Even the perception of privacy
concerns, whether or not valid, may harm our reputation. The occurrence of any of these risks could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_We may be required to increase our pension fund contributions._**

We have pension commitments to our existing and some of our former employees. These commitments are
partially covered by a pension scheme, pension funds, special purpose funds and insurance policies. As of
December 31, 2022, we have provisions for pensions and similar obligations in the amount of €18.1 million. The
amount of obligations is based on certain actuarial assumptions, including discount factors, life expectancy,
pension trends and future salary development as well as expected interest rates applicable to the applicable plan,
scheme or fund assets. If the actual results deviate from these assumptions, it could result in a considerable
increase of the pension commitments and thus to higher allocations to pension reserves in future years and could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Our tax burden could increase as a result of future tax audits and potential changes in applicable tax laws and_**
**_regulations._**

We are subject to routine tax audits by local tax authorities in the countries in which we operate. Future tax audits
may result in additional tax and interest payments, which would negatively affect our financial condition and
results of operation. Changes in fiscal regulations or the interpretation of tax laws by the courts or the tax
authorities in the foreign jurisdictions in which we conduct our business may also have negative consequences.
In addition, tax authorities may, to some extent, not accept the deductibility of interest payments, claiming among
other aspects, that limitation under interest ceiling rules or transfer pricing rules apply. In such event, we may face
additional tax payments becoming due in tax audits or in the process of tax assessments. Any additional tax
payments could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash
flows.

**_We are exposed to currency fluctuation risks in several different countries that could adversely affect our_**
**_profitability._**

Our results of operations may be affected by transaction effects and translation effects of foreign currency
exchange rate fluctuations. We are exposed to transaction effects when one of our subsidiaries incurs costs or
generates sales in a currency different from its functional currency. Fluctuations in exchange rates may also affect
the relative competitive position of our production facilities, as well as our ability to market our products
successfully in other markets. We are exposed to currency fluctuations when we convert currencies we receive
for our products into currencies required to pay our debt or currencies used to purchase raw materials, meet our
fixed costs or pay for services, which could result in a gain or loss depending on fluctuations in exchange rates.

35


-----

Certain of our sales are invoiced in currencies other than the euro, namely Swiss francs, Chinese yuan and U.S.
dollars, while our consolidated sales are reported in euro. If the value of the euro declines against currencies in
which our obligations are denominated or increases against currencies in which our sales are denominated, our
business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be adversely affected.

**_We are subject to the risk of loss resulting from non-payment or non-performance by our customers._**

Our customers may experience financial difficulties, including bankruptcies, restructurings and liquidations.
These and other financial problems that may be experienced by our customers, as well as potential financial
weaknesses in our industry, may increase our risk in extending trade credit to customers. We have limited credit
risk insurance, which does not extend to protect us against all potential losses to which we may be subject. A
significant adverse change in a customer relationship or in a customer’s financial position could cause us to limit
or discontinue business with that customer, require us to assume more credit risk relating to that customer’s
receivables or limit our ability to collect accounts receivable from that customer, all of which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows.

Furthermore, should a customer choose to exercise a force majeure clause in their contract and refuse to tender
payment for our services, this would lead to increased storage and costs on our part or even losses or write-offs.
Conversely, we may exercise a force majeure clause in a business contract and the customer may successfully
challenge this exercise. All of these circumstances could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Environmental, social and governance matters may impact our business and reputation._**

There has been increased focus by regulators, consumers, investors, employees, and other stakeholders, as well
as by governmental and non-governmental organizations, on environmental, social and governance matters
(“ESG”). This has resulted in expanding and increasingly complex mandatory and voluntary reporting, diligence,
and disclosure on ESG topics. These developments and other rapidly changing laws, regulations, policies and
related interpretations, as well as increased enforcement actions or investigations by various governmental and
regulatory agencies and increased litigation risk from private parties, may alter the environment in which we do
business and may increase the ongoing costs of compliance which could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Any failure or perceived failure to meet our ESG commitments or targets, or loss of confidence, or inability to
meet expectations with our ESG commitments on the part of customers, investors, employees and other
stakeholders as it relates to our ESG initiatives could negatively impact our business relationships, and the demand
for our products. These impacts could be difficult and costly to overcome, even if such concerns were based on
inaccurate or misleading information.

In addition, achieving our ESG initiatives may result in increased costs in our supply chain, fulfillment, and/or
business operations. Standards regarding ESG initiatives could change and become more onerous for us to meet
successfully. Evolving data and research could undermine or refute our current claims and beliefs that we have
made in reliance on current research, which could also result in additional costs or a decrease in revenue, negative
market perception and increased scrutiny that could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial
condition.

A variety of organizations measure the performance of companies on such ESG topics, and the results of these
assessments are widely publicized. In addition, investment in funds that specialize in companies that perform well
in such assessments is increasingly popular, and major institutional investors have publicly emphasized the
importance of such ESG measures to their investment decisions. Topics taken into account in such assessments
include, among others, a company’s efforts and impacts on climate change and human rights, ethics and
compliance with law and the role of a company’s board of directors in supervising various sustainability issues.
In light of investors’ increased focus on ESG matters, there can be no certainty that we will manage such issues
successfully, or that we will successfully meet society’s ESG expectations or achieve our financial goals. As part
of our commitment to ESG matters, we have introduced specific, quantifiable key performance indicators. If we
fail to meet the targets of these or other key performance indicators to measure our progress towards our ESG
goals, we may suffer reputational damage, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**Risks Relating to Manufacturing**

**_Our operations are subject to hazards such as chemical spills, unforeseen shutdowns and natural catastrophes_**
**_which could result in significant disruptions and liability for us. We have experienced chemical spills in the_**
**_past and may continue to experience such events._**

The hazards and risks of disruption associated with chemical manufacturing and the related storage and
transportation of raw materials, products and wastes exist in our operations and the operations of other occupants
with whom we share manufacturing sites, including our suppliers. These potential risks of disruption include, but
are not necessarily limited to:

- unplanned production or power disruptions;

- failure of mechanical, process safety and pollution control equipment;

- pipeline and storage tank leaks and ruptures;

- explosions and fires;

- inclement weather and natural disasters (including earthquakes, the development of sinkholes and tornados);

- construction of national highways affecting our facilities;

- cyber-attacks and other external assaults on our IT-systems or digital infrastructure;

- terrorist attacks;

- political turmoil;

- chemical spills and other discharges or releases of toxic or hazardous substances or gases;

- exposure to toxic chemicals; and/or

- other accidents.

These interruptions and hazards could also lead to a short- or long-term suspension of operations, expose
employees, customers, the community and others to toxic chemicals and other hazards, contaminate the
environment, damage property, result in personal injury or death, damage our reputation and adversely affect the
productivity and profitability of a particular manufacturing facility or our business operations as a whole, and
result in the need for remediation, governmental enforcement, regulatory shutdowns, the imposition of
government fines and penalties and claims brought by governmental entities or third parties. In addition, the
occurrence of any such event could harm our ability to obtain or maintain our existing licenses or our key
commercial, regulatory, and governmental relationships. For example, in the past we have experienced chemical
spills and leakages in certain of our sites, including Kokkola and Pratteln. Furthermore, a part of our Pratteln site
sits in an area with increased risk of landslides and sinkholes, with one such sinkhole collapse event occurring in
2018. While we have made foundation improvements to our plants as part of investments to protect against
earthquakes and believe the risk to our operations is limited, unexpected natural disasters, including landslides
and sinkholes, may cause significant damage or delays in our plants.

Legal claims and regulatory actions could subject us to civil liability, administrative sanctions and criminal
penalties, which could affect our product sales, reputation and profitability. In many jurisdictions, such as the
United States, these risks are amplified by the frequency of class action lawsuits and high punitive damages
awards. Furthermore, our existing environmental, health and safety compliance and management systems set-up
to prevent potential risks, enable emergency responses and crisis management plans and mitigate damages may
not successfully prevent or mitigate these risks. Should any of these risks materialize, our production capacity
could be materially adversely affected, which could in turn negatively impact our sales and potentially lead to a
loss of market share. This could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows.

37


-----

**_We have experienced in the past and may continue to face unplanned production disruptions, manufacturing_**
**_interruptions and delays at our facilities worldwide._**

We currently have six manufacturing sites, four located in Europe, one in China and one in the United States. In
the ordinary course of business, we may face unplanned production disruptions due to unforeseen events such as
fires, power shortages, sabotage, accidents or natural catastrophes, resulting in significant operational disruptions,
delays, costs, or liability. For example, in 2020, a fire incident at our Pratteln site led to a partial standstill of the
chlorine value chain, which negatively impacted production and therefore sales of our products, negatively
affecting our revenue in 2020. In addition, in February 2021, our Jayhawk facility experienced a seven-day
standstill due to a severe winter storm. As a result, we incurred substantial costs and expenses due to this standstill.
Some of the crucial equipment, infrastructure systems and storage systems used within our various plants (for
example: incineration boilers, mixer settlers, reactors or utility infrastructure systems) may also experience
damages, decreased quality in terms of functionality or restraints due to either unforeseen events or normal wear
and tear. Although we possess customary insurance for damage to our property and the disruption of our business,
and, for example, we were able to claim back certain losses from the fire incident at our Pratteln site, such plans
and insurance may not cover all such disasters or be sufficient to cover all of our potential losses and may not
continue to be available to us on acceptable terms or at all. In addition, such disruptions could impact our
relationships with our clients, all of which could have a negative impact on our business.

Additionally, adverse weather or other natural catastrophes such as flooding, severe storms, landslides,
earthquakes or others, whether caused by climate change or natural processes of the earth, may significantly affect
our production sites and cause severe disruptions and some of our production facilities worldwide may be more
exposed to such risks. For example, a past geological survey conducted at our Pratteln site in Switzerland, revealed
that the site is subject to seismic activity and earthquake risk. We have already explored and initiated a seismic
retrofitting process which, however, is envisaged to take several years for completion.

If disruptions occur, alternative facilities with sufficient capacity or capabilities may not be available, may cost
substantially more or it may take significant time to start production. Each of these scenarios could materially
adversely affect our business and financial performance. If any of our production facilities is unable to
manufacture our products for an extended period of time, our sales may decline due to the disruption and we may
not be able to manufacture sufficient volumes of products to meet our customers’ needs.

Furthermore, our production processes and supply chains are highly integrated and any disruptions to such
production processes or supply chains may negatively impact the sales of our products. For example, the fire
accident at our Pratteln site in 2020 affected not only our products used in the Crop Science and Life Science
industries but also, as a result of our integrated production network, our products which are used in the Advanced
Intermediates and Base Chemicals industry. As the production of one of the key chemicals manufactured at the
Pratteln site depends on monochloroacetic acid (MCA) sourced from our Knapsack and Gersthofen facilities, we
lost volumes of MCA during the outage due to the reduced demand at Pratteln while production capacity was
down. Furthermore, we may face work-related accidents and near-misses on part of the employees and workers
in our plants.

Although we believe we maintain disaster recovery plans in line with customary industry standards and possess
customary insurance for damage to our property and the disruption of our business from casualties, such plans
and insurance may not cover all such disasters or be sufficient to cover all of our potential losses and may not
continue to be available to us on acceptable terms or at all. Any inability to recover from a third-party any or all
compensation related to a disruption could have a negative impact on our business. In addition, any inability to
meet our customers’ needs could cause them to seek other suppliers. Furthermore, to the extent a disruption occurs
at a production facility that has been operating at or near full capacity, the resulting shortage of our product could
be particularly harmful because production at the facility may not be able to reach levels achieved prior to the
disruption. Shutdowns, strikes, weather or other disruptions affecting our upstream supply chain or our utilities or
logistics providers, could have a negative impact on our business. Any such disruptions and the resulting
repercussions may adversely impact our reputation, business, financial condition, results of operations and cash
flows.

**_We rely on third parties for the performance of transportation and logistical services._**

We rely on third-party service providers for certain aspects of our business, particularly the receipt of raw
materials from our suppliers and the transport and distribution of our products to our customers as well as certain
services related to waste disposal. Our ability to receive vital raw materials, to provide our products to our
customers and to dispose of our waste depends on our ability to negotiate reasonable terms with third parties,

38


-----

including railroad, trucking and shipping companies. To the extent that our third-party service providers increase
their rates, including to reflect higher fuel, maintenance, labor or other costs due to increased regulation, taxation
or otherwise, we may not be able to pass on such increases to our customers in a timely manner or at all.

In certain instances, we depend on a single or limited number of third-party service providers, including for our
chlorine supply in Knapsack or certain waste disposal services across the Group. Any disruption to our third-party
service providers may lead to standstills or otherwise negatively impact our ability to manufacture our products
(due to a lack of, for example, raw materials and energy supply (e.g. steam)), to deliver our products to our
customers or to continue our operations in the event we cannot find any alternative provider, in particular if the
availability of a particular type of service provider is limited or if we depend on only one provider. Any material
increases in our transport and distribution costs that we are unable to pass on to customers or any disruption to
our transportation and logistical network, including waste disposal, could have an adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operation or cash flows. For example, transportation routes between cities in
Germany and Switzerland have limited capacity and if there is no alternative container or tank wagon that can
transport products to and from our sites, our customers would fail to receive their ordered products or our own
production sites would fail to receive the raw materials. Inability to deliver ordered products to customers may
also lead to additional unpredicted costs for storage. Some of the chemicals we transport also face transportation
and loading restrictions – for example, certain of our materials are not approved by authorities for transportation
by vehicular means, which further limits the number of alternative transportation means available. Furthermore,
our suppliers in China have faced the risk of unexpected delivery delays as a result of China’s zero-COVID policy
and may face in the future the risk of similar political measures in which the detection of a single case of COVID19 may lead to the shut-down of an entire port. See “⸺Risks Related to the Industry in which We Operate⸺The
_spread of the 2019 coronavirus (“COVID-19”) has had, and the outbreak of another infectious disease or other_
_serious public health concern around the world could have, a negative impact on economies, financial markets_
_and business activities.”_

Future disruptions of this nature may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results
of operation or cash flows.

**_We may face capacity constraints that could compromise our ability to meet customer expectations or_**
**_overcapacity that could negatively impact our results._**

If we encounter capacity limitations or fail to effectively manage our capacity, our business could suffer either as
a result of not meeting customer expectations (e.g., inability to meet agreed delivery deadlines) or having to
decline potential new business opportunities. Conversely, if we are not able to effectively manage our capacity or
there is a decline in customer demand, and, as a result, we experience underutilization of certain sites, this could
lead to overcapacity and result in profit margin erosion due to the high fixed costs of our manufacturing sites.
Currently, certain of our facilities are operating at high capacity. Any disruptions in the manufacturing of
chemicals at these sites, including due to capacity constraints, could impact our ability to fulfill the respective
customer manufacturing contracts.

In addition, the volume of manufacturing for different chemicals varies across our sites, with some sites having
certain focuses and specialties. Thus, if there is increased demand in a certain manufactured chemical, we may
experience over-capacity at select manufacturing sites, while other sites operate at less efficient levels. In some
cases, we may not be able to easily or quickly shift production between sites employing the same methodology or
technology due to the specific manufacturing requirements of our customers’ customized products (including
regulatory requirements). As a result, we may face significant challenges in managing our capacity. If we are
unable to manage effectively or optimally our capacity in light of changing customer requirements, which can
vary and shift across the quarters of the financial year, we may experience operational inefficiencies and site
underutilization or need to reduce the volumes of more profitable products to manufacture contractually
committed volumes of other products.

Furthermore, such risks may be greater at facilities that are new or going through significant expansion or
renovation. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results
of operations and cash flows.

39


-----

**_We are dependent on the availability of raw materials and any shortages, lack of delivery or price increases_**
**_may lead to manufacturing interruptions and/or increases in manufacturing costs, and may also limit our_**
**_ability to grow our business._**

We produce a certain amount of raw materials ourselves, however, we also procure raw materials from third
parties. As such, our manufacturing processes are dependent on the availability of various raw materials,
including, inter alia, acetic acid, other carboxylic acids, acetic acid anhydride, lactic acid derivatives, chlorine in
sites where we do not produce it ourselves, and various solvents and catalysts.

While we rely on a number of third-party suppliers to provide us with raw materials and supplies, it is possible
that any of our third-party suppliers could be interrupted due to changing regulatory requirements, import or export
restrictions, natural disasters, international supply disruptions, geopolitical issues, strikes, shortages, financial,
operational or quality issues at a supplier’s facilities and other events or could be terminated in the future. Our
third-party suppliers may close production sites causing supply chain problems and any decision by our suppliers
to fail to deliver certain materials in part or at all may negatively impact our business. In addition, our third-party
suppliers may deliver defective raw materials that fall out of the agreed specifications in which case such raw
materials would be returned. For example, macroeconomic developments or other events such as the RussiaUkraine conflict may negatively impact raw material supply chains, affecting the availability of raw materials
needed for our production or used by our customers. As a result of any of these factors, we may be unable to
source input products from other suppliers upon short notice and/or at the required volume. Any such delay or
failure of delivery by our suppliers could result in delaying our customers’ production schedule, which could
result in loss of business and reputational damage. See “⸺Risks Related to the Industry in Which We
_Operate⸺Economic downturns or worsening global economic conditions may adversely impact our business,_
_financial condition, results of operation and cash flows” and “⸺The Russia-Ukraine conflict and the resulting_
_sanctions and measures taken against Russia have had and may have further adverse material effects on the_
_global economy, energy supplies and prices, and may have severe adverse effects on the operations of energy-_
_intensive sectors (e.g., heavy industry, chemical manufacturers, metallurgy, pharma, etc.).”_

In certain instances, for example where the supply of raw materials to our production site requires a specific

and Jining depend on adjacent suppliers to supply chlorine via a pipeline. Furthermore, at our Gersthofen and

_of the 2019 coronavirus (“COVID-19”) has had, and the outbreak of another infectious disease or other serious_

_business activities.”_

We have historically been able to partially pass on increases in raw materials costs to our customers when the
prices for the purchase of raw materials increased, for example, through raw material price adjustment clauses in
some of our agreements and corresponding price annexes. In certain instances, we also partially pass on
transportation, energy and packaging costs to our customers. However, there is a risk that we will not always be
able to do so in the future and any significant and/or unexpected increases in the cost of raw materials or
transportation costs that we are unable to pass on to our customers (at least in part) or that lead to a significant
increase of costs in business relationships based on contracts that do not contain adjustment mechanisms could
have a negative impact on our financial results. Furthermore, even if we continue to pass on a portion of the cost
of raw materials and transportation costs to our customers, the cost of such raw materials and/or transportation
costs may increase to a significantly higher price such that customers would seek other suppliers.

In addition, several of our raw materials suppliers are based in China and any changes to the environmental, health
and safety laws and regulations in this region will likely impact certain chemical sites, including those of our
third-party suppliers. Such changes could result in increased costs of such raw materials, delay in the production
of such raw materials and, in turn, could impact our supply chain and our ability to meet our own chemical product
delivery timelines. See “⸺Risks Related to Our Business⸺We are exposed to risks related to conducting
_operations in several different countries.” On the other hand, we may also experience challenges in managing our_
inventory due to, inter alia, customer order cancellations or inaccurate manufacturing forecasts. Any inability to
manage our inventory levels could result in such inventory becoming obsolete, resulting in write-downs of certain
purchased raw materials and supplies. Any change in inventories, whether an increase or decrease, affects our
cash flow and other financial results.

In addition to these risks, governmental regulations, environmental laws and regulations, increasing demand for

**_Increased energy costs, disruptions in energy supplies or our inability to pass on energy costs could have a_**
**_material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows._**

Our business is dependent on the steady supply of significant amounts of energy, in particular electricity for our
electrolysis production processes in Pratteln and Knapsack. For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, our
energy costs recognized in cost of sales amounted to €65.6 million, or 8.7% of our revenue. Energy costs are
affected by various factors, including the availability of supplies of particular sources of energy, energy prices
and regulatory decisions.

In particular, prices for oil, gas and electricity have been volatile in recent years, and such volatility may continue
as a result of geopolitical instability, such as the Russia-Ukraine conflict. In addition, electricity prices for
industrial consumers in Germany and Switzerland are generally higher than in several neighboring countries. Any
significant increase in market prices, transportation costs, grid fees or taxes (including by reduction of tax benefits)
associated with the supply of energy would increase our operating costs and, thus, may negatively affect our
results of operations if we are not able to pass a certain portion of the increased costs on to our customers. Any
deficiencies in our contracts with our customers or our suppliers, such as a misstatement or misapplication of a
price formula, any disagreement with respect to the interpretation of a price formula or other unforeseen events,
such as increasing energy prices, could result in an increase in our energy costs and could result in an inability to
pass on increases in energy costs to our customers.

In addition, any significant disruption in our energy supply at any of our facilities as a result of outages, stoppages,
supply chain issues, regulators or public authorities requesting reduction in energy consumption as a result of
supply issues or other reasons, could impact our supply chain and our ability to fulfill our customer manufacturing
contracts.

Any inability or delay in passing on increases in energy costs to our customers or any interruption or shortage of
energy supply from our suppliers may negatively impact our business, financial condition, results of operations
and cash flows.

**Risks Relating to Environmental and Regulatory Matters**

**_Compliance with increasing regulatory requirements concerning the testing, labelling, registration and safety_**
**_analysis of our products may result in significant additional costs for us or may reduce or eliminate the_**
**_availability and/or marketability of some of the raw materials we use or of our products. Our inability to_**
**_maintain our existing classification registration in member states of the European Union under the REACH_**
**_legislation, or comparable legislation in other countries in which we operate or do business, may affect our_**
**_ability to manufacture and sell certain products._**

To operate a chemical manufacturing business and to sell and distribute chemical products involves safety health
and environmental risks. As part of our business, we store, handle, transport and use certain substances or
components that may be considered toxic or hazardous. If operational risks - such as fires, leaks, releases and
explosions - materialize, they could result in injury or loss of life, damage to the environment or loss of production.

We must comply with a broad range of regulations related to the testing, manufacturing, registration, labeling and
safety analysis of our products or the products of our suppliers. In some countries, including the Member States
of the European Union (particularly Finland and Germany), Switzerland, the United States and China, these types
of regulatory controls and restrictions have become increasingly demanding and we expect this trend to continue.

For example, our products and raw materials produced or imported into the European Union are subject to
extensive environmental and industrial hygiene regulations governing the registration and safety analysis of the
substances contained in them. The European Union Regulation on the Registration, Evaluation and Authorization

41


-----

of Chemicals (Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006), (“REACH”), imposes significant obligations on the chemicals
industry as a whole with respect to the testing, evaluation, assessment and registration of basic chemicals and
more advanced chemicals. The review and update of existing registrations is expensive and time-consuming and
lead to increased production costs and reduced operating margins for chemical products. We also cannot exclude
with certainty that the European Chemicals Agency (“ECHA”) may not designate some of our other products as
substances of very high concern (“SVHCs”) and thereby require authorization and a strict safety evaluation for
them under REACH.

ECHA is also responsible to evaluate potential restrictions of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (“PFASs”) that
have been proposed by the Member States. PFASs are a large class of thousands of synthetic chemicals that are
used throughout society. They are increasingly detected as environmental pollutants and some are linked to
negative effects on human health. PFASs have been frequently observed to contaminate groundwater, surface
water and soil. A number of PFASs are already on the REACH candidate list of SVHCs, for example
perfluorinated carboxylic acids (C9-14 PFCAs) and PFHxS. On January 13, 2023, a proposal prepared by the
competent national authorities of, inter alia, Denmark, Germany and Sweden to restrict around 10,000 PFASs
was submitted to ECHA. All PFASs in the scope of the proposal are very persistent in the environment and the
national authorities estimate that around 4.4 million tonnes of PFASs would end up in the environment over the
next 30 years unless action is taken. ECHA’s scientific committees are currently evaluating the proposal. The
evaluation will also take into consideration the results and the input from a six-month public consultation that
started on March 22, 2023. Afterwards, ECHA’s scientific committees will adopt formal opinions, based on which
the European Commission and the Member States will then decide on the potential restrictions. We cannot exclude
that the proposed restrictions of the use of PFASs may have a negative impact on our business activities.

Moreover, under the Biocidal Products Regulation (EU) No. 528/2012 we have to apply for approval of active
substances at ECHA and for product authorization before placing a biocidal product on the market. In connection
with REACH or the EU Classification, Labeling and Packaging Regulation (Regulation (EC) No. 1272/2008)
(“CLP”), some key raw materials, chemicals or substances, including our products, could be reclassified as having
a toxicological or health-related impact on the environment, on users of our products, or on our employees.

Furthermore, the European Directive No. 2010/75/EC on industrial emissions (“IED Directive”) sets out rules on
the prevention and control of pollution from industrial activities and includes rules aimed at reducing emissions
into air, water and land, as well as preventing the generation of waste in order to achieve a high level of overall
environmental protection. Although the IED Directive and its implementation provide transitional provisions,
once a new industry standard becomes binding, existing permits, which are not in compliance with such standard
can become invalid. We have in the past incurred, and will in the future incur, significant cost for capital and
operating expenditures to obtain and maintain necessary permits.

In the European Union, the “European Green Deal”, a strategy aiming at making Europe the first climate-neutral
continent by 2050, will have a considerable impact on the industry throughout all sectors, including on our
business. The implementation of the “European Green Deal” involves revisions of a large number of regulations,
including REACH, CLP and the IED Directive. The “European Green Deal” is still in the process of being
implemented, with many bills in the legislative process, and the impact on our business cannot yet be predicted in
detail. However, we will be facing a stricter regulatory framework in many respects going forward.

In addition, the Toxic Substances Control Act (“TSCA”) mandates that the United States Environmental
Protection Agency (“EPA”) conduct safety evaluations for all chemicals in active commerce and determine that
new chemicals and significant new uses of chemicals are not likely to present an unreasonable risk before entering
the market. With respect to any facilities we operate or may operate in the United States and with respect to any
products we sell or may in the future sell in the United States, classification or reclassification of one or more of
our raw materials or products could affect our ability to manufacture or market our products, result in a ban on
purchase or sale of our products or raw materials or require us to incur increased costs to comply with notification,
labelling, handling, or other requirements.

Furthermore, all pesticide products sold in the United States must comply with the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide
and Rodenticide Act (“FIFRA”), and most must be registered with the U.S. EPA and similar state agencies. Our
inability to obtain or maintain such registrations, or the cancellation of any such registration of our products, could
have an adverse effect on our business, the severity of which would depend on a variety of factors, including the
product(s) involved, whether another product could be substituted and whether our competitors were similarly
affected. We attempt to anticipate regulatory developments and maintain registrations of, and access to, substitute
active ingredients, but there can be no assurance that we will be able to avoid or reduce these risks.

Furthermore, environmental laws may expose us to liability for the conduct of or conditions caused by others, and
