**Business Overview**

We are a leading CDMO (contract development and manufacturing organization) and fine chemistry manufacturer
with global operations, supplying customized ingredients to major players in the Western Crop Science market,
as well as high purity and high-complexity chemical ingredients to customers in the Life Science and Performance
Material markets. Our strong technology portfolio, technical know-how and execution capabilities allow us to
cover a wide spectrum of highly specialized customer needs, specifications and complexity profiles.

Headquartered in Germany, we operate a global network with six production facilities located in Pratteln
(Switzerland), Kokkola (Finland), Galena (Kansas, United States), Gersthofen (Germany), Knapsack (Germany)
and Jining, Shandong Province (China).

Our varied product portfolio is organized across two product groups: (i) Exclusives (tailor-made active ingredients
and precursors developed for individual customers on an exclusive basis (our CDMO offering)) and Specialties
(highly specialized ingredients with applications in high-margin end-markets) products and (ii) Advanced
Intermediates and Base Chemicals products (intermediate and base chemical products such as high purity
monochloroacetic acid (“MCA”), chloroacetyl chloride (“CAC1”) and caustic soda across a large purity spectrum
with multiple end-use applications).

Our products are deeply embedded into our customers’ value chains, often on a near-exclusive basis, allowing us
to be aligned in demand planning and supply chain coordination and to set up scalable manufacturing facilities
and efficient commercial production processes. The combination of our production know-how, lengthy product
development processes and contractually agreed capital expenditure contributions for some of our products
typically result in high contract renewal rates and low customer churn.

For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenue of €755.5 million and an Adjusted
EBITDA of €162.6 million (21.5% Adjusted EBITDA margin). Between 2020 and 2022, our revenue grew at
23.9% CAGR, whereas our Adjusted EBITDA grew at 20.0% CAGR. Exclusives and Specialties contributed to
56.8% of our revenue for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 whereas Advanced Intermediates and Base
Chemicals accounted for 43.2% of our revenue for the same period.

Our products are used for end-market applications mainly in: (i) Crop Science (e.g., herbicides, fungicides,
insecticides and other livestock and crop protection products), (ii) Life Science (e.g., pharma, personal care,
nutrition, fragrances and flavor applications) and (iii) Performance Materials (e.g., curatives in epoxies,
polyimides, polyesters and other resin systems used for electronic components, semiconductors and for
composites, fibers, films, and foams that provide heat and electrical resistance). These end-markets, in particular
Crop Science, have shown resilient historical growth rates and benefit from structural mega-trends that are
expected to drive further resilient growth in the near- to mid-term, such as increasing demand for food and need
for increased farming yields on the one hand, and an aging population and improving living standards on the other.
In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of our products were used in the
Crop Science market, approximately 20% in the Life Science market, approximately 15% in the Performance
Materials market and approximately 15% relate to others (e.g., base chemicals and industrial MCA) (measured as
a percentage of revenues).

67


-----

Exclusives, our CDMO offering, provides tailor-made active ingredients and precursors tailored to individual
customer specifications in Crop Science and are a primary contributor to our overall profitability. Based on
customer-developed IP, these products require customized production lines, expansive know-how and close
cooperation with our customers. We offer development and manufacturing services for proprietary products on
an exclusive and confidential basis to leading players in the Crop Science market such as: BASF, Bayer, Corteva
and Syngenta, and we have relationships with nearly all major players in the Western Crop Science market.

Our Specialties offering consists of specialty ingredients that leverage our considerable manufacturing expertise
to create complex chemical products that serve specific customer needs across a variety of applications in the
Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials industries. Unlike Exclusives, these products can be
offered to multiple customers at a time. Our offering highlights our excellent production capabilities and knowhow along with our ability to offer specialized technology process and development services which allows us to
continuously provide high-quality and purity products to our customers and which we believe is a key
differentiator in this field. Our Specialties products are also a strong contributor to profitability, leveraging our
close client relationship and high customer “stickiness”. In particular, we offer high value-add products for fastgrowing applications in Life Science (pharma and personal care as well as nutrition) and Performance Materials
markets (coatings, e.g., in electronics or other industrial applications), backed by several attractive long-term
customer contracts, which offer high visibility on the lifecycle and returns on our products. Customers for our
Specialties products include players such as Agilent Technologies, Bayer, Corteva, Deciem/Estee Lauder, DSM,
Evonik, Merck, Novartis and Syngenta.

In our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group, we offer intermediate and base chemical
products, such as MCA, CAC1 and caustic soda, that serve as chemical building blocks for other secondary
chemical processes with a variety of applications across a large number of industries and markets. We believe we
are one of the leading suppliers of MCA to Western Europe and the Americas and we operate state-of-the-art sites,
allowing us to provide a full range of purity and quality for our customers. Large parts of our Advanced
Intermediates supply agreements feature price formulas that allow us to partially pass on price increases in costs
of certain raw materials. Furthermore, we also generate a portion of our revenue from Base Chemicals and other
products such as caustic soda, that are generated as by-products from our Exclusives and Advanced Intermediates
production lines.

**Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations**

**_Development of mega-trends in the Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials markets_**

_Crop Science market_

In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of our products were used in the
Crop Science market (measured as a percentage of revenues). Accordingly, with our focus on the Crop Science
market, our results of operations are affected by changes in the market environment and the demand for our
products by our customers. In particular, the underlying global Crop Science market growth is driven by megatrends such as a growing population driving demand for food and crops and decreasing arable land per capita,
requiring efficient crop protection products to increase farming yields. Our results are also affected by trends in
the addressable CDMO Crop Science market such as a growth in CDMO outsourcing and increasing complexity
of active ingredient molecules requiring specialist CDMO partners with strong technical expertise and assets
fitting into global supply chains of Crop Science players (Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

From 2019 to 2022, the underlying global Crop Science market grew at a CAGR of 7.8% from €55.6 billion to
€69.6 billion due to trends such as favorable weather conditions, increased crop prices as well as increased
manufacturing and logistics costs partially passed through with the product price (Roland Berger Report). See
“Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺General⸺Key Drivers.”

Herbicides, fungicides and insecticides, for which we supply tailor-made products, as well as high-quality
intermediates, to our customers, play an essential role in crop protection and result in higher productivity per acre
(higher crop yields). In 2022, herbicides, the largest sub-segment of the underlying global Crop Science market,
accounted for approximately 40%. Insecticides accounted for approximately 30%, fungicides for approximately
28% and others (e.g. plant growth regulators) approximately 3% of the market. The majority of the different
segments are expected to grow with a CAGR between 2% and 3% until 2027, with the exception of herbicides,
which is expected to grow at a CAGR of less than 1% between 2022 and 2027. Overall, the global Crop Science
market growth is expected at a CAGR of 2% between 2022 and 2027 (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor).

68


-----

_Life Science market_

In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 20% of our products were used in the Life
Science market (measured as a percentage of revenues). We have considerable manufacturing power for chemical
products aimed for the Life Science market. However, our results of operations are affected by macroeconomic
changes in the Life Science market and the ultimate demand for our customers’ products. See “Risk
_Factors⸺Risks Related to the Industry in Which we Operate⸺Economic downturns or worsening global_
_economic conditions may adversely impact our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows”_
and “⸺Changes in our customers’ products or processes can reduce the demand for our products.”

Markets for Life Science products served by us showed varying growth rates between 2019 and 2022. Our targeted
Life Science market segments also include several fast-growing niche products such as DCA, which significantly
increased in size during the same period. The addressable Life Science market growth is driven by supportive
developments in specific segments with a high demand for specialty products, such as novel RNA therapeutics,
vitamins and supplements, as well as a rising adoption in skin care products. In addition, the Life Science market
is further positively impacted by certain mega-trends such as a global aging population, together with an increasing
disposable income spent on health and personal care. Our customers include some of the largest established market
brands in the cosmetics (including anti-aging products), vitamin and supplements industries. Our top products
comprise Monochloroacetic acid (“MCA”), Dichloroacetic acid (“DCA”), Glycolic acid (“GA”) and Ethyl-2chloroacetoacetate (“CAE”), each with several high-value applications across the Life Science market. In personal
care, our high purity MCA acts as basis for Betaine synthesis used, e.g., for shampoos, toothpaste or synthetic
caffeine. In addition, we are the global market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high purity grade
DCA (a key ingredient for RNA-based medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications (by high purity
DCA revenue as of 2022). In cosmetic grade GA, we are globally the second largest supplier (measured by revenue
as of 2022) and the only European producer with global coverage. In the vitamins market, CAE produced in our
plants is used as the basis for Vitamin B6 synthesis that are further applied in, for example, nutrition (Company
assessment based on the Roland Berger Report). See “Industry and Market Data⸺Life Science⸺General.”

_Performance Materials market_

Alongside our operations in the Crop Science and Life Science markets, our results of operations are also driven
by changes in the global Performance Materials market and the demand for our products by our customers. In
2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 15% of our products were used in the
Performance Materials market (measured as a percentage of revenues).

High Performance Materials are increasingly needed by suppliers to manufacture their complex products, with
our chemicals being used in, among others, flexible printed circuitry and foldable displays for smart devices,
composite components for automotive and aviation, thermal insulation for aircraft and marine vessels, coatings
and tubing for medical devices and radiation shielding for spacecraft. See “Industry and Market
_Data⸺Performance Materials⸺Specialty Anhydrides⸺General.”_

**_Volume, product mix and pricing_**

Individual product volumes and margins as well as our product mix are key drivers to maintaining and enhancing
our profitability.

We hold strong market positions across certain of our product groups in the Crop Science, Life Science and
Performance Materials markets. We believe that we are among the top two Western CDMO players in the Crop
Science market (by Crop Science CDMO revenue as of 2021). The active ingredients and precursors that we
supply to our Crop Science customers are used in the production of herbicides, fungicides and insecticides.
Demand for these products and therefore the volumes that we sell may vary from year to year based on, amongst
others, external factors such as weather conditions in different parts of the world and prevailing crop prices, which
in turn can impact our margins. Our key Crop Science customers are active on a global scale and our sales to them
are oftentimes based on longer-term contracts. Moreover, being a specialized CDMO is a service business, most
of our Exclusives products are tailored to an individual customer’s specific requirements based on their intellectual
property and, therefore, critical to the production or performance of our customers’ products. In addition, our
portfolio comprises innovative products in niche markets with high growth rates, such as DCA (Roland Berger
Report, Company Information). We are one of the largest European Life Science MCA suppliers (by production
volume in Europe as of 2022). We are the global market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high
purity grade DCA (a key ingredient for RNA-based medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications
(by high purity DCA revenue as of 2022) (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). See also

69


-----

“⸺Development of mega-trends in the Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials Markets” and
“Industry and Market Data.”

We benefit from the critical nature of certain of our Exclusive and Specialties ingredients to the performance of
our customers’ products as well as our high integration into our customers’ value chain, sometimes being the
primary supplier of certain key products, which is in such cases embedded into our contractual agreements with
our customers.

For our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals group, which comprises a number of products, each with a
broad range of customers, our business operations are mostly driven by underlying supply and demand market
dynamics as well as our plant utilization rates. MCA, as one of our main products in Advanced Intermediates and
Base Chemicals, is mainly used in the Life Science and the Crop Science markets. Historically, demand for MCA
has grown across various end-markets, which, we believe, has contributed to our high utilization rates.
Furthermore, proximity to customers and supply chain expertise are critical due to the relatively high
transportation costs of distributing MCA. We believe we are also able to better serve our customers in this area
due to our differentiated logistics capabilities. Our Base Products, such as caustic soda and hydrochloric acid, are
by-products from the production of chlorine and MCA, and are used in several end-markets including the broader
chemicals space, pulp and paper, alumina, soap, detergents and others. Caustic soda prices are highly volatile due
to their strong dependency on chlorine production (which impacts caustic supply, as caustic demand remains
relatively stable over time) and energy prices. The market price for caustic soda declined in 2020 and 2021 driven
by lower overall economic activity during the pandemic, thereby negatively impacting the contribution of some
of our products to our profitability for the 2020 and 2021 financial years, however it subsequently significantly
increased in 2022 with prices reaching an all-time high, which had a positive impact on our results which
materialized in a significant uplift of revenues in 2022. Since then, the market price of caustic soda has declined
to some extent and we expect it to normalize (at approximately €400-600/t, based on Western European spot rates)
further in the future (Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

**_Raw materials and energy costs_**

Raw material and energy prices are key components of our cost of sales and therefore are a significant value lever
for our gross profit. Our cost of raw materials and supplies was €270.7 million or 47.9% of our cost of sales for
the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022 (2021: €216.5 million or 47.0% of our cost of sales; 2020: €157.6 million
or 40.4% of our cost of sales).

The cost of raw materials has generally been correlated with industry wide supply, demand dynamics and global
economic conditions. For example, a primary driver for the increase in 2021 and 2022 was due to an increase in
certain raw materials prices such as acetic acid. We have a value-added pricing model with partial cost passthrough mechanisms in some of our contracts. Since price volatilities in raw material or energy prices could have
a negative impact on our margins, we are highly focused on our ability to partially pass on raw material price
changes and our ability to maintain high degree of utilization in our plants.

In the Crop Science market in particular, raw materials used in the production of our Exclusives and Specialties
products are to a significant extent either provided by our customers and are therefore not recorded in our cost of
sales, or some of our customer contracts include partial pass-through clauses to protect against fluctuations in the
prices of raw materials, helping to protect against margin fluctuations. For example, in Exclusives, some contracts
are conversion fee model based and resulting revenues from most of such contracts were not exposed to any raw
material price fluctuations. In such contracts, raw materials are sourced directly through the customers or 100%
charged at cost at the end of the production run.

For Specialties and Advanced Intermediates products, some of our contracts include partial cost pass-throughs.
These partial pass-through provisions help to limit fluctuations in our cost of sales and therefore protecting
profitability by allowing us to partially pass on raw material price increases to our customers. For the Advanced
Intermediates and Base Chemicals, our most important raw materials are acetic acid, acetic anhydride and chlorine
and certain customer contracts by sales include price formulas that allow for a partial pass-through of price
variations (not including chlorine price variations).

Alongside raw material costs, our cost of sales also include energy costs, which amounted to €65.6 million or
11.6% of our cost of sales for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022 (2021: €41.3 million or 9.0%; 2020: €35.1
million or 9.0% of our cost of sales). Operating our state-of-the-art technologies requires a significant amount of
energy. Rising energy prices, energy price fluctuations as well as environmental levies or government incentives
have had, and may continue to have, an impact on our margins. We therefore hedge against some of these price

70


-----

volatilities, in particular for our sites in Germany and Switzerland. For the financial years ended December 31,
2020, 2021 and 2022, approximately 83%, 80% and 69%, respectively, of our electricity costs have been hedged
and for the financial year ended December 31, 2023, we have hedged approximately 70% of our electricity costs
(measured as a percentage of total GWh).

**_Capital Expenditures and Capacity Expansion_**

Our capital expenditures (capex) focus on (a) targeted capacity expansions for new and existing products and debottlenecking projects in line with the specific customer demands (“Growth Capex”), (b) maintenance projects
to continuously upgrade and optimize our facilities and increase asset reliability levels as well as adopting our
facilities to the required regulatory and safety standards (“Maintenance Capex”), and (c) targeted plant upgrades
programs (including our “Fit for Future” (F4F) capex program to upgrade Pratteln assets, which is expected to
finish this year). Our cash capital expenditure for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 was €71.6 million
(2021: €68.6 million; 2020: €60.0 million). For the financial year ended December 31, 2023 we expect capital
expenditures to be in the mid-€60 million range.

Our capex allocation follows a stringent prioritization process managed by our Executive Committee and board
to review all projects regarding financial return, e.g., payback periods and return rates (predominantly Growth
Capex), binding customer commitments as well as implications on asset availability and safety prior to approval.
For Maintenance Capex, we focus on our capex allocation primarily on production lines with high margin potential
and/or strong customer demand and efficiency projects, e.g., improvements of energy efficiency, to ensure
adequate return rates from investments. For Growth Capex projects, we typically target EBITDA pay-back periods
of approximately three years and return rates of approximately 25% internal rate of return secured by binding
customer commitments, with customers signing either firm commitments for minimum volumes and/or
contributing a share of the capex via a fixed facility fee. While this is not achieved in all our projects, we aim to
strengthen our product portfolio over time with projects that either match our key criteria above or otherwise offer
strategic opportunities.

_Growth Capex_

Growth Capex accounted for slightly more than a third of our yearly capex spend and increased as a proportion
of total capex from 2020 to 2021 as a result of additional capacity expansion projects for new products in Finland
and Switzerland and has remained relatively constant as a proportion of total capex across 2021 and 2022.

Growth investments are mostly focused on high-margin Crop Science products and Life Science. We partner with
most of our CDMO customers through long-term contracts to deliver specialized active ingredients and precursors
according to individualized requests, often requiring custom production lines and processes. As a result, a large
share of our capex is invested in our CDMO business or in contracted capacity expansion for our Specialties
products.

A CDMO project development lifecycle of a new product can extend to up to 18 months in the customer request
phase as well as a further 24 months of investment period before commercialization. As a result, we aim to have
our customers take a share in the initial capex spend by entering into agreements with our clients to de-risk the
investments, with our long-term contracts for a large part of our portfolio, most of which featuring either
guaranteed volumes commitments for an initial period, up-front contributions to the capex requirements to set-up
production or ‘take-or-pay’ clauses. In general, we aim to recover our capex investment within approximately
three years from the start of commercialization and a typical production horizon for large, strategic products
extends historically to over 10 years.

Increasing our ability to onboard client projects, in 2019 we expanded our operations into the United States with
the acquisition of Monitchem Kansas S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries, including the Jayhawk facility in Galena, Kansas,
United States. Furthermore, as part of our capacity expansions at our multipurpose plants, we further expanded
our production capacities in Kokkola (Finland) to serve our customers in connection with already secured and
newly developed products for the Crop Science market.

_Maintenance Capex_

Overall, Maintenance Capex remained relatively constant as a proportion of total capex across 2020 and 2021,
increasing in 2022, in line with our growing asset base.

We allocate ongoing Maintenance Capex to support differentiation and competitiveness of our existing plants.
Our Maintenance Capex requirement is mainly driven by the corrosive nature of substances used in our production

71


-----

process, making periodical inspection and maintenance of our plants and production chains necessary.
Furthermore, our Maintenance Capex helps to ensure asset availability, productivity, energy efficiency and
optimized performance. A significant proportion of yearly Maintenance Capex is allocated to maintenance works
for our production plants with Pratteln (as our largest site), accounting for a large share of yearly Maintenance
Capex expenses.

_F4F capex_

In 2018, we began the “Fit for Future” (“F4F”) capex program for our site in Pratteln. The project, which is
expected to finish this year, covers key aspects of our operations and comprises multiple initiatives to further
improve and safeguard asset safety, reliability, availability and compliance. Our F4F investment projects offer
returns via opportunities for price increases as well as additional volumes from the respective production lines.

**_Seasonality_**

Our results of operations for the first and fourth quarters of the year are generally stronger than our results of
operation for the second and third quarters, largely due to seasonal factors in demand from our Crop Science
customers. We typically experience an increase in production levels in the first and fourth quarters of the year in
order to meet the stronger demand in those quarters in line with increased demand for Crop Science products in
the Northern Hemisphere each spring prior to the growing season. In addition, we and other chemical companies,
including certain suppliers and customers, generally schedule repairs of machinery and facility turnarounds
(scheduled shutdowns of production units or facilities for maintenance) in the summer months, which may result
in lower sales in the second and third quarters relative to the first and fourth quarters of a given year. To the extent
possible, we try to coordinate such repair schedules with our customers and suppliers.

Seasonal fluctuations including adverse weather conditions may adversely affect certain of our markets and
customers, thereby impacting our quarterly results disproportionately due to the seasonal nature of our business.
For example, in the 2020 summer, the dry weather in Europe affected some of our customers and therefore
impacted demand. See “Risk Factors⸺Risks Related to Our Business⸺Seasonal fluctuations may impact our
_sales and cash flows.”_

**_Effects of COVID-19_**

Generally, in the financial year 2020, the Group’s business model proved to be resilient throughout the coronavirus
pandemic, as we experienced resilient end-customer demand from the Crop Science and Life Science markets,
benefitting from predictable revenues under existing long-term supply contracts for a large part of our portfolio.
Furthermore, we were able to maintain well-managed supply chains and ensure reliable production and delivery
channels to customers.

While we have experienced some delays in raw material deliveries and were required to adapt our processes in
procurement, inventory management and trade working capital strategies, the COVID-19 pandemic and the global
supply chain and transportation network disruptions did not have a material impact on our results of operations in
2020, 2021 and 2022, underlying the resilience of the business model.

COVID-19-related restrictions impacted Crop Science production in the first quarter of the financial year 2020
but normalized following the easing of lockdown restrictions. Whilst the COVID-19 restrictions did impact labor
availability, both in terms of production and field work, many countries deemed the agricultural sector to be of
considerable importance in order to maintain food security, therefore, restrictions on movement were less stringent
than in other industries.

**_Manufacturing Capacity Utilization and Planned maintenance turnarounds_**

Utilization rates of our manufacturing capacity is a significant driver of our profitability, since our cost of sales
comprises variable and fixed components. Fixed costs include plant related and overhead costs such as personnel
expenses, energy costs, repair and maintenance expenses, which are largely independent from production
volumes.

We operate our facilities at generally high utilization rates and continuously focus on further improving these
utilization rates. To maintain the efficiency of our assets, we regularly undergo scheduled maintenance shutdowns
in order to carry out required maintenance activities, perform necessary inspections and tests or accommodate for
shutdowns of key suppliers. We refer to these scheduled outages as “turnarounds”. The number and length of such
turnarounds carried out in any given period impact our operating results and the level of our capital expenditures.

72


-----

However, we try to coordinate such repair schedules with our customers and suppliers as they may also need to
undergo “turnarounds” at the same time. Furthermore, for our multi-purpose plants that produce customized and
specialized chemicals, whenever we change production from one product to another, we factor in the ‘switchover’ times required to clean the reactor vessels. This requires us to shut down operations of a production unit
within a production facility until the cleaning is completed. See “⸺Seasonality.”

Our production facilities undergo regular maintenance which requires the outage of a production unit or the entire
facility for a period of two to four weeks per year. Repair and maintenance costs in connection with such regular
maintenance can be up to several millions. In the past three years, our repair and maintenance expenses amounted
to €27.5 million in 2022 (2021: €21.4 million; 2020: €20.8 million).

**_Industry regulations_**

Our results of operations are also influenced by the evolving nature of regulations impacting the industries in
which our customers operate. In particular for our Exclusives and Specialties product group, certain customers
produce pharmaceuticals subject to evolving requirements, or complex Crop Science products subject to
developing rules around permitted usage. Such requirements have become increasingly extensive and complex,
requiring specialist CDMO partners with strong technical expertise and assets fitting into global supply chains of
Crop Science players. As a result of these changing requirements, we have taken a strategic decision in the past
to phase out certain services and products with lower margin to focus on our core strengths and expertise in Crop
Science, which offers us a more attractive business case and return on investment. Such strategic portfolio
management decisions have temporarily negatively affected our revenue for the respective years but have freed
up capacities and avoided cost increases for the expansion in our core business. See also “Regulation,
_Environmental, Health and Safety Measures” and “Risk Factors⸺Risks related to the Industry in which we_
_Operate⸺We are subject to stringent environmental, health and safety laws and regulations across multiple_
_jurisdictions. We are highly regulated and may incur significant costs to maintain compliance with, or address_
_liabilities under, environmental, health and safety laws and regulations applicable to our business.”_

**Key Income Statement Items**

Set forth below is a brief description of the composition of the key line items of our consolidated statement of
profit or loss:

**_Revenue_**

Revenue from contracts with customers is recognized in the amount of the consideration the Group expects to
receive in exchange for the goods or services when the customer obtains control of the goods or services. Control
is considered to be transferred when the customer can direct the use of the goods or services and can obtain all
substantial remaining benefits from them.

We primarily generate income from the sale of goods. For the Exclusives and Specialties product group, revenue
from specific customer contracts is recognized over time. In these cases our performance obligation consists in
the creation of an asset without an alternative use to us and we have an enforceable right to payment for the
performance obligation completed to date. These contractually enforceable rights are recognized and disclosed
within ‘Accounts receivable, trade’ if already shipped, or otherwise within ‘Contract assets’.

Certain customer contracts for the Exclusives product group foresee non-refundable up-front capital expenditure
fees, which are paid by the customer at the beginning of the investment project. These advance payments are
recognized in the consolidated statement of profit or loss in proportion to the performance used by the customer
during the contract period (output method). The outstanding performance obligation is disclosed in the balance
sheet at each reporting date.

If a customer contract does not meet these criteria, the customer obtains control of the goods at a specific point in
time, and the corresponding sales revenue is hence recognized at a specific point in time. Determination of the
point in time at which the customer obtains control of the goods occurs in the context of an overall assessment of
the circumstances which considers the existence of a present claim to payment, the legal title to the goods, actual
physical possession of the goods, the transfer of risks and rewards as well as customer acceptance. The transfer
of risks and rewards takes into account the underlying terms of delivery (especially the International Commercial
Terms, or “Incoterms”) and is of particular practical significance. According to these principles, sales revenue
from the sale of goods is generally recognized upon delivery.

73


-----

**_Cost of Sales_**

Cost of sales comprises the costs of materials and supplies, personnel expenses, proportionate depreciation and
amortization, repairs and maintenance, energy, analysis and ecology, production overheads, plant overheads as
well as costs of packaging the products.

**_General and Administrative Expenses_**

General and administrative expenses comprise personnel expenses, legal and consultancy costs and other external
services as well as insurance premiums.

**_Distribution and Logistics Expenses_**

Distribution and logistics expenses comprise the costs of personnel expenses, proportionate depreciation on
property, plant and equipment and intangible assets as well as transport costs.

**_Research and Development Expenses_**

Research costs are recognized immediately as expense when they are incurred. They comprise wages and salaries,
cost of materials, proportionate depreciation on property, plant and equipment and overheads. Development costs
are only capitalized if, on the basis of various criteria, it is probable that the capitalized amount will be covered
by future income.

**_Financial Result_**

Financial result contains interest income and expenses as well as foreign currency gains and losses. Interest income
and expenses is recognized using the effective interest rate method.

**_Net Result for the Period_**

Net result for the year comprises net result for the year attributable to shareholders as well as net result for the
year attributable to non-controlling interests. Non-controlling interests reflect a 32.4% share in CABB–Jinwei
Specialty Chemicals (Jining) Co. Ltd., Zhanghuang Town (PRC) that is held by shareholders other than CABB
GmbH.

_Revenue_

Revenue increased year-on-year by €96.7 million or 19.6% from €492.3 million in the financial year ended
December 31, 2020 to €589.0 million in the financial year ended December 31, 2021, due to strong demand in
both our product groups in 2021 across the portfolio and supported by the reversal of temporary pressure on
caustic soda prices induced by COVID-19.

Revenue of the Exclusives and Specialties product group increased by €55.1 million or 17.6% from €312.2 million
in the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €367.3 million in the financial year ended December 31, 2021,
driven by a strong demand from our agrochemical customers for Exclusives. The strong revenue growth was both
driven by higher volumes and by positive pricing effects, as increased raw material prices were partially passed
on to our customers. Revenue of Specialties increased, driven by positive pricing effects and a continued strong
demand for high-value products in regulated markets, such as pharmaceutical, personal care, food and animal feed
as well as automotive, aerospace and agrochemical industries.

In 2020, a fire incident at our Pratteln site led to a partial standstill of the chlorine value chain, which negatively
impacted our revenues in both product groups. In addition, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a temporary
decline in the price for caustic soda, resulting in temporarily lower 2020 revenues. Adjusted for the impact of the
Pratteln site fire incident, all our product groups still experienced strong growth: in our Exclusives and Specialties
product group the strong growth of 17.6% resulted from project wins and strong demand for our existing portfolio
of products, growth in innovative niche specialties products and overall very resilient demand in Crop and Life
sciences, while Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals exhibited a 23.1% year-on-year growth in revenue
which was principally due to the start of the caustic soda price recovery, continued successful partial pass-through
of a certain portion of raw material price increases to customers and a largely stable volume development and, for
some Specialties and Advanced Intermediates, the need for Western suppliers to de-risk supply chains.

(1) Reported EBITDA means net result for the period adding back taxes on income, financial results, amortization and depreciation.

(2) Adjusted EBITDA means result for the period adding back taxes on income, financial result, amortization and depreciation and
adjustments for expenses and income not related to the operational performance of the business activities, such as strategic projects,
restructuring and reorganization measures, financial impacts of natural disasters, property damage insurance compensations, as well as
valuation impacts resulting from curtailments or modifications to pension or post-retirement benefits schemes and purchase price
allocations. Neither EBITDA nor Adjusted EBITDA is a performance indicator recognized under IFRS. The EBITDA and the Adjusted
EBITDA reported is not necessarily comparable to the performance figures published by other companies as EBITDA or Adjusted
EBITDA or the like.

Adjusted EBITDA increased by €34.8 million, or 27.2%, from €127.8 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2021 to €162.6 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Historical growth in
Adjusted EBITDA was driven by favorable market conditions and a continued strong demand across both product
groups in 2022, in particular due to an increase in pricing resulting in a higher margin for our products from
customers in our Exclusives and Specialties business as well as positive pricing effects in our Advanced
Intermediates and Base Chemicals business.

Adjusted EBITDA increased by €14.9 million, or 13.2%, from €112.9 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2020 to €127.8 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. The growth in Adjusted
EBITDA was driven by resilient top-line growth and new product introductions, paired with shift to higher margin
Exclusives and Specialties business, our ability to partially pass on raw material prices efficiently and substantial
benefits from operating leverage as we focus on efficient plant and overhead management. The strong growth in
Adjusted EBITDA was achieved despite supply chain disruptions in early 2021.

In the first half of the financial year 2021, the Group’s performance was negatively affected by extreme winter
weather conditions in the Gulf coast area in the U.S., impacting the business operations of our raw material
suppliers. These suppliers were forced to declare the occurrence of a force majeure event for various products
such as, for example, Acetic Acid. This resulted in a loss of already contracted business (purchase orders), which
was not compensated by insurance and was normalized as part of non-recurring items.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our principal sources of funds have been cash generated from our operating activities, borrowings under the
Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and sale of receivables under the Securitization Program and the
Factoring Program. Our principal uses of cash are for capital expenditures, to fund debt service obligations and
for working capital. As of December 31, 2022, we had cash and cash equivalents of €69.9 million.

Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows. We will also
have access to the New Revolving Credit Facility to service our working capital and general corporate needs. The
continued availability of the New Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon certain conditions as described
further under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement.” In
addition, our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which, in turn, depends to
some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control.
See “Risk Factors.”

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, together with available borrowings
under the New Revolving Credit Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs,
we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities or that future
debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including
the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

**_Financial Year ended December 31, 2021 compared with the Financial Year ended December 31, 2022_**

_Cash Flow from Operating Activities_

Cash flow from operating activities increased by €54.3 million from €96.4 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2021 to €150.7 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily
due to the significant increase in Reported EBITDA. Furthermore, despite rising raw material and energy prices,
net working capital increased at a slower rate than in the previous period.

_Cash Flow from Investing Activities_

Cash flow used in investing activities increased by €4.2 million from €67.3 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2021 to €71.5 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily
due to investments into measures regarding asset reliability and availability with respect to our production sites
as well as contracted growth projects, including our “Fit for Future” program.

_Cash Flow from Financing Activities_

Cash flow used in financing activities increased by €8.6 million from €42.4 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2021 to €51.0 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily
due to an increase in drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in the amount of €5.0
million and an increase in interest rates as a result of such larger amount drawn thereunder. In addition, other
financial debt decreased to a cash outflow of €2.4 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 resulting
from a sale of non-current assets and includes proceeds that were not passed on to other members of a consortium
until the financial year 2022.

**_Financial Year ended December 31, 2020 compared with the Financial Year ended December 31, 2021_**

_Cash Flow from Operating Activities_

Cash flow from operating activities decreased by €28.1 million from €124.5 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2020 to €96.4 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. While our Reported
EBITDA increased significantly from €110.7 million to €117.5 million as a result of strong business growth, our
working capital requirements also increased, in particular higher inventories and accounts receivables which
reduced our cash flow from operating activities year-on-year.

_Cash Flow from Investing Activities_

Cash flow used in investing activities increased by €7.5 million from €59.8 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2020 to €67.3 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was principally
due to higher investments in property, plant and equipment in 2021, in particular at the sites in Pratteln and in
Kokkola. Material investments in 2021 included maintenance, safety and reliability measures as well as the
expansion of production capacities for the Exclusives and Specialties product group, which were higher than in
2020.

_Cash Flow from Financing Activities_

Cash flow used in financing activities increased by €2.2 million from €40.1 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2020 to €42.3 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. While interest and financing
fees paid decreased from €44.3 million to €44.0 million year-on-year. In addition, we utilized our Existing
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in 2020 by €10.0 million compared to an additional utilization of only €5.0
million in 2021. This was due to higher net working capital financing needs, which increased as a result of a strong
business performance and rising raw material and energy prices. The change in other financial debt (€2.5 million)
was a result of the sale of fixed assets and reflects proceeds in 2021 which were forwarded to other members of a
consortium in 2022.

**_Capital Expenditures_**

Our capital expenditures primarily relate to maintenance projects, facility upgrades and capacity expansion
projects, optimization and de-bottlenecking. A significant portion of our yearly capex expenditure is allocated to
maintenance costs, a big proportion of which is required for our plant in Pratteln. Growth Capex accounted for
slightly more than a third of our yearly capex spend and increased as a proportion of total capex from 2020 to
2021 and has remained relatively constant as a proportion of total capex across 2021 and 2022. See “⸺Factors
_Affecting our Results of Operations⸺Capital Expenditures and Capacity Expansion.” A relatively small part of_
our capital expenditures is spent on intangible assets, including information and communications technology,
research and development.

**_Goodwill_**

Goodwill in the amount of €199.2 million is recognized in the consolidated statement of financial position for the
financial year ended December 31, 2022. Goodwill is subject to an annual impairment test at on the basis of cashgenerating units a minimum by comparing its carrying amount with its recoverable amount.

87


-----

The goodwill impairment test is performed on the basis of cash-generating units (CGUs) by comparing the
recoverable amount with the carrying amount. Consistent with the internal management and reporting structure,
the following three cash generating units have been identified: (i) CDMO – Europe, (ii) CDMO – North America,
(iii) Non - CDMO. The CGUs reflect the lowest level within the entity at which goodwill is monitored for internal
management purposes. The existing goodwill was allocated to the CGUs in accordance with the purchase price
allocation in 2014 for the CGU CDMO – Europe and the CGU Non – CDMO resp. 2019 for the CGU CDMO –
North America.

The recoverable amount of the cash-generating units is calculated based on the fair value less costs to sell
approach. The underlying cash flow projections are based on past experiences, current results and on the best
estimate of the future development of influencing factors. Market assumptions, such as the development of the
overall economy and the market growth are considered using external macroeconomical and industry-specific
information sources. The required discounting of cash flows for impairment testing is calculated using the
weighted average cost of capital rate after tax, which is determined using the capital asset pricing model. It
comprises a risk-free interest rate, a market risk premium, and a spread for credit risk based on the respective
industry-specific peer group. The fair value measurement was categorized as a level 3 fair value. The financial
projections were approved by management and consist of a detailed planning period of five years.

The annual impairment test was performed as of October 31, 2022. The recoverable amount of all CGU’s exceed
their carrying amounts as of December 31, 2022 and as of December 31, 2021. No goodwill impairment was
indicated. See Note 18 to our 2022 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

**_Pension provisions_**

As of December 31, 2022, we reported provisions of €18.1 million for pensions and similar obligations. The
valuation of these pension provisions is influenced by assumptions regarding the future development of wages
and salaries or pensions as well as interest rates.

In Germany, retirement benefits are provided via the pension fund of the employees of the Hoechst Group VVaG.
The Swiss employees of the Group are insured with the pension fund of CABB AG, Pratteln, Switzerland. The
retirement benefits of the Finnish employees are processed via the pension insurance company Ilmarinen Ltd. The

such as the discount rate and the pension growth rate used for calculating the present value of the future pension
obligations. Future salary increases and increases in the other benefits to employees also influence the calculation
of the present value of future pension obligations. In addition, the independent actuaries engaged by us also use
statistical data such as probability of departure and life expectancy of the insured parties for their assumptions.

The discount rate for the actuarial calculations of the German and Finnish defined benefit obligations was
determined by applying the Mercer Pension Yield Curve Approach (MYC). The data and methodology used to
create the MYC is reviewed periodically by Mercer to ensure consistency and improved estimates.

**Recently Adopted Accounting Regulations**

With effect from January 1, 2022, we applied certain new and amended standards and interpretations published
by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and endorsed by the European Union. The amendments
had no material impact on the Group’s financial position or results of operations:

- Amendments to IFRS 3 Business Combinations, IAS 16 Property, Plant and Equipment, IAS 37 Provisions,
Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets as well as Annual Improvements to IFRS 2018 – 2020. The
amendments to IFRS include an update of the reference of the Conceptual Framework in IFRS standards.
Furthermore, an additional provision was added to IFRS 3 stating that an acquirer must apply the provisions
from IAS 37 and IFRIC 21 rather than the Conceptual Framework when identifying assumed liabilities within
the scope of these standards.

- The amendments to IAS 16 specify that income received by a company through the sale of items produced
while the asset is being brought to its location and into working order must be recognized with the associated
costs in profit or loss. Including these items in the cost of the asset is not permissible.

- The amendments to IAS 37 specify which costs an entity includes in determining the cost of fulfilling a
contract for the purpose of assessing whether the contract is onerous. The amendments apply for annual
reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2022 to contracts existing at the date when the amendments
are first applied. At the date of initial application, the cumulative effect of applying the amendments is
recognized as an opening balance adjustment to retained earnings or other components of equity, as
appropriate. The comparatives are not restated.

- The annual improvements to IFRS 2018 – 2020 pertain to amendments to IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments,
whereby only such costs and fees which are paid to the lender by the company and vice versa are to be
included in the “10% test” for the purpose of derecognition of financial liabilities. Costs or fees paid to other
third parties may not to be included. Moreover, they pertain to minor amendments to IFRS 1 First-Time
Adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards, IAS 41 Agriculture, and to the explanatory
examples of IFRS 16 Leases.

**INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA**

Our three main end-markets: (i) Crop Science, (ii) Life Science and (iii) Performance Materials, which we serve
with our offering across product groups, benefit from several persistent and structural long-term mega-trends.

**Crop Science**

**_General_**

Crop Science products mainly comprise three key product segments, (1) herbicides, (2) insecticides and (3)
fungicides, which are applied to improve crop yields and increase efficiency of crop production for products such
as corn, wheat or soybeans. In 2022, total revenue of the underlying global Crop Science market amounted to
€69.6 billion, growing at a CAGR of 7.8% from €55.6 billion in 2019 (Roland Berger Report).

Out of the approximately €70 billion Crop Science market, active ingredients (including advanced intermediates)
manufacturing accounted for approximately €13-17 billion. Active ingredients refer to the chemical compound
that is used in the final crop protection product and achieves the desired counteractive properties against pests,
such as weeds, insects and fungi, among other organisms. Active ingredients manufacturing refers to a multi-step
manufacturing process of the key chemical ingredient within crop protection products that imparts the biological
activity to the crop protection products. Within the active ingredient manufacturing market, around 40-50% of the
production is outsourced to CDMOs such as us, implying a total addressable Crop Science CDMO market for the
CABB Group (“CABB”) of approximately €6.5-7.0 billion in 2022 (Roland Berger Report). See “⸺Crop
_Science⸺CDMO.”_

**_Key Drivers_**

Demand for crop protection products is primarily driven by farmer demand. Increasing demand is expected due
to two underlying long-term mega-trends, which overall positively affect the Crop Science market: (1) the growing
population and rising middle class; and (2) decreasing arable land per capita. Population growth and the
consequent increase in food demand, which, taken with the reduction in arable land per capita available, will drive
a strong need for more efficient, higher-priced innovative crop protection products capable of improving farmland yields on available areas (Roland Berger Report).

_Growing population and rising middle class_

Growing global population leads to an increased demand for food and crops. Additionally, a higher caloric intake
per capita and a fast-growing global middle class also positively impact the future demand for food supply. The
total world population is expected to grow at a CAGR of 0.9% from approximately 7.8 billion in 2020 to 8.5
billion in 2030, down from a slightly higher CAGR of 1.2% between 2000 and 2020 (Roland Berger Report). The
global middle class population (i.e., households with per capita income between US$10 and US$100 per person
per day) drives a stronger demand for food and crops and has grown at a CAGR of 4.4%, from 3.0 billion in 2015
to 3.8 billion in 2020. Forecasts predict a further CAGR of 3.7% from 2020 to 2030 (Roland Berger Report).

_Decreasing arable land per capita_

Although arable land has grown slightly in absolute terms, it has decreased in relation to the increasing global
population. Available hectares per capita have declined at a rate of -1.1% CAGR from 2000 to 2020 (Roland
Berger Report). As a result, achieving target crop yields per hectare within available areas to support an increasing
population requires greater efficiency in crop protection, which fosters the need for efficient Crop Science
products (Roland Berger Report).

Source: Roland Berger Report

_Increased prices for crop commodities since 2020_

Prices of crop commodities are a major factor for the Crop Science market, since high (or low) trading prices
generally lead to increased (or reduced) farmer income, and as a result increase (or decrease) farmers’ ability to
spend on Crop Science products. Furthermore, farmers are increasingly using tools such as digital monitoring of
crop areas, which allows them to use more precise, accurate and sophisticated Crop Science products (e.g., small
batches and/or targeted applications) to enhance their crop yields. After a long period of stagnation, the prices of

91


-----

crop commodities surged in the second half of 2020 due to increased demand and supply imbalance caused by
strong demand from China, unfavorable weather conditions and COVID-19, which led to supply chain
interruptions. Similarly, prices have sharply increased in the first half of 2022 as a result of the energy crisis and
the overall inflationary environment among other factors. At the end of 2022, prices had decreased slightly but
still remained at high levels. Further, because Russia and Ukraine are major producers and exporters of crops, the
Russia/Ukraine war has led to a crop supply reduction, which subsequently created a need for higher yields in
other countries and drove up crop protection prices. However, the Russia/Ukraine war appears to have had a very
limited impact on volumes in the Crop Science market as both countries accounted for less than 5% of the total
market value for 2022 (Roland Berger Report).

Driven by the foregoing trends, the underlying Crop Science market is expected to experience long-term growth
of approximately 2% CAGR until 2027, ultimately reaching approximately €77 billion (Roland Berger Report).

Source: AgbioInvestor; Roland Berger Report

**_CDMO_**

_General_

The Crop Science CDMO market, which is the key addressable market relevant to CABB, is expected to grow
faster than the general Crop Science market. Crop Science CDMO players serve as an outsourcing solution for
global Crop Science companies versus the in-house development and manufacturing of crop protection products.
The decision of Crop Science players to outsource to CDMO specialists is mainly driven by three factors: (1)
technical expertise; (2) capacity availability; and (3) cost considerations and capital expenditure requirements
(Roland Berger Report), which are further detailed below under “—Key Drivers.”

Over the years, there has been an increase in outsourcing within the Crop Science industry. As of 2022,
approximately 40-50% of active ingredient production by Crop Science players was outsourced to contract
manufacturers, such as CABB. The CDMO Crop Science market represented about €6.5-7.0 billion as of 2022,
having grown at a CAGR of 9-10% between 2019 and 2022. The market is expected to further grow at a CAGR
of 4-5% until 2027 (Roland Berger Report). Due to the increasing complexity of new molecules, a lack of available
capacities in-house at clients and a high likelihood of customers engaging in cost reduction efforts, it is expected
that Crop Science players will outsource an increasing share of development and manufacturing to CDMOs
(Roland Berger Report).

92


-----

_Key Drivers_

_(1) Technical expertise_

Among the factors considered, technical expertise and know-how is one of the top decision criteria that companies
take into consideration when determining whether to outsource their production. This is explained by the rising
complexity of new active ingredient molecules. Synthesis of these molecules requires a higher number of steps,
so the production process typically requires specialist know-how. Since major Crop Science players may not
always have the complete technical expertise required, they increasingly rely on CDMO partners with an
increasing share of their production process expected to be outsourced in the future as a result (Roland Berger
Report).

_(2) Capacity availability_

Another important key decision criterion for customers when choosing their CDMO partner is suitable capacity
availability. Crop Science players do not always have excess capacity to cover growing product demand and
consequently rely increasingly on CDMO partners. As major Crop Science players look to outsource their
production activities, the ability for CDMOs to offer sufficient fit-for-purpose production capacity as well as
flexibility for further expansion is critical (Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

_(3) Cost considerations and capex requirements_

The increasing complexity of molecules, more stringent regulatory trends and fast-evolving customer demand
patterns mean that major Crop Science players must focus increasingly on research and development, regulatory
and marketing activities, and thereby less on growing in-house manufacturing. Against this backdrop, Crop
Science players are focused on ensuring cost and capex discipline with regard to production activities, which
supports their decision to outsource production to CDMOs (Roland Berger Report).

_CDMO Globally_

The CDMO market is expected to grow by a CAGR of 4-5% across geographies, with India as key growth driver
and decent growth in Europe at a CAGR of 2-4%, given the different growth dynamics in various locations.
Below is a list of geographies in terms of the location of production for the CDMO market. On a regional level,
Europe accounted for 20-25% of market value in 2022 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 2-4% until 2027,
primarily driven by the introduction of and increasing demand for new proprietary and complex active ingredients.
Europe is home to three of the global Crop Science majors and a strong foothold in the region ensures customer
proximity. India is the largest market, accounting for approximately 35-40% of the global Crop Science CDMO
market. While outsourcing to China has grown substantially over the last decade, increasing competition from
India and concerns over security of supply are expected to limit growth going forward. India is the key historic
and future growth driver and is expected to capture a large part of the additionally outsourced production due to
strong customer relationships with major customers, high price competitiveness paired with less governmental
control compared to China and increasing manufacturing competence. Consequently, India’s Crop Science
CDMO market is expected to grow at 8-10% CAGR until 2027, compared to a 15-16% growth rate from 2019 to
2022. North America and Japan, respectively, represent 3-8% and 2-4% of the global CDMO market and are
expected to grow at a CAGR of 5-7% and 1-3%, compared to 4-5% growth each from 2019 to 2022. The North
American market is expected to benefit from, among other things, higher level of regulation and high energy
prices in Europe. However, Europe and North America still remain important markets as shown in the graphic
below (Roland Berger Report).

**_Competition_**

Key competitors (by turnover) in the European Crop Science CDMO space include: Saltigo (Germany), Arxada
(Switzerland), WeylChem Group (Germany) and ESIM (Austria). Further, there are several Asian players
including Deccan (India) and Lianhetech (China) and in North America, CABB’s Jayhawk site competes with
Viakem (Mexico) and Grace (US). (Roland Berger Report).

Saltigo and CABB are the key European players in the novel active ingredients (AIs) segment. Further, along with
Saltigo, CABB is one of the leading players in the Crop Science market in terms of technological know-how,
possessing the ability to meet customer demands on a variety of commercial levels. Further, CABB has a strong
track record and long-standing client relationships due to its strong customer centricity. CABB has a unique global
supply chain structure with CDMO sites in the U.S., Switzerland and Finland. Proximity to the headquarters of
key Crop Science players such as Syngenta, Bayer and BASF in Europe and Corteva and FMC in the U.S.
constitute an advantage for CABB in the competitive landscape. Certain players in Asia perform better from a
price perspective due to lower personnel and infrastructure costs and fewer regulatory requirements. However,
price is less important for purchase decisions, as customers typically focus on technical know-how and track
record first (Roland Berger Report).

The Crop Science CDMO market shows a broad range of growth rates depending on the year of introduction of
the respective products. Products introduced after 2010 (“Novel AIs”) experience a higher outsourcing share and
are expected to exhibit stronger growth of 10% CAGR or above from 2022 until 2027. Those Novel AIs introduced
after 2010 account for approximately 5-10% of the addressable 2022 Crop Science CDMO market. The majority
of the market value of products launched before 1990 comprises generic active ingredients (>50%) with an
established market position but also lower expected growth from 2022 to 2027 of approximately 2-3% CAGR
(Roland Berger Report).

As of 2021, CABB, Deccan, Lianhetech, Saltigo, and PI Industries combined accounted for approximately 3237% of the global Crop Science CDMO Market. Together with the remaining five top ten competitors, the top ten
players account for approximately 50-55% of the overall Crop Science CDMO market (Roland Berger Report).

In terms of the market share in the EU, the Crop Science CDMO market is concentrated, with the top five players
in total comprising an estimated market share of 70-75% in 2021. More specifically, Saltigo represented 23-28%
of the market share, CABB 17-22%, Arxada 8-13%, WeylChem 6-11%, ESIM 5-10% and other entities combined
24-29% of the overall market (Roland Berger Report).

**Life Science**

**_General_**

The Life Science industry involves companies working in areas such as personal care, nutrition and
pharmaceuticals. Within the Life Science market, CABB mainly manufactures four products: (1)
monochloroacetic acid (“MCA”), which is predominantly used in personal care, e.g., bath and shower products,
but also in other items outside of the Life Sciences industry; (2) dichloroacetic acid (“DCA”) used in
pharmaceuticals, e.g., novel RNA and DNA therapeutics; (3) glycolic acid (“GA”), which is used in personal care,
e.g., skin care, and other products outside of the Life Sciences industry; and (4) ethyl-2-chloroacetoacetate
(“CAE”), which is used in food and feed, e.g., vitamins, and other products outside of the Life Sciences industry
(Roland Berger Report).

**_Key Drivers_**

Demand for Life Science ingredients is driven by the underlying demand for Life Science products, which in turn
is primarily impacted by several structural long-term trends: (1) as the global population ages, chronic diseases
and spending on pharmaceutical products are expected to rise. This is also fueled by a growing middle class
leading an increasingly sedentary lifestyle; (2) the growing middle class has resulted in corresponding growth in
disposable income and an expected increase in spending per capita on personal care products, especially antiaging solutions; (3) ongoing innovations and technological progress are enabling new therapeutic approaches and
more customized and personalized medicine that require Life Science ingredients; (4) rising prosperity in
emerging economies and rapid urbanization has corresponded with improved access to medical treatment and
solutions; and (5) rising concerns about the harmful effects of chemicals and synthetic products is shifting
consumer preference towards organic products, which may in turn decrease demand for chemical intermediates
in personal care and nutrition. Some consumers are also increasingly concerned about negative effects chemicals
may have on the environment (Roland Berger Report).

**_MCA_**

_General_

MCA is a building block in organic synthesis used in Life Sciences not only for the production of ingredients for
personal care, pharma and food products but also for industrial applications. As of 2022, the total global MCA
market represented about 1,100-1,200 ktons. Our MCA is mainly used in the Life Science industry, the Crop
Science industry and in Industrials & others. Life Science represented the largest MCA end-market as of 2022,
accounting for approximately 40-50% of the market volume. MCA has a large market volume of 520-540 ktons
focused on Life Science as of 2022, with a solid growth outlook of 4-5% CAGR (in terms of volumes in ktons)
between 2022 and 2027. In 2022, CABB was one of the largest MCA producer in terms of production capacity
installed. CABB and Nouryon are considered the leading market players in terms of security of supply and
delivering quality and high purity MCA (Roland Berger Report).

Other key competitors in this space include PCC Rokita SA (Poland) and Niacet (U.S.). In terms of supply
security, we and Nouryon are known to offer highly reliable supplies and are located in key geographic areas in
close proximity to key customers (Roland Berger Report).

_Key Drivers_

As of 2022, MCA within the Life Science market was expected to grow at a CAGR of 4-5% (in terms of volumes
in ktons) between 2022 and 2027, primarily due to the increased focus on hygiene and general health awareness.
This is driven by, among others, the following factors: (1) a higher demand for personal care products and
detergents supported by COVID-19, which is expected to positively impact the demand for MCA and betaines
(partially made up of MCA) in the long-run since they are essential ingredients in producing these personal care
products; (2) within consumer products in emerging markets, an increasing switch from solid to liquid products,
including soap and dishwashing detergents, which is expected to have a positive volume impact on betaines since
they are frequently used in liquid personal care products; and (3) within the food industry, an increasing trend of
adding carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) as a thickening agent or stabilizer in different foods and beverages. As
CMC production requires MCA as ingredient, MCA demand is expected to correspondingly benefit. While
volumes are expected to grow moderately overall, driven by the aforementioned market-trends, prices are
expected to decline after a peak in 2022 because MCA price is strongly linked to commoditized raw material
prices, and input costs are typically passed through to customers (Roland Berger Report).
