_MCA Esters_

As of 2022, the global Life Science MMCA and EMCA markets are expected to grow in value by around 4-5%
CAGR between 2024 and 2027, following a period of moderate growth or stagnation from 2023 to 2024 and a
decline in 2023 due to normalization of energy prices. The underlying volume growth can largely be attributed to
growing demand from all end-markets, i.e., food supplements (vitamin A), pharma (contrast agents and piracetam)
and the flavor and fragrances industry (Roland Berger Report). We convert MCA to MCA esters, i.e.
methylmonochloroacetate (MMCA) and ethylmonochloroacetate (EMCA), with applications such as producing
contrast agents, vitamins and other drugs such as the anti-dementia drug Piracetam.

**_DCA_**

_General_

DCA is a chemical compound predominantly used as a crucial component in the oligonucleotide synthesis process
for next-gen RNA-based therapeutics in pharmaceuticals. It is an essential ingredient in the key process step
(detritylation) of siRNA through oligonucleotide synthesis and for the chemical synthesis of DNA templates used
to produce mRNA drugs. DCA is the ideal reagent in this process given its purity, acid strength and ease of use.
The end-use applications of oligonucleotide-based drugs are in genetic diseases and next-gen cancer treatments
(Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

Historically, DCA experienced a growth of more than 100% CAGR between 2019 and 2022. DCA is a niche
market with €15-20 million in market value as of 2022, and with an estimated market value CAGR of 20% to
65% between 2022 and 2027 (depending upon underlying assumptions, specifically on the performance of the
key commercial product on the market). Overall, the pure DCA market is expected to outgrow the underlying
market for oligonucleotide-based drugs, as DCA is a main component of blockbuster products as well as other
promising drugs in the research and development pipeline. In a conservative case, the DCA market is expected to
grow at a CAGR of approximately 20-30% until 2027, assuming limited contributions from the key commercial
product and new blockbuster drugs as well as some price decline. In an optimistic case, assuming key product
sales grow according to global data forecasts, non-blockbuster product sales develop in line with the
oligonucleotide synthesis market (approximately 15% CAGR), and that the blockbuster drugs currently reach
commercial launch, the DCA market could grow at a CAGR of up to 60-70%, in a scenario that assumes no price
decline (Roland Berger Report).

96


-----

Key competitors in this space include Hongene, a Chinese DCA producer with limited footprint in Europe and
other Chinese players that produce DCA but focus on lower purity products. Due to the complexity of producing
high purity DCA, other Chinese players besides Hongene are predominantly focused on a lower quality and lower
purity level of production than CABB. As a result, European and U.S. distributors typically do not partner with
other Chinese manufacturers apart from Hongene due to current quality & purity profiles as of 2022 (Roland
Berger Report).

_Key Drivers_

The underlying oligonucleotide synthesis market is expected to grow significantly, primarily driven by research
and development investments and innovations. Specifically, growth in the oligonucleotide synthesis market is
expected to be driven by (1) increased government funding and research efforts to improve genomic technologies
(e.g., DNA sequencing) and develop oligonucleotide-based drugs, as well as growing demand for synthesized
oligos for use in several pharmaceutical companies’ pipeline drugs; and (2) a broadening field of applications
stemming from technical advancements that are expected to further increase importance of oligonucleotide-based
drugs (Roland Berger Report).

The DCA market is expected to outgrow the oligonucleotide synthesis market, as it is a key input of already
marketed and potentially upcoming “blockbuster” drugs (Roland Berger Report). Key drivers include: (1) CDMOs
increasing production capacity to meet growing demand from customers along with expected increases in endmarket demand for existing oligonucleotide-based drugs as they receive approvals from regulatory bodies and
reimbursement is improved; and (2) ongoing innovation in connection to oligonucleotide-based drugs leading to
the discovery of new treatments requiring DCA as raw material for their synthesis in addition to ongoing
investigation into DCA given directly as a treatment (e.g., as possible treatment for endometriosis) that will likely
lead to new areas of application and increase demand (Roland Berger Report).

**_Glycolic Acid (GA)_**

_General_

GA with ultra-high purity profiles is primarily used in skin care for various lotions and peeling products (e.g.,
anti-aging creams, facial cleansers, etc.). In 2022, GA had a market value of €50-60 million with a moderate
expected growth outlook of 3-6% CAGR between 2022 and 2027. Skin care was the largest application of GA,
accounting for around 55-65% of the overall market in 2022 and is expected to grow at a market value CAGR of
3-6% CAGR from 2022-2027. Key competitors in this space included Chemours (US), CrossChem (US) and a
number of Chinese and Indian players focused on the lower end of the quality spectrum. Chemours is the only
player that manufactures products of similar quality to those of CABB (Roland Berger Report).

_Key Drivers_

Overall, the glycolic acid market is expected to experience moderate growth until 2027, driven by usage in
personal care products, growing by 3-4% CAGR from 2022-2025 and 4-6% CAGR from 2025 to 2027. The key
drivers include: (1) rising adoption of skin care products utilizing GA as ingredient (e.g., anti-aging products) due
to its superior properties related to water holding capacity, skin hydration and skin turgor/acne removal, for which
no organic substitutes have been identified as of today; (2) growing importance of personal appearance and related
beauty products, especially in emerging markets; many products containing glycolic acid, such as moisturizers,
cleansers, acne treatment and skin lightening treatments, are in high demand; and (3) new care product
developments of (large) personal care brand owners/product manufacturers as GA remains one of the key
ingredients, especially for removal of old skin particles and skin moisturizing (Roland Berger Report).

**_CAE_**

_General_

CAE is typically a by-product from, e.g., chlorination processes and serves as a building block that can be used
in a variety of rather niche synthesis steps and has various applications. Vitamin production using CAE (CMO
process) is located in Europe while players in APAC typically use the EMO process. In the pharmaceutical sector,
CAE is used as a building block for APIs, e.g., in Cimetidine for treating GERD (Gastroesophageal reflux disease)
and in other molecules used to treat diseases of the central nervous system and cardiovascular system. CAE is
valued for its reactiveness and the high yields it produces (Roland Berger Report).

97


-----

The non-captive CAE market remains a niche market in Life Sciences with a market value of €15-20 million as
of 2022 and an expected growth outlook of 3-4% CAGR between 2022 and 2027 (Roland Berger Report).

It is estimated that 50-60% of the companies that require CAE produce it in-house. CAE is typically created as a
by-product of other production processes, such as chlorination. As of 2022, the expected growth projection for
CAE used in vitamins was a market value CAGR of 3-4% until 2027. Key competitors in this space include
Wacker Chemie AG (or Wacker) (Germany) and certain Asian players, such as Sinochem (China). In terms of the
end-customers’ key purchasing criteria, including customer relationships and price, there were small differences
between the major market players CABB and Wacker, and both were clearly ahead of Asian competition by all
metrics except pricing. CABB is focused on the high purity segment in which delivery reliability and price are the
most important purchasing criteria (Roland Berger Report).

_Key Drivers_

As stated above, as of 2022, the expected growth projection for CAE used as the building blocks for vitamins is
3-4% CAGR until 2027, primarily driven by the following factors: (1) rapidly developing personalized and
functional nutrition as consumer and societal expectations are set to move beyond taste and texture and awareness
of the importance of a quality nutritional profile grows. Vitamins can improve the nutritional value of both meat
and dairy alternatives. Demand is also being driven by (2) the increasing use of feed fortification since farm
animals remain an important part of the nutrition of a growing global population. Feed fortification through the
addition of vitamins can improve the lifetime performance of farm animals through benefits related to animal
health and digestion by extracting more value from the feed. Lastly, (3) a growing incidence of vitamin deficiency
observed in patients with certain diseases and an increased prevalence of these diseases is expected to augment
market growth for certain vitamins such as vitamin B6 to address autoimmune, kidney and liver diseases (Roland
Berger Report).

**Performance Materials**

**_Specialty Anhydrides_**

_General_

Within the Performance Materials market, we supply specialty anhydrides (including benzophenone
tetracarboxylic-dianhydride (BTDA), hexafluoroispropylidene diphthalic anhydride (6FDA) and electronic
performance materials (one product) to our customers. BTDA and 6FDA are used in the electronics, infrastructure
and transportation sub-markets and, more specifically, can be used as a co-monomer for preparation of polyimide
thin films used within electrical insulation and hot-gas filtration. The Electronic Performance Materials Product
are used in semi-conductors and in the laboratory space for diagnostic purposes (Roland Berger Report, Company
Information).

As of 2022, specialty anhydrides represented a global value of €180-200 million. BTDA and 6FDA constitute a
significant share of the specialty anhydrides market. All specialty anhydrides are high-value products that are
supplied into niche markets. The BTDA market is expected to grow from €25-35 million market value at a CAGR
of 3-5% until 2027 and the 6FDA market is expected to grow from €30-40 million market value at 7-8% CAGR
until 2027 (Roland Berger Report).

_Key Drivers_

The specialty anhydrides market is expected to continue growth from 2022 to 2027. Such growth is driven by
higher demand from all end markets, especially the electronics end-market due to the following drivers: (1)
growing volumes of newly purchased smart devices like phones and tablet computers, which in turn drive demand
for BTDA-based polyimide films used for electrical insulation in smart devices; (2) the expected global switch to
5G infrastructure will likely also drive the increased demand for dianhydrides like BTDA and 6FDA which are
used for polyimide-based flexible films in 5G circuitry; (3) the bioprocessing market is growing dynamically, and
thus so is 6FDA which is used for hollow fiber membranes within the single-use equipment for chemical
separation in highly acidic environments that is gaining share over previously used stainless steel equipment; (4)
the superior properties of polyimide fibers that make them an appealing material in hot-gas filtration, e.g., in waste
incineration and cement production, which is expected to experience high single-digit growth, driven by more
stringent environmental regulation, standards for flue gas filtration and CO2 reduction requirements; and (5)
growth within the transportation industry is expected to lead to increased demand for dianhydrides, as they are
used for the thermal insulation of aircraft engines and marine vessels. Although the relevant aerospace market
declined due to the COVID-19 pandemic, continuous recovery is expected until 2027 (Roland Berger Report).

**_Electronic Performance Materials Product_**

_General_

One of CABB’s products in Performance Materials which is exclusively manufactured for one customer (the
“Electronic Performance Materials Product”) is used in semiconductor production as well as in laboratory and
diagnostics applications.

As of 2022, the addressable market for the Electronic Performance Materials Product had a market value of around
approximately €80-100 million. The vast majority of this market value is represented by application in the
semiconductor industry where the Electronic Performance Materials Product is used as a plating and surface
treatment agent before the chemical vapor deposition process. The remaining portion of the addressable market
for the Electronic Performance Materials Product is represented by applications in the laboratory and diagnostics
space, where they are used for the calibration of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy of organic
solvents. Overall, the addressable market for the Electronic Performance Materials Product is expected to benefit

_Key Drivers_

As of 2022, the addressable market for the Electronic Performance Materials Product is expected to experience
strong growth of 8-10% CAGR until 2027, driven by the growing demand in the semiconductor industry and

as mobile communication devices and smart watches is increasing alongside a global rise in household income

with semiconductors being an integral part of consumer electronics; (2) electrification and growing digital

**_Sodium Hydroxide_**

We also provide sodium hydroxide (caustic soda) in our sites in Gersthofen and Pratteln and are the only producer
in Switzerland offering logistic advantages. Caustic soda is used in production of various intermediate products
as well as a wide range of end applications such as in chemicals, pulp and paper, and alumina, among others. For
example, it is used in the base feedstock for the production of various chemicals as well as in the pulping of wood
for paper production or regenerated fibers. Sodium hydroxide is also used in the water treatment process. The
volume demand for sodium hydroxide is therefore closely related to GDP development (Roland Berger Report,
Company Information).

Sodium hydroxide is a by-product of chlorine production. This allows chlorine producers to recycle the chlorine
they produce and monetize it. As it is highly commoditized, the supply chains of sodium hydroxide are relatively
short and as a result, our target market for sodium hydroxide remains mainly in Europe (Roland Berger Report,
Company Information).

Overall, the sodium hydroxide market is expected to experience positive volume growth from 2022 to 2027, and
is used in numerous end-markets, such as automotive, textile, pulp and paper and household cleaners. The price
of sodium hydroxide, on the other hand, is historically volatile and difficult to predict due to its dependency on
chlorine production and energy prices. Key indicators point towards a slight decline in 2023 and subsequent years,
though price is expected to remain above 2021 levels. For example, PVC consumption, which is the main driver
of the supply of caustic soda, is expected to grow by approximately 1% or less until 2026. Electricity price, which
is a driver of production cost, started to drop towards the end of 2022 and is expected to drop further in 2024,
though it is expected to remain higher than pre-COVID-19. Specifically, pricing of caustic soda reached an alltime high in 2022 with a yearly average of €765/t (WE spot rate), compared to a five-year average of €402/t for
2017-2022 and an average of €260/t for 2020-2021. Caustic soda prices are expected to decrease to the level of
€550-700/t in 2023, and then normalize at a longer-term average of €400-600/t from 2024 onwards (Roland Berger
Report, Company Information).

**OUR BUSINESS**

**Business Overview**

We are a leading CDMO (contract development and manufacturing organization) and fine chemistry manufacturer
with global operations, supplying customized ingredients to major players in the Western Crop Science market,
as well as high purity and high-complexity chemical ingredients to customers in the Life Science and Performance
Material markets. Our strong technology portfolio, technical know-how and execution capabilities allow us to
cover a wide spectrum of highly specialized customer needs, specifications and complexity profiles.

Headquartered in Germany, we operate a global network with six production facilities located in Pratteln
(Switzerland), Kokkola (Finland), Galena (Kansas, United States), Gersthofen (Germany), Knapsack (Germany)
and Jining, Shandong Province (China).

Our varied product portfolio is organized across two product groups: (i) Exclusives (tailor-made active ingredients
and precursors developed for individual customers on an exclusive basis (our CDMO offering)) and Specialties
(highly specialized ingredients with applications in high-margin end-markets) products and (ii) Advanced
Intermediates and Base Chemicals products (intermediate and base chemical products such as high purity
monochloroacetic acid (“MCA”), chloroacetyl chloride (“CAC1”) and caustic soda across a large purity spectrum
with multiple end-use applications).

Our products are deeply embedded into our customers’ value chains, often on a near-exclusive basis, allowing us
to be aligned in demand planning and supply chain coordination and to set up scalable manufacturing facilities
and efficient commercial production processes. The combination of our production know-how, lengthy product
development processes and contractually agreed capital expenditure contributions for some of our products
typically result in high contract renewal rates and low customer churn.

For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenue of €755.5 million and an Adjusted
EBITDA of €162.6 million (21.5% Adjusted EBITDA margin). Between 2020 and 2022, our revenue grew at
23.9% CAGR, whereas our Adjusted EBITDA grew at 20.0% CAGR. Exclusives and Specialties contributed to
56.8% of our revenue for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 whereas Advanced Intermediates and Base
Chemicals accounted for 43.2% of our revenue for the same period.

Our products are used for end-market applications mainly in: (i) Crop Science (e.g., herbicides, fungicides,
insecticides and other livestock and crop protection products), (ii) Life Science (e.g., pharma, personal care,
nutrition, fragrances and flavor applications) and (iii) Performance Materials (e.g., curatives in epoxies,
polyimides, polyesters and other resin systems used for electronic components, semiconductors and for
composites, fibers, films, and foams that provide heat and electrical resistance). These end-markets, in particular
Crop Science, have shown resilient historical growth rates and benefit from structural mega-trends that are
expected to drive further resilient growth in the near- to mid-term, such as increasing demand for food and need
for increased farming yields on the one hand, and an aging population and improving living standards on the other.
In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of our products were used in the
Crop Science market, approximately 20% in the Life Science market, approximately 15% in the Performance
Materials market and approximately 15% relate to others (e.g., base chemicals and industrial MCA) (measured as
a percentage of revenues).

Exclusives, our CDMO offering, provides tailor-made active ingredients and precursors tailored to individual
customer specifications in Crop Science and are a primary contributor to our overall profitability. Based on
customer-developed IP, these products require customized production lines, expansive know-how and close
cooperation with our customers. We offer development and manufacturing services for proprietary products on
an exclusive and confidential basis to leading players in the Crop Science market such as: BASF, Bayer, Corteva
and Syngenta, and we have relationships with nearly all major players in the Western Crop Science market.

Our Specialties offering consists of specialty ingredients that leverage our considerable manufacturing expertise
to create complex chemical products that serve specific customer needs across a variety of applications in the
Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials industries. Unlike Exclusives, these products can be
offered to multiple customers at a time. Our offering highlights our excellent production capabilities and knowhow along with our ability to offer specialized technology process and development services which allows us to
continuously provide high-quality and purity products to our customers and which we believe is a key
differentiator in this field. Our Specialties products are also a strong contributor to profitability, leveraging our
close client relationship and high customer “stickiness”. In particular, we offer high value-add products for fast

growing applications in Life Science (pharma and personal care as well as nutrition) and Performance Materials
markets (coatings, e.g., in electronics or other industrial applications), backed by several attractive long-term

Specialties products include players such as Agilent Technologies, Bayer, Corteva, Deciem/Estee Lauder, DSM,

In our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group, we offer intermediate and base chemical

**Our Strengths**

**_Structurally growing end-markets and increasing outsourcing trends_**

Our underlying key end-markets (Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials) are enjoying strong and
resilient underlying growth, further supported by increasing outsourcing trends that are reinforcing demand for
our Crop Science CDMO offering.

In the financial year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 70% of our revenue was generated in the Crop
Science and Life Science markets (estimate based on internal company assessments), the majority of which
consists of our CDMO offering through our Exclusives products and to a smaller degree of contributions from
our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals products. As a result, growth in the underlying Crop Science
and Life Science markets, specifically within CDMO products and novel advanced intermediates, represent key
growth levers for our business.

_Crop Science_

Our addressable CDMO Crop Science market grew by 9% to 10% CAGR between 2019 and 2022, outperforming
the underlying global market for Crop Science products which grew by approximately 8% CAGR during the same
period (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor). Market research indicates continued growth until 2027 with
respect to both our addressable CDMO Crop Science market (4% to 5% CAGR from 2022 to 2027) and the
underlying global market for Crop Science products (2% CAGR) (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor). For
more information on the specific historical and projected growth of the addressable CDMO Crop Science and
underlying global Crop Science markets, see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺General.”

The growth in the underlying global Crop Science market in particular is underpinned by the following megatrends (see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺Key Drivers” for a more detailed overview) (Roland
Berger Report, AgbioInvestor):

    - Growing population: global population growth drives demand for food and crops; and

    - Decreasing arable land: arable land per capita is decreasing, requiring efficient crop protection
products to increase farming yields.

These market dynamics are further supported by several specific trends in the addressable CDMO Crop Science
market, including (see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺Key Drivers” for a more detailed overview)
(Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor, Company Information):

    - Growth in CDMO outsourcing: customers prioritizing research and development, sales and
marketing and digitalization activities and striving to reduce their capital intensity and costs (in 2022,
approximately 40% to 50% of active ingredient production by Crop Science Players was outsourced
to CDMOs);

    - Increasing complexity of active ingredient molecules: requires specialist CDMO partners with strong
technical expertise and assets fitting into global supply chains of Crop Science players; and

    - Increasingly stringent regulatory requirements: lead to higher demand for novel active ingredients,
often outsourced to CDMOs with highly efficient multi-purpose facilities.

102


-----

Furthermore, historical demand for crop protection products has proven to be resilient to adverse events
maintaining a growth trend in spite of temporary downturns. For example, declines in average crop commodity
prices (e.g., corn, wheat, soybean) caused by events such as lower pest pressure and economic recessions in
production markets such as in Brazil, and North American weather conditions in 2019 led to a temporary downturn
in the crop protection market but were followed by year-on-year increases. Furthermore, while agrochemical
production was impacted by coronavirus-related restrictions in the first quarter of 2020, it swiftly normalized
following an easing of lockdown restrictions. While the coronavirus restrictions did impact labor availability both
in terms of production and field work, many countries deemed the agricultural sector to be of considerable
importance in maintaining food security, so restrictions on movement were less severe than in most industries
(Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

The addressable market for novel active ingredients (active ingredients introduced after 2010), a subset of the
CDMO Crop Science market, is anticipating significantly higher growth rates at a CAGR of approximately 13.7%
from 2021 to 2027, owing to, among other factors, a higher outsourcing rate due to production complexity (Roland
Berger Report). Against this background, we act as a key partner for our clients in this area, supporting innovators
with our technical expertise and state-of-the-art production facilities. Our Crop Science product portfolio benefits
from a modern set of active ingredients. We are not materially involved in the production of raw materials or
finished product for glyphosate or neonicotinoids.

Our addressable Life Science markets grew between 2019 and 2022 and are expected to grow further, driven by
structural mega-trends including a global aging population and an increasing disposable income spent on personal

Information). For more information on trends driving Life Sciences growth (including niche markets), see
“Industry and Market Data⸺Life Science⸺Key Drivers.”

Individual addressable high growth sub-markets such as the oligonucleotide synthesis market (used for the

31, 2020 to €755.5 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Revenue growth in 2022 was primarily
driven by strong demand in both our product groups across the portfolio supported by higher pricing effects, in
particular partial pass-through of increased raw material prices and supply chain costs in our Advanced
Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group.

Our Adjusted EBITDA has grown at a CAGR of 20.0% from €112.9 million for the financial year ended
December 31, 2020 to €162.6 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The significant growth in
Adjusted EBITDA in 2022 in particular was due to an increase in pricing resulting in a higher margin for our
products from customers in our Exclusives and Specialties business as well as positive pricing effects in our
Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals business.

**_Backward-integrated model that enables re-use of by-products and reduction of waste_**

Increasing operational efficiency is a top priority for us as it provides clear benefits. When these benefits are
combined, they create a virtuous cycle by minimizing negative environmental impacts, creating cost advantages
in production, driving innovation and enabling our long-term competitiveness.

Production processes always result in byproducts. We aim to reuse or commercialize such byproducts wherever
feasible and avoid waste wherever possible. To this end, we believe we operate a highly efficient circular economy
processes and we eliminate waste by developing highly efficient processes with optimized product yields and
reusing materials within production cycles. Besides the environmental and sustainability advantages, this type of
closed-loop system also has tangible financial benefits, as it can reduce costs for raw materials and waste
treatments. In Pratteln, we are contributing to the creation of a circular economy using a “Verbund System”. This
enables highly efficient and sustainable chlorination and sulfonation reactions. Chlorine and sulfur trioxide are
produced as primary raw materials and used to manufacture a variety of chlorination and sulfonation reagents. In
turn, these are used to produce further downstream intermediates and active ingredients. The HCl and SO2
generated as off-gases are separated, purified and recycled, reused or resold.

Finally, our production sites benefit from high supply chain resilience through backward integration of key raw
materials and production processes for our Exclusives and Specialties Products (by using our Advanced
Intermediates production). In particular, our main multi-purpose plant in Pratteln uses an innovative set-up that
offers high efficiency production of Exclusives and Specialties products, based on backwards integration of the
key raw materials of chlorine. Together with the supply of large volumes of necessary MCA from our sites in
Germany, we can therefore contribute to supply resilience, as we are in control of the relevant production steps
and at the same time can manage the direct commercialization of side streams generated in the production
processes, which are then sold as Base Chemicals. See “⸺Production Facilities.” We benefit from close
proximity to our customers’ main production sites in the Western markets and we focus on developing and
maintaining strong logistic capabilities to enable seamless fulfillment and integration in the respective customer’s
supply chain. The chart below shows our production site locations around the world and our production

**Our Strategy**

The following is a summary of the activities we are currently undertaking in pursuit of these opportunities:

**_Deliver excellence in production to optimize profitability_**

We are focused on further developing our project portfolio and aim to add more high-value projects to our
portfolio each year, keeping in line with our historical project win rates. Our established market position in
Exclusives serves as the backbone of our strategy by continuously driving resilient growth and margin stability,
complemented by high growth in existing niche markets in Specialties and further supported by fundamental
market trends. We are dedicated to continue focusing on novel active ingredients and high-value products,
expanding our distribution and geographical reach in our Life Science applications and focusing on high-purity
and higher margin segments in Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals for attractive contracts with
increasing capacity. We aim to further increase our operational excellence by focusing on efficiency,
strengthening key account and sales functions, ramp-ups of additional capacities and continuous de-bottlenecking,
as well as fostering our commercial excellence by winning new customers from large, less reliable competitors in
the MCA business.

**_Deliver de-risked capacity and technology expansion_**

We will continue to strengthen our strategic positioning in Exclusives and Specialties by focusing on novel active
ingredients and investments in state-of-the-art technologies. We believe that we can benefit from a ramp-up in a
number of contracted and already invested projects across Exclusives and Specialties products with contractual
‘take-or-pay’ or exclusivity clauses which are underpinned by a well invested asset base that, as a result,
significantly reduces the risks associated with their execution. We expect to additionally benefit from leveraging
partial cost pass-through mechanisms in future contracts. Consequently, we believe our business is highly resilient
and that the predictable customer demand for our CDMO and other highly specialized products offers high
visibility on the underlying product lifecycle and returns for a certain part of the portfolio.

**_Strong focus on client relationships and varied commercial capabilities_**

We are dedicated to winning new projects by leveraging our long-standing relationships with our blue chip
customer base as well as our know-how and reputation as a trusted Western CDMO Crop Science business partner
to accelerate and win new contracts as proven in the past. In addition, we plan to further increase our Specialties
revenue through a push of our attractive portfolio to additional geographies and customers expanding the volume
of our high margin products.

Furthermore, as some of our main customer relationships exceed 15 years, we have established ourselves as a key
outsourcing partner with trusted supplier status for our clients worldwide who often return to extend existing
projects or to collaborate with us on potential new products. As a result, we have very low customer churn,
particularly for our Exclusives and Specialties offering, and our top customers work with us for a multitude of
individual products. We will continue to strengthen those long-standing customer relationships by working closely
with our customers to meet their volume and specification needs for their existing and new products. We intend
to expand our production capacity to meet the growing demand of our key customers, continue to optimize our
production processes to share efficiency gains and work closely with them to tailor our production processes to
new products.

We intend to continue to focus on multinational customers and industry leaders, in an effort to benefit from strong
innovation and global market penetration opportunities. By further strengthening our relationships with
multinational customers who have leading market positions in their industries, we seek to grow with them as they
expand their businesses. The introduction of OneCABB has allowed us to further streamline our customers
primary points of contact with us and will, we believe, contribute to even stronger customer relationships.

**_Develop and further expand into additional markets_**

We remain focused on targeted capacity expansion to capture growing demand and additional production volumes
that our customers seek to outsource to us, in line with new growth projects of our customers. Jayhawk, located

offer the potential for standalone growth from its existing pipeline portfolio and production of new products, as

**_Maintain focus on profitability and cash flow_**

We will continue to focus on improving our profitability through cost savings and efficiency enhancements where
possible, such as investments in energy saving measures, footprint optimization and automatization. We believe
that there is an ongoing potential for efficiency measures through continuous optimization of our manufacturing
processes and recycling streams. We intend to seek to further improve cash flow generation by maximizing the

**_Maintain health, safety and environmental excellence_**

We are committed to a strategy of ESG and sustainability based on environmentally responsible manufacturing

**Our History**

109


-----

Our business has its origins in the chemical production activities of Hoechst AG, which originally commissioned
our production facility in Gersthofen, Germany, in 1905 as well as our production facility in Knapsack, Germany,
in 1949. In 1997, the Hoechst Specialty Chemicals business was acquired by Clariant. Several years later, in 2003,
the CABB Group GmbH was founded as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Clariant before being acquired by an
Investment Management in 2005 and then by AXA Private Equity in the following year.

In 2007, we acquired SF Chem, including our production facility in Pratteln, Switzerland, which allowed us to
expand into contract manufacturing. In 2011, we were acquired by Bridgepoint; that same year we acquired
KemFine from 3i and commenced production at our facility in Kokkola, Finland, to further expand our contract
manufacturing capabilities.

In 2013, we expanded our footprint to Asia through the establishment of a joint venture with Jining Jinwei Gold
Power to acquire Jinwei Huasheng Chemicals. We hold a 67% stake in the joint venture entity CABB-Jinwei
Specialty Chemicals (Jining) Co., Ltd.

In 2014, we were acquired by the Permira Funds and have since invested in an electrolysis plant in Pratteln,
capacity expansions and de-bottlenecking in most facilities as well as in a new wastewater facility in China.

In 2019, we acquired Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals Corporation, one of the leading fine chemicals companies
in the U.S., from Evonik Industries AG.

In 2021, we introduced OneCABB, which combined our legacy business units into one integrated company to
flatten the organizational structure and drive efficiencies across functions.

**_Exclusives and Specialties_**

Exclusives and Specialties consist of high-value products we offer to our Crop Science and Life Science clients
that fully leverage our experience and technical capabilities. Exclusive products include tailor-made solutions for
proprietary and innovative active ingredients as well as specialty ingredients and derivatives. Exclusives and
Specialties products accounted for €429.3 million or 56.8% of our revenue for the financial year ended December
31, 2022 (2021: €367.3 million or 62.4%; 2020: €312.2 million or 63.4%).

_Exclusives_

Exclusives, our CDMO portfolio, consists of mainly products used as active ingredients or intermediates in the
Crop Science industry. Underpinning our clear focus on the Crop Science market segment, we manufacture
customized active ingredients on an exclusive and confidential basis for our customers and specialize in complex
multi-stage processing and quality assurance. Our active ingredients are produced to match our individual
customers’ specifications with regard to both their production systems and end product requirements (one
customer, one product). These products are usually based on customer-developed IP and thus are tailored, highly
complex and technically challenging active ingredients.

The active ingredients as well as complex building blocks we produce are used by our customers primarily for
herbicides for corn, cotton and sugarcane and insecticides and fungicides for a broad range of applications. We
currently manufacture approximately 30 different exclusives for use in agricultural and Crop Science applications,
representing a significant driver for our sales and profitability growth. In addition to the Crop Science market, our

110


-----

exclusive custom synthesis products are manufactured for applications in certain specialty end-markets (e.g.,
animal health).

To create these exclusive products, we develop long-term projects and contracts with most of our customers for a
large part of our portfolio, characterized initially by capital expenditure commitments or ‘take-or-pay’ clauses to
design the custom production facilities required as well as long-term purchase commitments from the customers,
providing attractive return profiles. See also “—Our product portfolio.”

We contractually obtain customer lock-in from their co-investment in capex or ‘take-or-pay’ clauses, and our
customers benefit from our differentiating process know-how. Our multi-year contracts give us high visibility on
the underlying product lifecycle and returns for a large part of our portfolio. We serve as the sole supplier for
many of our exclusives customers, and our contracts with these customers emphasize volume commitments and/or
‘take-or pay’ clauses particularly at their start. Within our multi-purpose plants we maintain a well-balanced
offering across crops and active ingredient types and remain relatively insulated from seasonal fluctuations in
demand for any particular crop. We are not materially involved in the production of raw materials or finished
product for glyphosate or neonicotinoids.

We operate three production facilities capable of producing tailor made products in Exclusives: one in Pratteln,
Switzerland, one in Kokkola, Finland and one in Galena, Kansas, United States. See “—Production Facilities.”

_Specialties_

Our Specialty portfolio comprises ingredients for Life Science (in particular DCA, GA and CAE) and Performance
Materials (in particular BTDA) and targets market segments with expected high customer value-add and growth
potential. These include a variety of end-market applications in Life Science including starting materials for
innovative pharmaceuticals, actives for cosmetics, building blocks for nutrition supplements and food and
beverage ingredients as well as applications in Performance Materials (e.g., for mobile electronic devices and
semiconductors). Our products are based on our differentiating technology platforms and our deep understanding
of customer application requirements contributing to a strong customer lock-in.

We are a leading supplier in the Western world for highly profitable Specialties. Our leading quality levels of our
products also provide for further expansion opportunities in Asia. We obtain customer lock-in as a result of our
differentiating portfolio for niche applications.

For innovative pharmaceuticals, ultra-pure Dichloroacetic Acid (DCA) and Trichloroacetic Acid (TCA) (both of
which we produce) are used as a critical starting material for the production of oligonucleotides which are used
for novel RNAi based pharmaceuticals, e.g., antisense RNA or small interfering RNA (siRNA). We are the global
market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high purity grade DCA (a key ingredient for RNA-based
medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications (by high purity DCA revenue as of 2022) (Roland
Berger Report, Company Information).

For cosmetic applications, Glycolic acid (GA) is one of our other primary ingredients with a differentiating purity
profile. Due to its capability to penetrate skin, glycolic acid has many applications as an active ingredient in skin
care and personal care with main applications in anti-aging products such as face masks and peels. In cosmetic
grade GA, we are globally the second largest supplier (measured by revenue as of 2022) and the only European
producer with global coverage (Company assessment based on the Roland Berger Report).

For nutrition supplements and food & beverage ingredients, our portfolio comprises building blocks for the
production of vitamins, e.g., vitamin B6, as well as acetates which are used as a buffering agent in various
industrial applications and as a preservative or flavor enhancer in the food industry. We maintain a leading market
position in the production of CAE (the building blocks for vitamins) due to our strong relationships with key
customers (Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

In Performance Materials, we supply dianhydrides in a variety of end-markets, including in the semiconductor
production and mobile devices including 5G and smart devices, as well as high performance materials for
engineering applications, such as those used in fibers for hot gas filtration and for acoustic and thermal insulations.
With regards to one of the Performance Materials applications products we produce, BTDA, we are the only large
scale ultrapure producer with production footprint in the United States (Roland Berger Report, Company
Information).

We operate three production facilities capable of producing Specialties: one in Pratteln, Switzerland, one in
Gersthofen, Germany and one in Galena, Kansas, United States. See “—Production Facilities.”

**_Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals_**

Intermediates are chemical products that require significant expertise and technical equipment to manufacture,
which are not produced for one specific customer but have multiple applications across many end-markets and
are suitable to many use cases. Intermediates are used in crop protection as well as in pharmaceutical, Life Science
and specialized applications such as automotive and detergents. Our Advanced Intermediates offering is
predominantly focused on personal care and nutrition within Life Science.

Our portfolio comprises mainly monochloroacetic acids (MCA), acid chlorides and chlorine-based products as
well as selected base chemicals as by-products generated from our chlor-alkali electrolysis and chlorination
processes. Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals are produced in highly efficient large-scale production
assets in our facilities in Gersthofen and Knapsack, Germany, and in Pratteln, Switzerland as well as in China
through our joint venture with Shandong Lutai Chemical Co., Ltd. (formerly Jining Jinwei Gold Power Co., Ltd.).
In Knapsack we produce Advanced Intermediates based on a close relationship with a chlorine supplier within
the same industrial park.

Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals accounted for €326.2 million or 43.2% of our revenue for the
financial year ended December 31, 2022 (2021: €221.7 million or 37.6%; 2020: €180.1 million or 36.6%).

_Advanced Intermediates_

Our Advanced Intermediates portfolio comprises MCA, acid chlorides and chlorine-based products as key product
groups.

MCA is a key building block for the organic synthesis of ingredients in crop protection applications, Life Sciences,
pharmaceuticals as well as in chemical products. We offer customers the full MCA portfolio spanning across all
relevant MCA grades up to ultra-pure qualities as well as all relevant formulations such as solutions, melt and
MCA salts (SMCA). Our production facilities benefit from state-of-the-art hydrogenation technology. We are one
of the largest European Life Science MCA suppliers (measured by production volume in Europe as of 2022). A
significant share of our MCA product is produced for captive demand from certain MCA derivatives in the Life
Science business. MCA is further used for (captive) Crop Science demand in Exclusives and Specialties business
(Roland Berger, Company Information).

Our acid chlorides and chlorine-based products portfolio includes products such as chloroacetyl chloride (CAC1)
which is used in crop protection applications as well as in pharmaceutical applications (e.g., pain relievers) and
various additional acid chlorides and chlorides products which are used in agrochemical synthesis and are also
applied in the synthesis of organic peroxides, car tires, sizing agents, flavor and fragrance, high blood pressure
medications, antibiotics and animal feed stock additives.

_Base Chemicals_

Our chlor-alkali electrolysis processes (used to create key precursors for our Exclusives and Specialties products
as well as the advanced intermediates) yields two main co-products: chlorine and caustic soda. In various
chlorination processes, chlorine is partially utilized in the process and with the remainder being transformed into
hydrogen chloride and hydrochloric acid as solution. We increase our efficiency by selling the caustic soda,
hydrochloric acid and other co-products we cannot recycle back into our production processes to third-party
customers.

Sales of caustic soda are typically made to customers and other third parties through distributors, with the majority
of purchasers located within 300 kilometers of our Gersthofen and Pratteln sites due to transportation costs. The
market is partially protected as logistics costs limit longer distance shipping. In Switzerland, where we are the
only producer of caustic soda, we sell a substantial part of our base products via pipeline to tenants of the
Schweizerhalle industrial cluster based on long-term contracts, offering superior supply reliability.

**Product Applications**

Our product portfolio has a number of applications across our major end-markets, Crop Science, Life Science and
Performance Materials and the growth of these underlying addressable markets is a contributing factor to our
results.

**_Uses for our products in Crop Science_**

In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of our products were used in the
Crop Science market (measured as a percentage of revenues).

Chemicals we produce are used by our clients to develop herbicides protecting multiple crops including maize,
soybean, sunflower, sugarcane and fruits and vegetables. As a result we maintain an offering across crops and we
have benefited in parts of our portfolio from the decrease in some existing generics under regulatory and public
scrutiny by producing replacement products. We are not materially involved in the production of raw materials or
finished product for glyphosate or neonicotinoids.

**_Uses for our products in Life Science_**

In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 20% of our products were used in the Life
Science market (measured as a percentage of revenues). We believe that the addressable markets for our products
within Life Science will grow until 2027 due to featured noteworthy developments in specific segments with high
demand, such as: novel RNA therapeutics, vitamins and supplements as well as rising adoption in skin care
products as detailed below.

_RNA-based Pharma Applications_

We are a leading Dichloroacetic acid (or DCA) producer used for RNA and oligonucleotide applications, with
DCA being an essential input for the production of RNA from DNA. DCA helps to synthesize nucleic acids that
are then used in numerous therapeutic active pharmaceutical ingredients in various phases of clinical trials and
few products already in commercial stage (Roland Berger, Company Information).

The DCA market is highly differentiated by its level of purity and through our state-of-the-art facilities, we are
able to produce the highest purity levels and managed to fulfill the emergent demand for DCA in 2020, 2021 and
2022. Main RNA-based market growth drivers are investments in research and development to improve genomic
technologies as well as the broadening the field of application (e.g. “oligonucleotide therapeutics”). As a result of
further uses of DCA in the chemical synthesis of oligonucleotides and broader commercial application of the
therapeutics, the addressable market is forecasted to grow by a wide range between 2022 and 2027 (Roland Berger,
Company Information). For more information on projected growth and key market drivers, see “Industry and
_Market Data⸺Life Science⸺General⸺DCA” and “Industry and Market Data⸺Life Science⸺General⸺DCA_
_Key Drivers.”_

_Building blocks for vitamins_

Our product CAE is used as the basis for Vitamin B6 synthesis used, for example, for nutrition. The vitamins
market is estimated to grow between 2022 and 2027 (3% to 4% market value CAGR). Key drivers that support
this growth include: (i) an increased focus on preventative health care; (ii) a rise of personalized and functional
nutrition; and (iii) the use of vitamins in animal food (Roland Berger).

_Skin care_

We are a key supplier of high purity Glycolic Acid for fast-growing skin care applications, e.g., anti-aging and
deep facial cleansers, with the market for skincare products expected to grow between 2022 and 2027 (market
value CAGR of 3% to 4% from 2022 to 2025 and 4% to 6% from 2025 to 2027). Key drivers that support this
growth include: (i) a rising focus on personal appearance and related beauty products, particularly in the emerging
markets; (ii) new care product developments of personal care players; and (iii) a continued usage of Glycolic Acid
in personal care products (e.g. anti-age products) in combination with an aging population (Roland Berger).

_Personal care, packaged food & pharma_

We are one of the largest European Life Science MCA suppliers (by production volume in Europe as of 2022).
The personal care market is expected to grow between 2022 and 2027 (4% to 5% market CAGR by volume in k
tons). Key drivers that support this growth include: (i) a higher demand for hygiene products due to increasing
awareness for hygiene and cleanliness as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic; (ii) changing consumer preferences
from solid to liquid products; and (iii) the continued usage of CMC as a thickening agent or stabilizer in food and
beverages (Roland Berger).

**_Uses for our products in Performance Materials_**

In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 15% of our products were used in the
Performance Materials market (measured as a percentage of revenues). Performance materials are used in the
creation of curatives in epoxies, polyimides, polyesters and other resin systems. These products have multiple
applications such as the coating and protection of electronic components as well as in producing composites and
adhesives, with common uses in electronic components, semiconductors, electric motor components and industrial
coating. Furthermore, Performance Materials created with our products include composites, fibers, films, and
foams that provide heat and electrical resistance and stability under aggressive conditions. End-uses of such
Performance Materials include, among others: flexible printed circuitry and foldable displays for smart devices,
composite components for automotive and aviation, thermal insulation for aircraft and marine vessels, coatings
and tubing for medical devices and radiation shielding for spacecraft.

Our products cater to the niche applications in mobile electronics, transportation and green energy. Specifically,
we supply (i) certain dianhydrides (BTDA and 6FDA) and (ii) one product which eventually goes into the
semiconductor end-market.

Moreover, BTDA is used for numerous applications in electronics, infrastructure and transportation with limited
competition. With regards to BTDA, we are the only large scale ultrapure producer with production footprint in
the United States (Roland Berger). For more information on growth rates and key drivers, see “Industry and
_Market Data⸺Performance Materials⸺Specialty Anhydrides⸺General” and “Industry and Market_
_Data⸺Performance Materials⸺Electronic Performance Materials Product⸺General.”_

**_Uses for our products in Base Chemicals_**

In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 15% of our products were used in Base
Chemicals (measured as a percentage of revenues, includes MCA used across industries for further refinement).
Base Chemicals are produced as by-products generated from our chlor-alkali electrolysis and chlorination
processes and primarily consist of two main products: chlorine and sodium hydroxide (caustic soda). Caustic soda
is used in the production of various other intermediate products, for example, in chemicals to manufacture organic
chemicals as a dehydrochlorinating agent, catalyst or neutralization agent (Roland Berger). We believe that caustic
soda demand is structurally outgrowing production capacities in Europe due to various technology shifts. Enduses of such Base Chemicals include, among others, the pulp and paper and alumina industry. For more
information on growth rates and key drivers, see “Industry and Market Data⸺Sodium Hydroxide.”

**Our Product Portfolio**

Our Exclusives and Specialties business model is built around a strong product portfolio of customer orders and
long-term projects for a large part of our portfolio, supporting high visibility of the underlying product lifecycle
and returns. We generate a significant amount of our Group’s profitability from our CDMO activities in the
Exclusives product group through long-term projects for our customers. To a smaller extent, our Specialties
contracts are also a strong contributor to profitability.

In Exclusives, we also benefit from de-risked growth capex investments as customers contribute to the capex
required to set up productions (e.g., co-investment undertakings by customer or ‘take-or-pay’ commitments). This
also adds to such customers’ switching costs and helps create long lasting relations due to our integration in their
supply chain and generally results in very low customer churn and high contract renewal rates for our Exclusives
products.

**_Project selection and Tender process_**

We try to closely manage our project tenders and open offers, prioritizing large-scale growth projects for our
Exclusives products and advantageous Specialties contracts. As a result, we regularly review our open tenders as
well as ongoing projects against key investment metrics, checking if our production capacity is used effectively.

Between 2020 and 2022, we received approximately 200 project inquiries across all our business operations
(Exclusives, Specialties and Advanced Intermediates). After evaluating the individual characteristics of each
potential project, 13 potential projects were further developed in the same period through to the offer stage, where
we tender an offer for a given customer product. In the selection process, we benefit from a proven reliability
record and trusted supplier status in the market, underpinned by our strong technology and execution capabilities
as well as standout client services. We believe these act as distinguishing factors in the tender process, particularly
when compared to competitors in Western and Asian markets.

-----

Over the last three years, we have established a track record of consistent project wins (at least one major 1[st]
campaign project per year), building upon our deep integration into our customers’ value chains and our reputation
of reliability and ability to manage complex processes. In the same period, we generally signed an additional one
to two other Exclusive or Specialties products contracts to further strengthen utilization and returns of our installed
asset base with limited investment requirements.

**_Key targets for investment criteria and capex requirements applicable to our CDMO Exclusives projects_**

Tailor-made products based on customer-developed IP require custom-built production lines and close
cooperation with our customers to achieve the requested quality, volume and product specification. This requires
significant ramp-up times and costs to set-up appropriate production lines and processes. We contractually commit
to such long-term projects (under contractual frameworks) for a large part of our portfolio with the expectation
that we will recover our initial investments in the short-term and achieve attractive returns and profitability growth
in the mid- to long-term. If we successfully find projects that match our targeted key investment criteria, we stand
to benefit from increased profitability and visibility on the underlying product lifecycle and returns.

We aim to find projects that allow an EBITDA pay-back of our capex investment in approximately three years
from the start of production. To achieve this, we seek a minimum contractual length for CDMO projects in
Exclusives, as well as include other mechanisms (e.g., co-investments by customers) to ensure the recovery of our
capex. Our customers cover part of our incurred capex either through initial co-investments or through ‘take-orpay’ clauses committing our customers’ to minimum purchase volumes and prices. This co-investment helps
integrate our services into our customers’ value chains and adds to their potential cost to switch suppliers, which
generally drives very-high project renewal rates. Our typical CDMO contract models follow one of two contract
templates: we either engage in CDMO contracts featuring a facility fee, where customers take on a share of the
initial capex investment and our project margins are in line with market levels or, as an alternative, we provide
CDMO contracts featuring an offtake arrangement, where the initial capex investment is largely funded by us and
our desired return profile is achieved through ‘take-or pay’ contract provisions. As a result, the customer has a
limited capex commitment upfront but through a firm offtake arrangement, the customer commits to purchase a
certain amount of our future output for an extended period (typically five years). These CDMO contracts usually
feature higher product margins to compensate for our larger upfront capex commitment and are oftentimes
renewed before the end of their initial term.

Furthermore, before committing our capacity to a given long-term project, we try to assess the projected internal
rate of return (IRR) of each new project over the span of its predicted lifecycle, and aim to select advantageous
returns (IRR targets of 25%). While this is not achieved in all our projects, we aim to strengthen our product
portfolio over time with projects that either match our key criteria or otherwise offer strategic opportunities.

**_Product Portfolio Visibility_**

Due to contractual commitments and yearly purchase schedules, we have a strong visibility over the underlying
product lifecycle and returns of a large part of our Exclusives products.

As of March 31, 2023, we also had 14 projects in varying ramp-up phases, which are expected to contribute to
our revenue and profitability growth in the short to medium term.

Our Knapsack site located near Cologne, Germany, has been in production since 1949 and covers approximately

via pipeline under a supply agreement from our supplier’s adjacent facilities. The facility has a two-line production
process, which allows for maintenance and repair activities, and produces multiple purity grades of MCA as liquid,
solutions and flakes.

Our Gersthofen site, situated in the Gersthofen Industrial Park located approximately 60 kilometers northwest of

**Sources and Availability of Raw Materials**

Some of our customer contracts by sales include price formulas that allow for partial pass-through of price
variations in acetic acid and acetic anhydride. These pass-through provisions help to limit significant fluctuations
in our cost of sales but often include a time lag. The remaining revenue from the sale is contracted at spot prices
that reflect current prices for raw materials, which mitigates our exposure to fluctuations in raw materials prices.

For tailor-made products, raw materials for production are provided by our customers or, where we are responsible
for the procurement of raw materials, our customer contracts may include pass-through clauses for raw materials,
thereby providing a certain degree of protection from fluctuations in prices of raw materials.

Purchases of raw materials primarily consist of acetic acid, acetic anhydride, chlorine and energy. The chlorine
production process based on chlor-alkali electrolysis at our Gersthofen and Pratteln production facilities requires

significant amounts of electricity. At our Knapsack plant, we purchase chlorine via pipeline pursuant to a supply
contract from Vinnolit, whose chlorine production facility is adjacent to ours. Similarly, our joint venture in China
sources its chlorine requirements from our joint venture partner, who operates an adjacent chlorine production
facility.

As part of our quality control management procedures, we maintain long-term relationships with suppliers for
large parts of the portfolio. We also conduct ongoing performance assessment and benchmarking as part of our
supplier selection process. In the event of supply shortages, we may seek to purchase raw materials or other
products from our competitors. From time to time, we also enter into product swap agreements with key
competitors to guarantee that our customers can be supplied at all times, even during facility maintenance or
turnarounds. While temporary shortages of raw materials could occasionally occur, we generally have access to
sufficient raw materials to cover current and projected requirements.

Our distribution and logistics team is responsible for organizing and coordinating the delivery of products to our

We serve customers through three distribution models: (i) bulk shipments mainly via tank container and rail cars,
(ii) packaged goods (e.g., coated drums, big bags, etc.,) and (iii) via pipeline.

For bulk shipments, we currently have a large in-house managed leased fleet covering tank containers and railcars
to transport demanding materials (e.g., melts, corrosive liquids) to our customers. We provide state-of-the-art
supply solutions to our customers through GPS tracking of shipments and a modern container fleet, including our
leased titanium railcars for transporting MCA which are 40% lighter than regular railcars and can capture 30%
more product volumes.

For packaged goods, we also supply customers with, for example, coated drums and super sacks. We operate
semi-automated drum filling lines in our product sites in Pratteln and Gersthofen to target high margin niche
segments mainly for Advanced Intermediates and Specialties as well as in semi-automated filling lines for MCA
flakes and salts in big bags and super sacks at our plants in Gersthofen and Knapsack.

For pipeline customers, we distribute Base Chemicals to customers adjacent to our production sites mainly in

**_Environmental_**

We consider environmental protection and sustainability to be one of the pillars of our ESG strategy. We

We are constantly working on solutions to reduce energy consumption and to optimize energy efficiency, in

specialized measures such as optimized energy usage in distillation, energy-efficient technology for chloralkali
electrolysis or measuring energy consumption more accurately with software are helping us to reduce the amount

We believe we operate a highly efficient circular economy production processes and by optimizing product yields
and reusing materials within product cycles. For example, the raw materials used in our “Verbund” plant in our
site in Pratteln, chlorine and sulfur trioxide, are not only used to manufacture chlorination and sulfonation
reagents, but also to produce further downstream intermediates and active ingredients. The “Verbund” plant
enables the separation of the off-gases HCI and SO2 which are separated, purified and recycled, reused or sold.

Our sites undergo regular audits by Eco-Vadis, the world’s largest provider of sustainability ratings. In the latest
ratings conducted in 2022, our site in Kokkola was awarded the platinum rating and our site in Pratteln
(Switzerland) as well as the sites in Germany and China were awarded with the gold rating. As part of the audit
report, EcoVadis also provides valuable input on areas in which CABB can continue to improve, and we have
developed strategies and set key targets to achieve these possible improvements.

Operationally, we are employing the newest technology to improve efficiency. The acquisition of new
compressors at the German Knapsack site in May 2021 is another example of how we are using energy in a more
targeted manner. Compressed air generation is now distributed between two smaller compressors instead of one
central machine. Before, all the air used to be compressed to the highest pressure required and then depressurized
for other processes, now however, compressed air can be generated directly at the requisite pressure level as
needed. This reduces the energy consumption by around 30% in the relevant processes. Another tool at our
disposal is the use of even more energy efficient technology. For example, as part of a planned overhaul at the
turn of 2019/20220, the electrolysis plants at the German Gersthofen site were upgraded to the latest technology,
allowing the membranes to be positioned between the electrodes without any spacing (“zero-gap technology”),
with the resulting higher current densities between the electrodes driving significant improvement in electrical
efficiency. We are also focusing on renewables with our Finnish Kokkola plant being fully powered by
hydroelectricity since January 2020. On the other side, our USA Jayhawk plant sources 40% of its electricity from
regionally generated wind energy. Most recently, we committed to invest into a CO2 neutral office building in our
site in Kokkola and further committed to reduce our absolute CO2 emissions (Scope 1 and 2) by 30 ktons by 2025
(against 2019 baseline).

**REGULATION, ENVIRONMENTAL, HEALTH AND SAFETY MATTERS**

**Overview**

Our business is subject to numerous laws, rules and regulations at supranational, national, state and municipal
levels as well as technical and management standards in all of the jurisdictions in which we operate.

We expect that, in many of the countries in which we do business, the applicable laws, rules and regulations,
including environmental laws and regulations, will become more comprehensive and stringent over time. We
further expect that many environmental laws and regulations will continue to be harmonized at the EU level over
the near-to-medium-term. Member states will, however, remain free to adopt laws and regulations that are more
stringent than those required by the European Union. The failure to comply with these laws and regulations may
result in civil liability, fines or even criminal sanctions.

As the applicable regulatory framework and technical standards are subject to revision and continuous
development, it is very difficult to accurately predict the future cost of compliance with such regulatory
requirements and technical standards. Additional or more stringent laws, rules, regulations and technical standards
could increase our costs or limit our ability to continue our business operations in the same manner as we have
done in the past. See “Risk Factors.”

The following provides only a brief overview of certain selected areas of regulation applicable to our business
operations.

**Regulation Relating to our Business**

**_Regulation of Chemicals European Union_**

REACH

The manufacturing, handling, use and trading of chemicals is regulated in the EU and its member states. The EU
requires control of the use of chemical products within its borders, requiring all affected industries to ensure and
demonstrate the safe manufacture, use and disposal of chemicals. “REACH” is the Regulation concerning the
Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals (Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006), which
came into effect on June 1, 2007, and which has been fully applicable since June 1, 2009, requiring the registration
of all chemical substances or preparations manufactured in, or imported into, the EU. Its main objectives include
improving the protection of human health and the environment from the risks that can be posed by chemicals and
ensuring the free circulation of substances on the internal market of the EU.

In principle, under REACH, all manufacturers and importers of chemicals must identify and manage risks linked
to the substances they manufacture and market. For substances produced or imported in quantities of one ton or
more per year per company, manufacturers and importers need to demonstrate that they have appropriately done
so by means of a registration dossier, which shall be submitted to the European Chemicals Agency (“ECHA”).
ECHA may then check that the dossier is compliant with REACH and will evaluate testing proposals to ensure
that the proposed assessment of the chemical substances will not result in unnecessary testing, especially on
animals. Where appropriate, authorities may also select substances of concern for a broader evaluation.

REACH requires formal documentation of the relevant data required for hazard assessments for each substance
registered as well as development of risk assessments for their registered uses. Under certain circumstances, the
performance of a chemical safety assessment is mandatory and a chemical safety report assuring the safe use of
the substance must be submitted. If there is no registration of the substance, it is impermissible to produce this
chemical in, or import it into, the EU (i.e., the ‘no data no market’ principle). Existing registrations need to be
reviewed on an ongoing basis and updated with respect to new scientific knowledge. Furthermore, purchasers of
registered chemicals must inform their sellers about the intended use of the chemicals, as the importer or producer
must add this information to its documentation.

REACH also provides for an authorization system aiming to ensure that substances of very high concern are
adequately controlled and progressively substituted by safer substances or technologies or only used where society
benefits overall from using the substance. These substances are prioritized and gradually listed on the so-called
candidate list for eventual inclusion in Annex XIV to REACH. Once they are included, the industry has to submit
applications to ECHA on authorization for continued use of these substances which are otherwise prohibited. In
addition, EU authorities can impose restrictions on the manufacture, use or placing on the market of substances
causing an unacceptable risk to human health or the environment.

123


-----

Manufacturers and importers must provide their downstream users with the risk information they need to be able
to use the substance safely. This is done via the classification and labeling system and Safety Data Sheets (SDS).
Therefore, the REACH Regulation was accompanied by legislation providing for a comprehensive system on the
classification, labeling and packaging of substances and mixtures (CLP Regulation (EC) No. 1272/2008 and
related European legislation).

We produce and use considerable quantities of substances that are subject to the REACH regulation. We believe
that we have complied with our current obligations under REACH. As part of a large consortium, the Group is a
co-registrant of registrations for chlorine, glycolic acid, MCA, SMCA and sodium hypochlorite. None of our
products affected by substances of very high concern (“SVHC”) are listed in the official SVHC-List of the ECHA.

As part of the “European Green Deal”, in 2020 the European Commission announced the launch of a “Chemicals
Strategy for Sustainability” and a “Zero Pollution Action Plan”, which provided for a revision of REACH. This
included, in particular, the approach that the most harmful chemicals should only be allowed if their use was
necessary for health, safety or critical for the functioning of society and if there were no alternatives acceptable
from the standpoint of environment and health. The Commission’s proposal was subject to comprehensive and
controversial discussions with stakeholders and the Commision pushed back the revision of REACH to the last
quarter of 2023. A revision of the CLP Regulation is currently in the legislative process. It includes, in particular,
new hazard classes for endocrine disruptors and other harmful chemical substances with the aim to better protect
humans and the environment from hazardous chemicals.

Our biocidal business is particularly regulated by the Biocidal Products Regulation (EU) No. 528/2012 (“BPR”),
which entered into force on September 1, 2013. Biocidal products are used to protect humans, animals, materials
or articles against harmful organisms, like pests or bacteria. Under the BPR, the approval of active substances
takes place at the EU level and the subsequent authorization of the biocidal products at the EU member state level.
Companies have to apply for the approval of an active substance by submitting a dossier to the ECHA. Following
the approval of an active substance, companies wishing to place biocidal products on the market in an EU member
state have to apply for product authorization. We carefully monitor our compliance with the BPR and are not
aware of any infringements in connection with our operations or products.

The use of pesticides in the EU is regulated by the Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 concerning the placing of plant
protection products on the market and other EU legislative acts (such as the Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on
maximum residue levels (MRL) of pesticides in or on food and feed of plant and animal origin and the Directive
2009/128/EC establishing a framework for Community action to achieve the sustainable use of pesticides,
commonly referred to as the Sustainable Pesticide Use Directive). In June 2022, the European Commission
presented a proposal for a regulation on the sustainable use of pesticides, which would repeal and replace the
Sustainable Pesticide Use Directive. The proposal sets legally binding targets at EU level to reduce by 50% the
use and the risk of chemical pesticides as well as the use of the more hazardous pesticides by 2030, in line with
the EU’s Farm to Fork strategy. According to the draft regulation, member states would have some flexibility in
setting their own binding national reduction targets within defined parameters, allowing account to be taken of
national situations. The proposal would ban the use of all pesticides in sensitive areas. The legislative procedure
is still pending in the European Parliament and the Council.

_Germany_

We are, inter alia, subject to various notification and labeling requirements and have to comply with certain safety
obligations arising under the German Chemicals Act (Chemikaliengesetz), which mainly reflects and accompanies
REACH at the national level, but which also establishes further national requirements. As the production and
handling of chemicals is the Group’s core business, these obligations are of significant importance for its
operations.

The Ordinance on Information Requirements relating to Poisonous Substances (Giftinformationsverordnung) was
released under the German Chemicals Act. It requires persons who market certain chemical products, in particular
biocidal products, to provide information needed for precautionary safety and curative measures and emergency
situations.

The Ordinance on the Prohibition of Certain Hazardous Substances (Chemikalien-Verbotsverordnung) bans or
restricts the marketing of dangerous materials, preparations, and products. This ordinance contains requirements
that must be complied with when marketing dangerous materials, such as proof of competence and notification,
information and recording duties.

_vor gefährlichen Stoffen und Zubereitungen, Chemikaliengesetz), which (apart from the product registration_

We are, inter alia, subject to notification and labeling requirements and have to comply with certain safety
obligations arising under the Finnish Chemicals Act (Kemikaalilaki). This legislation mainly reflects and
